messages.content: You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{2\log(1-x)\arctan x}{x}-\frac{2\log(x)\arctan x}{x}dx$

<think>
Note that \begin{align} &\int_0^1 \frac{\tan^{-1} x\ln(1+x^2)}{x}\ dx \\ = & \int_0^1\int_0^\infty \frac{2\ln t}{x^2+(t+1)^2}dt \ dx = \int_0^\infty \frac{2\ln t\cot^{-1}(t+1)}{t+1} {dt}\\ \overset{x=\frac1{t+1}} =& \int_0^1 \frac{2\ln(1-x) \tan^{-1} x}{x} -\frac{2\ln x\tan^{-1} x}{x} \ dx\\ \end{align} Rearrange to arrive at \begin{align} &\int_0^1 \frac{\tan^{-1} x}{x}\ln\frac{1+x^2}{(1-x)^2}\ dx\\ =& -2\int_0^1 \frac{\ln x\tan^{-1} x}{x} dx\overset{ibp}=\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2 x}{1+x^2}dx =\frac{\pi^3}{16}\\ \end{align}
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{-a}^{a}{2\pi}dt$

<think>
Below is maybe the most elegant. Rewrite the integral as follows by averaging the two integrals following $x\to -x$ \begin{align} &\int_{-1}^1\frac1{x\sqrt{1-x^2}}\ln\frac{2\,x^2+2\,x+1}{2\,x^2-2\,x+1}\ dx \>\>\>\>\>\>\> a = \csc^{-1}{\phi}\\ = &\int_{-1}^1\frac1{x\sqrt{1-x^2}}\ln\left[ x^2(\phi+\sin^2 t)+2\phi x\sin t+1\right]\bigg|_{t=-a}^{t=a}\ dx\\ = &\int_{-1}^1\int_{-a}^{a} \frac1{\sqrt{1-x^2}}\frac{x\sin2t +2\phi\cos t}{x^2(\phi+\sin^2 t)+2\phi x\sin t+1}dt\ {dx} \>\>\>\>\>x\to\frac{1-x^2}{1+x^2}\\ =& \int_{-a}^{a}\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{4\cos t[(\phi-\sin t)x^2+(\phi+\sin t)]}{\left[(\phi-\sin t)x^2- (\phi +\sin t)\right]^2 + 4x^2\cos^2 t}dx \ dt\\ =& \int_{-a}^{a} 2\tan^{-1}\frac{(\phi-\sin t)x-({\phi+\sin t})\frac1x}{2\cos t} \bigg|_0^{\infty}dt =\int_{-a}^{a}{2\pi} dt =4\pi \csc^{-1}\phi \end{align}
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\log(x)\log(1-x^4)}{1+x^2}dx$

<think>
Presented below is a self-contained evaluation. With $\int_0^1 \frac{\ln t}{1+t^2}dt =-G$ \begin{align*} I & = \int_0^1 \frac{\ln x \ln (1-x^4 )}{1+x^2}dx \\ & = \int_0^1 \ln (1-x^4 ) d\left(\int_1^x \frac{\ln t}{1+t^2}dt \right)\\ & \overset{ibp}= \int_0^1 \frac{ 4x^3}{1-x^4}{\left(\int_0^x \frac{\ln t}{1+t^2} \overset{t=xs } {dt}+G \right) } dx \\ & =4\int_0^1 \left( \int_0^1 \frac{x^4 \ln x+x^4\ln s }{(1-x^4 )(1+x^2s^2)}ds +\frac{Gx^3}{1-x^4} \right) dx\\ & =4\int_0^1 \int_0^1 \frac{x^4\ln x}{(1-x^4)(1+x^2s^2)}dsdx -4 \int_0^1\int_0^1 \frac{\ln s}{1+x^2s^2}dx ds \\ & \>\>\>\>\>+ 4 \int_0^1 \left(\int_0^1 \frac{\ln s }{(1-x^4 )(1+x^2s^2)}ds +\frac{Gx ^3}{1-x^4} \right) dx\\ \end{align*} Integrate the 2nd integral \begin{align*} \int_0^1\int_0^1 \frac{\ln s}{1+x^2s^2}dx ds =&\int_0^1 \frac{\ln s\tan^{-1}s}sds\\ \overset{ibp}=&-\frac12 \int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2s}{1+s^2}ds=-\frac{\pi^3}{32} \end{align*} and apply the decomposition below in the 3rd integral \begin{align} &\frac{1 }{(1-x^4 )(1+x^2s^2)}\\ = &\frac{-s^4}{(1-s^4)(1+x^2s^2)} +\frac1{2(1-s^2)(1+x^2)}+ \frac1{2(1+s^2)(1-x^2)} \end{align} Then, the 1st integral cancels and \begin{align*} I =& -4\left(-\frac{\pi^3}{32}\right) +2\int_0^1 \int_0^1 \frac{\ln s }{(1-s^2 )(1+x^2)}dx ds \\ &\>\>\> + 2\int_0^1 \left( \int_0^1 \frac{\ln s }{(1+s^2 )(1-x^2)}ds +\frac{2Gx ^3}{1-x^4}\right) dx\\ = & \frac{\pi^3}8+ 2\int_0^1 \frac{\ln s ds }{1-s^2}\int_0^1\frac{dx }{1+x^2} -2G \int_0^1 \left( \frac{1}{1-x^2} -\frac{2x^3}{1-x^4}\right) dx\\ = & \frac{\pi^3}8+ 2\left(-\frac{\pi^2}{8}\right) \frac\pi4 -2G \int_0^1 \left( \frac{x}{1+x^2} +\frac{1}{1+x}\right) dx\\ = & \frac{\pi^3}{16} -3G\ln2\\ \end{align*}
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{4}}\sqrt{\tan(x)}\sqrt{1-\tan(x)}dx$

<think>
\begin{align} \int_0^{\Large\frac{\pi}{4}} \sqrt{\tan x} \sqrt{1-\tan x}\,\,dx&=\int_0^1\frac{\sqrt{y(1-y)}}{1+y^2}\,dy\quad\impliedby\quad y=\tan x\\ &=\int_0^\infty\frac{\sqrt{t}}{(1+t)(1+2t+2t^2)}\,dt\quad\impliedby\quad t=\frac{y}{1-y}\\ &=\int_0^\infty\frac{2z^2}{(1+z^2)(1+2z^2+2z^4)}\,dz\quad\impliedby\quad z^2=t\\ &=2\int_0^\infty\left[\frac{2z^2}{1+2z^2+2z^4}+\frac{1}{1+2z^2+2z^4}-\frac{1}{1+z^2}\right]\,dz\\ &=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\left[\frac{2z^2}{1+2z^2+2z^4}+\frac{1}{1+2z^2+2z^4}-\frac{1}{1+z^2}\right]\,dz\\ &=I_1+I_2-\pi \end{align} \begin{align} I_1 &=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{2z^2}{1+2z^2+2z^4}\,dz\\ &=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{z^2+\frac{1}{2z^2}+1}\,dz\\ &=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{\left(z-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}z}\right)^2+1+\sqrt{2}}\,dz\\ &=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{z^2+1+\sqrt{2}}\,dz\\ &=\frac{\pi}{\sqrt{1+\sqrt{2}}} \end{align} where the 4th line we use identity \begin{align} \int_{-\infty}^\infty f\left(x\right)\,dx=\int_{-\infty}^\infty f\left(x-\frac{a}{x}\right)\,dx\qquad,\qquad\text{for }\, a>0. \end{align} The proof can be seen in my answer here . $I_2$ can be proved in similar manner (see user111187's answer ). \begin{equation} I_2=\frac{1}{2}\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{z^4+z^2+\frac{1}{2}}\,dz=\pi\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{2}-1}{2}} \end{equation} Combine all the results together, we finally get \begin{equation} \int_0^{\Large\frac{\pi}{4}} \sqrt{\tan x} \sqrt{1-\tan x}\,\,dx=\frac{\pi}{\sqrt[4]{2}}\sqrt{\frac{2+\sqrt{2}}{2}}-\pi \end{equation}
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi}\arctan^2 \frac{a\sin(x)}{1+a\cos(x)}dx$

<think>
Below is an elementary solution, for the generalized integral \begin{align} I(a)=&\int_0^\pi\arctan^2 \frac{a\sin x}{1+a\cos x}\ dx\\ I’(a)=& \int_0^\pi\arctan\frac{a\sin x}{1+a\cos x} d\bigg[ -\frac1a \ln\left( 1+2a\cos x+ a^2\right)\bigg]\\ \overset{ibp}=& \ \frac1{2a}\int_0^\pi \ln\left( 1+2a\cos x+ a^2\right) dx \\ &\>\>\>-\frac{1-a^2}{2a}\int_0^\pi \frac{\ln\left( 1+2a\cos x+ a^2\right)}{1+2a\cos x+ a^2}\ dx\\ \end{align} Then, apply the substitutions $t=\tan\frac x2$ and $t=\frac{1+a}{1-a}\tan\frac x2$ to the 1st and 2nd integrals, respectively, to arrive at $$I’(a)=\frac1a \left[-2K(1) +K\left(\frac{1+a}{1-a}\right)+ K\left(\frac{1-a}{1+a}\right) \right] $$ where $K(p) =\int_0^\infty \frac{\ln(1+p^2t^2)}{1+t^2}dt= \pi \ln(1+p) $ . As a result \begin{align} I’(a)&=-\frac\pi a \ln(1-a^2) \\ I(a) &=\int_0^a I’(s)ds = -\pi \int_0^a \frac{\ln(1-s^2)}s ds=\frac\pi2\text{Li}_2(a^2) \end{align}
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{3}}\arccos^2(2\sin(x)^{2}-\cos(x))dx$

<think>
Computing the integral We can start by rewriting the integral in terms of its inverse, similarly as seen in this answer. $$I=\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{3}}\arccos^2(2\sin^2 x-\cos x) dx \overset{x \to \pi-x}= \int_{\frac{2\pi}{3}}^\pi\arccos^2(2\sin^2 x+\cos x) dx$$ $$\small =\pi^3-\int_0^{\pi^2} \arccos\left(\frac14-\frac14 \sqrt{17-8\cos \sqrt{y}}\right)dy\overset{y\to y^2}=\pi^3-2\int_0^{\pi} y\arccos\left(\frac14-\frac14 \sqrt{17-8\cos y}\right)dy$$ Next, we should notice that the $\arccos$ argument is the " $-$ " solution of a quadratic equation with $b=-\frac12$ and $c=\frac{\cos y}{2}-1$ in $y_{\pm}=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4c}}{2}$ . Using Vieta's relations we can easily simplify $\arccos y_-\pm\arccos y_+=\arccos\left(y_-y_+\mp\sqrt{(1+y_-y_+)^2-(y_-+y_+)^2}\, \right)$ , and therefore, it makes sense to also consider the " $+$ " solution like this: $$\mathcal J_{\pm}=\int_0^\pi y\arccos\left(\frac14\pm\frac14 \sqrt{17-8\cos y}\right)dy$$ Here it should be noted that the " $+$ " solution is a purely imaginary number, as the $\arccos$ argument is outside the $(-1,1)$ range, thus we can subtract it from the original integral and directly take the real part. $$\Rightarrow I= \pi^3-2 \mathcal J_{-}=\pi^3-2\Re\left(\mathcal J_{-}-\mathcal J_{+}\right)= \pi^3-2\Re \int_0^\pi y \arccos\left(-1+\frac12e^{iy}\right)dy$$ $$=4\Re \int_0^\pi y\arcsin\left(\frac12 e^{iy/2}\right)dy=2\Re\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(2n)!}{2^{4n} (n!)^2(2n+1)} \int_0^\pi y e^{iy(n+1/2)}dy$$ $$=4\pi \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n(2n)!}{2^{4n} (n!)^2 (2n+1)^2}-8 \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(2n)!}{2^{4n} (n!)^2 (2n+1)^3}$$ $$=8\pi\int_0^1\frac{\operatorname{arcsinh}\left(\frac{y}{2}\right)}{y}dy+16 \int_0^1 \frac{\arcsin\left(\frac{y}{2}\right)\ln y}{y}dy$$ $$=\frac{2\pi^3}{5} - \frac{7\pi^3}{27}=\boxed{\frac{19\pi^3}{135}}$$ Above we used the power series of the $\arcsin$ function (twice) as well as the one for $\operatorname{arcsinh}$ . Also, the first integral can be found here and the second one here (after integrating it by parts). Generalization It might be worth to mention that we can further attempt to generalize the integral as: $$I(k)=\int_0^\frac{\pi}{3} \arccos^k\left(2\sin^2 x- \cos x \right) dx=2k\Re \int_0^\pi y^{k-1}\arcsin\left(\frac{1}2 e^{iy/2}\right)dy$$ $$=2k\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(2n)!}{2^{4n} (n!)^2(2n+1)} \Re\left(\frac{1}{i^{k-1}}\frac{d^{k-1}}{dn^{k-1}}\frac{i+e^{in\pi}}{2n+1}\right)$$ For example, with $k=3$ we'll obtain: $$\small I(3)=\int_0^\frac{\pi}{3} \arccos^3\left(2\sin^2 x- \cos x \right) dx=6\pi^2\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n(2n)!}{2^{4n} (n!)^2(2n+1)^2}-48\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n(2n)!}{2^{4n} (n!)^2(2n+1)^4}$$ $$\small =12\pi^2\int_0^1\frac{\operatorname{arcsinh}\left(\frac{y}{2}\right)}{y}dy-48 \int_0^1 \frac{\operatorname{arcsinh}\left(\frac{y}{2}\right)\ln^2 y}{y}dy=\frac{3\pi^4}{5}-48_5F_4\left(\begin{array}{c}\tfrac12,\tfrac12,\tfrac12,\tfrac12,\tfrac12\\ \tfrac32,\tfrac32,\tfrac32,\tfrac32\end{array}\middle|-\tfrac14\right)$$ Above there's a huge chance that the last hypergeometric function can be simplified, as we have the closed form for a similar one here : $$\small _5F_4\left(\begin{array}{c}\tfrac12,\tfrac12,\tfrac12,\tfrac12,\tfrac12\\ \tfrac32,\tfrac32,\tfrac32,\tfrac32\end{array}\middle|\color{red}{\tfrac14}\right) = \frac{\pi}{12}\zeta(3)+\frac{27}{32}\operatorname{Cl}_4\big(\tfrac23\pi\big)$$ Update: Thanks to KStar 's efforts, we can indeed obtain a closed form for $I(3)$ . $$I(3)=\boxed{\frac{4\pi^4}{15}-24\zeta(3)\ln(\varphi)+2\pi^2\ln(\varphi)^2-5\ln(\varphi)^4-15\operatorname{Li}_4\left(\frac{1}{\varphi^2}\right)}$$ However, starting from $I(4)$ it seems that the integrals are no longer reducible in closed form, without introducing new special functions. $$\small I(4)=8\pi^3\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n (2n)!}{2^{4n} (n!)^2(2n+1)^2} - 192\pi\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n (2n)!}{2^{4n} (n!)^2(2n+1)^4} + 384\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(2n)!}{2^{4n} (n!)^2(2n+1)^5}$$ $$\small = 16\pi^3 \int_0^1 \frac{\operatorname{arcsinh}\left(\frac{y}{2}\right)}{y} dy - 192\pi \int_0^1 \frac{\operatorname{arcsinh}\left(\frac{y}{2}\right) \ln^2 y}{y}dy - 128 \int_0^1 \frac{\arcsin\left(\frac{y}{2}\right) \ln^3 y}{y}dy $$ $$\small =\boxed{\frac{179}{243}\pi^5-96\pi \ln(\varphi)\zeta(3)+8\pi^3\ln^2(\varphi)-20\pi \ln^4(\varphi)-60\pi\operatorname{Li}_4\left(\frac{1}{\varphi^2}\right)-96\operatorname{Gl}_{4,1}\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)}$$ Above we introduced the multiple Glaisher function, as seen in $2$ and $5.1$ from this article. In our particular case there is $\operatorname{Gl}_{4,1}\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{H_{n-1}}{n^4}\sin\frac{n\pi}{3}$ .
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\arcsin(ax)}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx$

<think>
we have : $$\arcsin(x\sqrt{i}) =\text{arctan}\left({\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{1+x^4}-1}{x^2}}}\right) + \text{i } \text{arctanh}\left({\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{1+x^4}-1}{x^2}}}\right)$$ therfore: $$I = \text{Re}\left({\int^1_0 \frac{\arcsin(x\sqrt{i})}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} dx }\right)$$ we have :(Easy proof using series expansion ) $$\int^1_0 \frac{\arcsin(ax)}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} dx = \text{Li}_2(a)-\frac{1}{4}\text{Li}_2(a^2)$$ Therfore: $$I = \text{Re}\left({\text{Li}_2(\sqrt{i})-\frac{1}{4}\text{Li}_2(i)}\right) =\frac{\pi^2}{16}$$
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\arccos(x)\arcsin^2(ax)}{x}dx$

<think>
we have : $$\arcsin(x\sqrt{i}) =\text{arctan}\left({\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{1+x^4}-1}{x^2}}}\right) + \text{i } \text{arctanh}\left({\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{1+x^4}-1}{x^2}}}\right)$$ therfore: $$I = \frac{1}{2} \text{Im}\left({\int^1_0 \frac{\arccos(x)\arcsin^2(x\sqrt{i})}{x}dx}\right)$$ we have :(Easy proof using series expansion ) $$\int^1_0 \frac{\arccos(x)\arcsin^2(ax)}{x} dx = \frac{\pi}{8}\text{Li}_3(a^2)$$ Thus: $$I = \frac{\pi}{16}\text{Im}(\text{Li}_3(i))=\frac{\pi^4}{512}$$
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\arctan x}{x^2-x-1}dx$

<think>
Original approach Note that bellow $\phi$ denotes the golden ratio and $\operatorname{Ti}_2(x)$ the inverse tangent integral . $$\int_0^1 \frac{\arctan x}{x^2-x-1}dx\overset{\small x\to\tan\frac{x}{2}}=-\frac12 \int_0^\frac{\pi}{2} \frac{x}{\sin x+2\cos x}dx\overset{\small \tan x\to x}=-\frac12\int_0^\infty \frac{\arctan x}{(2+x)\sqrt{1+x^2}}dx$$ $$\overset{x\to \frac{1/2+x}{1-x/2}}=-\frac{1}{2\sqrt 5}\int_{-\frac12}^2\frac{\arctan\left(\small \frac{\frac{1}{2}+x}{1-\frac{x}{2}}\right)}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}dx =-\frac{2}{\sqrt 5}\arctan\left(\frac12\right) \ln \phi-\frac{1}{2\sqrt 5}\int_\frac12^2 \frac{\arctan x}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}dx$$ $$\overset{\large x\to \frac{x^2-1}{2x}}=-\frac{2}{\sqrt 5}\arctan\left(\frac12\right) \ln \phi+\frac{\pi}{2\sqrt 5}\ln \phi-\frac{1}{\sqrt 5}\int_{\phi}^{\phi^3}\frac{\arctan x}{x}dx$$ $$=\boxed{\frac{4\ln \phi}{\sqrt 5}\arctan\frac{1}{\phi}-\frac{\pi\ln \phi}{2\sqrt 5}+\frac{1}{\sqrt 5}\left(\operatorname{Ti}_2\left(\phi\right)-\operatorname{Ti}_2\left(\phi^3\right)\right)}$$ Another approach This is based on the fact that we can rewrite $\sin x+2\cos x$ as $\sqrt 5 \sin\left(x+2\arctan \frac{1}{\phi}\right)$ . $$\int_0^1 \frac{\arctan x}{x^2-x-1}dx\overset{\small x\to\tan\frac{x}{2}}=-\frac{1}{2\sqrt 5} \int_0^\frac{\pi}{2} \frac{x}{\sin\left(x+2\arctan \frac{1}{\phi}\right)}dx$$ $$\overset{x+2\arctan \frac{1}{\phi}\to x}=\frac{\arctan \frac{1}{\phi}}{\sqrt 5} \int_{2\arctan \frac{1}{\phi}}^{2\arctan \phi^3}\frac{dx}{\sin x}-\frac{1}{2\sqrt{5}}\int_{2\arctan \frac{1}{\phi}}^{2\arctan \phi^3} \frac{x}{\sin x}dx$$ $$\overset{\tan\frac{x}{2}\to x}=\frac{4\ln \phi}{\sqrt 5}\arctan \frac{1}{\phi}-\frac{1}{\sqrt 5}\int_{\frac{1}{\phi}}^{\phi^3} \frac{\arctan x}{x}dx$$ $$=\boxed{\frac{4\ln \phi}{\sqrt 5}\arctan \frac{1}{\phi}-\frac{1}{\sqrt 5}\left(\operatorname{Ti}_2\left(\phi^3\right)-\operatorname{Ti}_2\left(\frac{1}{\phi}\right)\right)}$$
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{4(1+t^2)}{1+14t^2+t^4}\arctan\left(\frac{2\sqrt{2}\sqrt{1-t^2}}{1+3t^2}\right)dt$

<think>
We have $$ I = \frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{+\infty}\arctan\left(\frac{\sqrt{x^2+x\sqrt{x^2+1}}}{\sqrt{x^2+1}-\frac{x}{2}}\right)\frac{dx}{1+\frac{x^2}{4}}=\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{+\infty}\arctan\left(\frac{\sqrt{e^z\sinh z}}{\cosh z-\frac{\sinh z}{2}}\right)\frac{\cosh z}{1+\frac{\sinh^2z}{4}}$$ or $$\begin{eqnarray*} I &=& \int_{0}^{1}\frac{4(1+t^2)}{1+14t^2+t^4}\arctan\left(\frac{2\sqrt{2}\sqrt{1-t^2}}{1+3t^2}\right)\,dt\\&=&\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{4(1+\sin^2\theta)\cos\theta}{1+14\sin^2\theta+\sin^4\theta}\arctan\left(\frac{2\sqrt{2}\cos\theta}{1+3\sin^2\theta}\right)\,d\theta\end{eqnarray*}$$ where $$ \frac{4(1+t^2)}{1+14t^2+t^4}=\frac{2-\sqrt{3}}{t^2+(2-\sqrt{3})^2}+\frac{2+\sqrt{3}}{t^2+(2+\sqrt{3})^2}$$ and integration by parts lead to $$ I=\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{ 8 \sqrt{2} \sin (t) (3 \cos (2 t)+11)}{-28 \cos (2 t)+9 \cos (4 t)+91}\left(\arctan\left(\frac{\sin (t)}{2-\sqrt{3}}\right)+\arctan\left(\frac{\sin (t)}{2+\sqrt{3}}\right)\right)\,dt.$$ Let us define $$\begin{eqnarray*} J(a) &=& \int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{ 8 \sqrt{2} \sin (t) (3 \cos (2 t)+11)}{-28 \cos (2 t)+9 \cos (4 t)+91}\arctan(a\sin t)\,dt\\&=&\int_{0}^{a}\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{ 8 \sqrt{2} \sin (t) (3 \cos (2 t)+11)}{-28 \cos (2 t)+9 \cos (4 t)+91}\cdot\frac{\sin(t)}{1+b^2\sin^2(t)}\,dt\,db\\&=&\int_{0}^{a}\frac{\pi \left(\left(3 \left(5+i \sqrt{5}\right) \sqrt{b^2+1}-14 \sqrt{2+i \sqrt{5}}\right) b^2+3 \left(5+i \sqrt{5}\right) \sqrt{b^2+1}-6 \sqrt{2+i \sqrt{5}}\right)}{\sqrt{4+2 i \sqrt{5}} \sqrt{b^2+1} \left(9 b^4+2 b^2+9\right)}\,db. \end{eqnarray*}$$ The last equality follows from the Poisson kernel. The last integral can be computed via $b\mapsto\sinh u$ and it is a linear combination of $\log(-b+\sqrt{1+b^2}-\xi)$ over the roots of $3 + 8 z + 6 z^2 - 8 z^3 + 3 z^4$ . With the help of a CAS it is not difficult to check that $I=J(2+\sqrt{3})+J(2-\sqrt{3})$ equals $\zeta(2)$ . On the other hand, admittedly, this is not an elegant approach.
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi}\log(1+\sin(x))\, dx$

<think>
$$\begin{align*} \int_0^\pi \log(1+\sin x) \, dx &= 2 \int_0^\infty \frac{\log\left(1+\frac{2y}{1+y^2}\right)}{1+y^2} \, dy & y=\tan\frac x2 \\ &= 2 \int_{-1}^1 \frac{\log\frac2{1+y^2}}{1+y^2} \, dy & y\to\frac{1-y}{1+y} \\ &= \pi \log 2 - 4 \int_0^1 \frac{\log\left(1+y^2\right)}{1+y^2} \, dy \\ &= 4G - \pi\log2 \end{align*}$$ The last integral is evaluated in a number of ways in this earlier question .
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\arctan^2(x^2)}{x^2\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx$

<think>
Use the substitution $x^2=\frac{1}{u^2+1}$ $$I=\int_0^1\frac{\arctan^2(x^2)}{x^2\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx=\int_0^\infty\arctan^2\left(\frac{1}{x^2+1}\right)dx$$ Use integration by parts with $u=\arctan^2\left(\frac{1}{x^2+1}\right),\space dv=dx$ $$I=\int_0^\infty\frac{4x^2}{x^4+2x^2+2}\arctan\left(\frac{1}{x^2+1}\right)dx=-4\Im\int_0^\infty\frac{x^2\ln(x^2+1-i)}{(x^2+1-i)(x^2+1+i)}dx$$ Evaluate using partial fractions and the following integral identity, which can be proved easily using a double integral or Leibniz's rule. $$\int_0^\infty\frac{\ln(x^2+a)}{x^2+b}dx=\frac{\pi}{\sqrt b}\ln(\sqrt a+\sqrt b)$$ $$\frac{x^2}{(x^2+1-i)(x^2+1+i)}=\frac{\frac{1-i}{2}}{x^2+1+i}+\frac{\frac{1+i}{2}}{x^2+1-i}$$ $$I=-4\Im\int_0^\infty\left(\frac{1-i}{2}\frac{\ln(x^2+1-i)}{x^2+1+i}+\frac{1+i}{2}\frac{\ln(x^2+1-i)}{x^2+1-i}\right) dx$$ $$=-2\Im\left((1-i)\frac{\pi}{\sqrt{1+i}}\ln(\sqrt{1-i}+\sqrt{1+i})+(1+i)\frac{\pi}{\sqrt{1-i}}\ln(\sqrt{1-i}+\sqrt{1-i})\right)$$ WolframAlpha simplifies this to $$I=\int_0^1\frac{\arctan^2(x^2)}{x^2\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx$$ $$=\frac{\pi}{2^{7/4}}\left(\sqrt{2+\sqrt2}\ln\left(\frac{3+2\sqrt2}{8}\right)+\pi\frac{\sqrt{2-\sqrt2}}{2}\right)$$ $$=\frac{\pi^2}{4}\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt2-1}{2}}+\pi\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt2+1}{2}}\ln\left(\frac{\sqrt2+1}{2\sqrt2}\right)$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{x^n}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx$

<think>
The integral $I_n= \int_0^1 x^n \sqrt{1-x^2}\ln x\ dx $ has the closed form $$\color{blue}{I_n=\frac{(n-1)!!}{(n+2)!!}\bigg(\ln2 + \frac{(-1)^n}{n+2}+\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{(-1)^{k}}{k}\bigg) \bigg( \sin^2\frac{n \pi}2-\frac\pi2 \cos^2\frac{n \pi}2 \bigg) }\tag1$$ derived below via a recursive elementary procedure. $$ \int_0^1 \frac{x^n }{\sqrt{1-x^2}} dx =\frac{n-1}n \int_0^1 \frac{x^{n-2} }{\sqrt{1-x^2}} dx +\frac1n x^{n-1} \sqrt{1-x^2}dx $$ from which one can integrate $K_n $ below by parts to establish the recursion $$ \int_0^1 \frac{x^n \ln x}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} dx =K_n =\frac{n-1}{n} K_{n-2}+\frac1n\int_0^1 x^{n-2} \sqrt{1-x^2}dx$$ Then, with $\int_0^1 x^{m} \sqrt{1-x^2}dx=\frac{(m-1)!!}{(m+2)!!} \left(\sin^2\frac{m \pi}2+\frac\pi2 \cos^2\frac{m\pi}2\right) $ , evaluate $K_n$ recursively \begin{align} K_n= &\ \frac{n-1}{n} K_{n-2}+ \frac{(n-1)!!}{n!!} \bigg(\frac1{n-1}-\frac1n\bigg) \left(\sin^2\frac{n \pi}2+\frac\pi2 \cos^2\frac{n \pi}2\right) \\ =& \ \frac{n-1}{n} \frac{n-3}{n-2} K_{n-4} + \frac{(n-1)!!}{n!!} \bigg(\frac1{n-3}-\frac1{n-2}+\frac1{n-1}-\frac1n\bigg) \left(\sin^2\frac{n \pi}2+\frac\pi2 \cos^2\frac{n \pi}2\right) \\ =&\ \cdots\\ =&\ \frac{(n-1)!!}{n!!}\bigg( \ln2 +\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{(-1)^k}k\bigg)\left(\sin^2\frac{n \pi}2-\frac\pi2 \cos^2\frac{n \pi}2\right) \\ \end{align} where the starting values $K_1= \int_0^1 \frac{x\ln x}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} dx =\ln2 -1$ and $K_0= \int_0^1 \frac{\ln x}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} dx =-\frac\pi2 \ln2$ are used in the last step. Finally, calculate $I_n = K_n- K_{n+2}\ $ to obtain the closed form (1).
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{E\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^2+8}}\right)dx}{\sqrt{8-7x^2-x^4}}$

<think>
I'm not going to accept this answer. I wonder if someone comes with a different approach (even if it is more difficult). We are going to see: \begin{align*} I(s)=\frac{1}{2}\frac{2-s^2}{\sqrt{1-s^2}}\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{E\left(\frac{s^2\sin{x}}{2\sqrt{s^2-1}}\right)dx}{1-\left(\frac{s^2\sin{x}}{2\sqrt{s^2-1}}\right)^2}=E(s)K(s)\hspace{.5cm} 0 < s \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},\tag{1} \end{align*} using series approach that I want to avoid. But maybe in this case this approach is easier to understand and more direct than the method in the paper suggested by @Zacky. The integral in question is the particular case: \begin{align*}\frac{1}{3}I\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \right)=\int_{0}^{1}\frac{E\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^2+8}} \right)dx}{\sqrt{8-7x^2-x^4}}=\frac{1}{3}K\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)E\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) =\frac{\pi}{12}+\frac{\Gamma^{4}(\frac{1}{4})}{96\pi},\end{align*} where we have used $K(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}})=\frac{\Gamma^2(\frac{1}{4})}{4\sqrt{\pi}}$ and $E(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}})=\frac{\Gamma^2(\frac{1}{4})}{8\sqrt{\pi}}+\frac{\pi^{3/2}}{\Gamma^2(\frac{1}{4})}$ . To obtain $(1)$ we begin with the well known expansion: \begin{align*}K(k)=\frac{\pi}{2}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(2n)!^2}{2^{4n}n!^4}k^{2n}\hspace{.5cm} 0 < k \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},\tag{2} \end{align*} and the relation: \begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{dK}}{\mathrm{d}k}=\frac{E(k)}{k(1-k^2)} - \frac{K(k)}{k}.\tag{3} \end{align*} Using $(2)$ and $(3)$ then: \begin{align*} k\frac{\mathrm{dK}}{\mathrm{d}k}+K(k)=\frac{E(k)}{1-k^2}=\frac{\pi}{2}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(2n)!^2(2n+1)}{2^{4n}n!^4}k^{2n}\hspace{.5cm} 0 < k \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}.\tag{4} \end{align*} Replacing in $(4)$ with $k=l\sin{x}$ , integrating in $(0,\pi/2)$ and applying Wallis' formula $\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\sin^{2n}{x}dx=\frac{\pi}{2}\frac{(2n)!}{2^{2n}n!^2}$ , we obtain: \begin{align*} \frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{E\left(l\sin{x} \right)dx}{1-l^2\sin^2{x}}=\frac{\pi^2}{8}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(2n)!^3(2n+1)}{2^{6n}n!^6}l^{2n}\hspace{.5cm} 0 < l \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}.\tag{5} \end{align*} In the other hand we proved here ( Integrals of elliptic integrals. ) that: \begin{align*} \frac{\sqrt{1-s^2}}{2-s^2}E(s)K(s)=\frac{\pi^2}{8}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(2n)!^3 (2n+1)}{2^{8n}n!^6}\left(\frac{s^4}{s^2-1}\right)^n\hspace{.5cm} 0 < s \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}.\tag{6} \end{align*} Finally setting $l=\frac{s^{2}}{2\sqrt{s^2-1}}$ in $(5)$ and comparing with $(6)$ the equality in $(1)$ follows.
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}x^a\frac{\log(1-x)\log(1+x)^{2}}{1-x}\, dx$

<think>
Let's consider the general case $$I(a,n)= \int_{0}^{1}x^a\ln^n (x)\frac{\ln(1-x) \ln^2(1+x)}{1-x} \, dx;\,n=0,1... $$ All we need is the following expansion: $$\ln^2(1-x)=2\sum_{m=2}^{\infty}\frac{H_{m-1}}{m}x^m$$ where $$H_{m}=\sum_{k=1}^{m}\frac{1}{k}$$ Now differentiate the expansion with respect to $x$ $$\frac{\ln(1-x)}{1-x}=-\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}H_{m}x^m$$ In the original expansion, we take $-x$ instead of $x$ $$\ln^2(1+x)=2\sum_{m=2}^{\infty}(-1)^m\frac{H_{m-1}}{m}x^m$$ Now we form the product $$x^a\frac{\ln(1-x) \ln^2(1+x)}{1-x}$$ and integrate $$\int_{0}^{1}x^a\frac{\ln(1-x) \ln^2(1+x)}{1-x} \, dx = $$ $$=-2\sum_{m=3}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^mf(m)}{m+1+a}$$ where $$f(m)=\sum_{i=1}^{m-1}(-1)^i\frac{H_{i}H_{m-1-i}}{m-i}$$ Finally, we differentiate the obtained result by $a$ $n$ times and get the final result: $$I(a,n)=-2(-1)^nn!\sum_{m=3}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^mf(m)}{(m+1+a)^{n+1}}$$ We get the integral given in the original post here by taking $a=0$ and $n=2$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\log^2\left(2 t \sqrt{1 - t^2}\right)}{1 + t}dt$

<think>
Different method for calculating $\Omega=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\ln^2\left(2 t \sqrt{1 - t^2}\right)}{1 + t}dt$ obtained by @Bertrand87 above: $$\Omega=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\ln^2\left(2 t \sqrt{1 - t^2}\right)}{1 + t}dt$$ $$=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\ln^2(2 t) }{1 + t}dt+\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\ln(t)\ln(1-x^2)}{1 + t}dt+\ln(2)\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\ln(1-x^2)}{1 + t}dt+\frac14\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\ln^2(1-x^2)}{1 + t}dt.$$ The first integral is $\frac32\zeta(3)-\ln(2)\zeta(2)+\ln^3(2)$ . The second integral can be found by using the generalization given in Theorem 3 of this preprint : $$ \int_0^1\frac{\ln^{q-1}(t)\ln(1-t^2)}{1+t}dt=(-1)^qq!\,\eta(q+1)-(-1)^q(q-1)!(2-2^{1-q})\ln(2)\zeta(q)$$ $$-(-1)^q(q-1)!\sum_{k=1}^{q-2}\zeta(q-k)\eta(k+1),\quad q=2,3,4,\cdots.$$ $$\Longrightarrow \int_0^1\frac{\ln(t)\ln(1-t^2)}{1+t}dt=\frac32\zeta(3)-\frac32\ln(2)\zeta(2).$$ As for the third and fourth integrals, we already have the generalization : $$\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^{q-1}(1-t^2)}{1+t}dt=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2q}\lim_{y\to 1}\frac{\partial^{q}}{\partial y^{q}}\frac{\Gamma(y)}{\Gamma(y-\frac12)},\quad q=2,3,4,\cdots$$ $$\Longrightarrow \int_0^1 \frac{\ln(1-t^2)}{1+t}dt=\ln^2(2)-\frac12\zeta(2);$$ $$\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2(1-t^2)}{1+t}dt=2\zeta(3)-2\ln(2)\zeta(2)+\frac43\ln^3(2).$$ Combine all integrals, we get $$\Omega=\frac72\zeta(3)-\frac72\ln(2)\zeta(2)+\frac73\ln^3(2).$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{1 - e^{-sx^2}}{x^2}\, dx$

<think>
We first note that, for $\operatorname{Re}(s) > 0$ , $$\begin{align*} F(s) := \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{1 - e^{-sx^2}}{x^2} \, \mathrm{d}x &= \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{s} e^{-tx^2} \, \mathrm{d}t\mathrm{d}x \\ &= \int_{0}^{s} \frac{1}{2}\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{t}} \, \mathrm{d}t \\ &= \sqrt{\pi s}. \end{align*}$$ Using this, we get $$\begin{align*} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-x^2}\sin^2(\alpha x^2)}{x^2} \, \mathrm{d}x &= \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-x^2}[1-\cos(2\alpha x^2)]}{x^2} \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \operatorname{Re} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-x^2}[1-e^{-2\alpha x^2 i}]}{x^2} \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \operatorname{Re} \left[ F(1+2\alpha i) - F(1) \right]. \end{align*}$$ Plugging the formula for $F(s)$ , this reduces to $$ \sqrt{\pi} \operatorname{Re} \left[ \sqrt{1+2\alpha i} - 1 \right] = \sqrt{\pi} \Biggl( \sqrt{\frac{1+\sqrt{1+4\alpha^2}}{2}} - 1 \Biggr). $$
</think>

If you use $$\log ^2(1-x)=\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac {a_n}{b_n}\,x^{n+2}$$ where the $a_n$ and $b_n$ correspond respectively to sequences $A002547$ and $A002548$ in $OEIS$ (all of them are positive). If $$c_n=\frac {a_n}{b_n}\quad \implies \quad c_n=\frac {(n-1) (2 n-3)\,c_{n-1}-(n-2)^2 \,c_{n-2}} {n(n-1) }$$ with $c_0=c_1=0$ and $c_2=1$ . $$\int_0^1\frac{\tan ^{-1}(x)}{x}\,\log ^2(1-x)\,dx=\sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n\,\int_0^1x^{n+1}\tan ^{-1}(x)\,dx$$ $$I_n=\int_0^1x^{n+1}\tan ^{-1}(x)\,dx=\frac 1{4(n+2)}\ \left(H_{\frac{n-1}{4}}-H_{\frac{n+1}{4}}+\pi \right)$$ Notice that $$\frac {I_{n+1}}{I_n}=1-\frac{1}{n}+\frac{2+3 \pi }{\pi n^2} +O\left(\frac{1}{n^3}\right)$$ and that $$\frac {c_{n+1}}{c_n}=1-\frac{3}{4 n}+\frac{2}{n^2}+O\left(\frac{1}{n^3}\right)$$ make $$\frac {c_{n+1}\,I_{n+1}}{c_n\,I_n}=1-\frac{7}{4 n}+\frac{8+23 \pi }{4 \pi n^2}+O\left(\frac{1}{n^3}\right)$$ This explains why the convergence is extremely slow. Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{dt}{\sqrt{n-t^3}}$

<think>
First solution Using the binomial expansion $$\frac{1}{\sqrt{n-t^3}}=\sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k\, \binom{-\frac{1}{2}}{k}\,n^{-k-\frac{1}{2}}\, t^{3 k}=\sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k\,\frac{\sqrt{\pi }}{\Gamma\left(\frac{1}{2}-k\right) \Gamma(k+1)}\,n^{-k-\frac{1}{2}}\, t^{3 k}$$ Integrating termwise $$I=\int \frac{dt}{\sqrt{n-t^3}}=\sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k\,\frac{\sqrt{\pi }\,\,n^{-k-\frac{1}{2}}}{(3 k+1) \Gamma\left(\frac{1}{2}-k\right) \Gamma (k+1)}\, t^{3n+1}$$ that is to say $$\frac{t}{\sqrt{n}}\sum_{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k\,\frac{\sqrt{\pi }\, n^{-k} t^{3 k}}{(3k+1) \Gamma\left(\frac{1}{2}-k\right) \Gamma(k+1)}\,t^{3n}$$ The remaining summation is the definition of a Gaussian hypergeometric function $$I=\frac{t}{\sqrt{n}}\,\, _2F_1\left(\frac{1}{3},\frac{1}{2}; \frac{4}{3};\frac{t^3}{n}\right)$$ and then, using the bounds $$\int_0^1\frac{dt}{\sqrt{n-t^3}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\,\,\, _2F_1\left(\frac{1}{3},\frac{1}{2};\frac{4}{3};\frac{1}{n}\right)$$ More generally $$\int_0^1\frac{dt}{\sqrt{n-t^m}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\,\,\, _2F_1\left(\frac{1}{m},\frac{1}{2}; \frac{m+1}{m};\frac{1}{n}\right)$$ Remark Notice that, if you write $$\frac{1}{\sqrt{n-t^3}}=\frac 1 {\sqrt{(r_1-t)\,(r_2-t)\,(r_3-t)}}$$ the result can be given in terms of elliptic integrals. $$I=\int \frac{dt}{\sqrt{n-t^3}}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{r_1-r_2}}F\left(\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{\sqrt{r_1-r_2}}{ \sqrt{r_1-t}}\right)|\frac{r_1-r_3}{r_1-r_2}\right)$$

Substitute $t = e^x$ , along with the shorthand $b= e^a$ \begin{align*} I= &\int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{e^x}{e^{2x}+e^{2a}}\frac{1}{x^2+\pi^2}dx =\int_0^\infty \frac1{(t^2+b^2)(\ln^2t+\pi^2)}dt\\ =& \int_0^\infty \frac{(1+t)-\frac{2b^2}{1+b^2}(t-\frac1t) }{(t^2+b^2)(\ln^2t+\pi^2) } - \frac{\frac1{1+b^2}}{t( \ln^2t+\pi^2) }\ dt \end{align*} Then, utilize the integral expressions $$\frac{1+t}{\ln^2t+\pi^2}= \frac1\pi\int_0^1 \sin(\pi y)t^{1-y}dy$$ $$\frac{t-\frac1t}{\ln^2t+\pi^2}=\frac2\pi\int_0^1 \sin(2\pi y)t^{1-2y}dy$$ and $ \int_0^\infty \frac1{t(\ln^2t+\pi^2)}dt=1 $ to evaluate \begin{align*} I= & \int_0^\infty \frac1{t^2+b^2} \left(\frac1\pi\int_0^1 \sin\pi y \ {t^{1-y}} -\frac{2b^2\sin2\pi y\ t^{1-2y}}{1+b^2}\ dy\right)dt\\ &\>\>\>\>\> -\frac1{1+b^2}\int_0^\infty \frac1{t(\ln^2t+\pi^2)}dt\\ = & \int_0^1 \int_0^\infty \frac{\sin\pi y \ {t^{1-y}}}{\pi(t^2+b^2)} -\frac{2b^2\sin2\pi y\ t^{1-2y}}{\pi(1+b^2)(t^2+b^2)}\ dt\ dy-\frac1{1+b^2}\\ =& \int_0^1 \cos\frac{\pi y}2 b^{-y}dy - \frac{2b^2}{1+b^2} \int_0^1 \cos\pi y\ b^{-2y}dy - \frac1{1+b^2}\\ =&\ \frac{2\pi+4b\ln b}{b(4\ln^2 b+\pi^2)} -\frac{4\ln b}{4\ln^2 b+\pi^2}- \frac1{1+b^2}\\ =&\ \frac{2\pi}{b(4\ln^2 b+\pi^2)}- \frac1{1+b^2} = \frac{2\pi e^{-a}}{4a^2+\pi^2}-\frac{1}{1+e^{2a}} \end{align*}

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{6}}\arcsin(\sqrt{\cos(3x)\cos(x)})dx$

<think>
$$I=\int_0^{\frac \pi 6}\arcsin\Bigl(\sqrt{\cos(3x)\cos(x)}\Bigr)\,dx$$ If we use the series expansion of the arc sine function, we should have to compute $$\sum_{n=0}^\infty\frac{ (2 n)!}{4^n\,(2 n+1) (n!)^2}\int_0^{\frac \pi 6}\Big(\cos (3x) \cos ( x)\Big)^{\frac{2 n+1}{2} }\,dx$$ $$J_n=\int_0^{\frac \pi 6}\Big(\cos (3x) \cos ( x)\Big)^{\frac{2 n+1}{2} }\,dx$$ Given by a CAS, the corresponding antiderivative is given in terms of the Appell hypergeometric function of two variables and $$J_n=-\frac{\pi ^{3/2}\, 4^n}{\Gamma \left(-2 n-\frac{1}{2}\right) \Gamma (2 n+2)}\, _2F_1\left(-2 n-1,-n-\frac{1}{2};-2 n-\frac{1}{2};\frac{3}{4}\right)$$ which are all positive. Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{4}}\int_{2-\sec^2\theta}^{2}\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt{u}dud\theta$

<think>
Another way is to start with the easy first iteration: $$ I=\int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{\sqrt{3-x^2-y^2-z^2} }\text{d}x \text{d}y\text{d}z=\int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1}\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt{2-x^2-y^2} $$ and then switching to polar coordinates: $$I=2\int_0^{\frac\pi 4}\int_0^{\sec\theta }r\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt{2-r^2}\,drd\theta=\int_0^{\frac\pi 4}\int_{2-\sec^2\theta}^2\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt{u}\,dud\theta $$ Luckily $\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt u$ has a nice anti-derivative and we get $$I=\frac{\sqrt2}4 \pi+\frac34\pi\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt2-I_1+I_2-3I_3$$ where $$I_1=\int_0^{\frac\pi4}\sqrt{2-\sec^2\theta}\,d\theta$$ $$I_2=\int_0^{\frac\pi4}\sec^2\theta\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt{2-\sec^2\theta}\,d\theta$$ and $$I_3=\int_0^{\frac\pi4}\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt{2-\sec^2\theta}\,d\theta.$$ I think, each integral $I_k$ above is an Ahmed-type integral and can be evaluated by similar techniques. You may see this answer . If I did not do any mistakes, the final (exact) result is $$I=\frac{3}8\pi^2+\frac32\pi-\frac{3\sqrt2}4 \pi-\frac94\pi\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt2$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{a}^{+\infty}\left(\frac{\pi}{u}\right)^{\frac{n}{2}}du$

<think>
You have already computed $S(1)$ and $S(2)$ . So let's assume that $n\geq 3$ . Define: $$f_n(a, b) = \int_{\mathbb R}\dots \int_{\mathbb R} \frac{e^{-(a-ib)(x_1^2+\dots+x_n^2)}}{x_1^2+\dots+x_n^2}dx_1\dots dx_n$$ Clearly, by evaluating at $a=0$ and $b=1$ and taking the imaginary part: $$S(n)=\Im f_n(0, 1)$$ Now $$\begin{split} \frac{\partial f_n}{\partial a}(a,0) &= -\int_{\mathbb R}\dots \int_{\mathbb R} e^{-a(x_1^2+\dots+x_n^2)}dx_1\dots dx_n\\ &=-\left( \int_{\mathbb R}e^{-ax^2}dx\right)^n\\ &=-\left(\frac \pi a\right)^{\frac n 2} \end{split}$$ Thus, noting that $f(a,0)\rightarrow 0$ as $a\rightarrow +\infty$ , $$f(a,0)=\int_a^{+\infty}\left(\frac \pi u\right)^{\frac n 2}du=-\frac{\pi^{\frac n 2}}{1-\frac n 2}\cdot\frac {1}{a^{\frac n 2 -1}}\tag{1}$$ Also $$\begin{split} \frac{\partial f_n}{\partial b}(a,b) &= i\int_{\mathbb R}\dots \int_{\mathbb R} e^{-(a-ib)(x_1^2+\dots+x_n^2)}dx_1\dots dx_n\\ &=i\left( \int_{\mathbb R}e^{-(a-ib)x^2}dx\right)^n\\ &=i\left(\frac{\pi}{a-ib}\right)^{\frac n 2} \end{split}$$ Thus $$ f(a,b)-f(a,0)=\int_0^b i\left(\frac{\pi}{a-iv}\right)^{\frac n 2}dv\\ =\frac {\pi^{\frac n 2}} {\frac n 2-1}\cdot \left(\frac 1 {(a-ib)^{\frac n 2 -1}} - \frac 1 {a^{\frac n 2 -1}}\right) $$ Combining with $(1)$ gives $$f(a,b)=\frac {\pi^{\frac n 2}} {\frac n 2-1}\cdot \frac 1 {(a-ib)^{\frac n 2 -1}} $$ Thus $$f(0,1) = \frac {\pi^{\frac n 2}} {\frac n 2-1}\cdot \frac 1 {(-i)^{\frac n 2 -1}} = -\frac {i\pi^{\frac n 2}} {\frac n 2-1}e^{\frac{i\pi n}{4}}$$ and $$\boxed{S(n)=-\frac{\pi^{\frac n 2}}{\frac n 2 -1}\cos\left(\frac {n\pi}4\right)}$$ Edit: As noted by @Ninad Munshi, this formula works for all $n\geq 1$ (not just $n\geq 3$ ). For $n=2$ , you need to take the limit $n\rightarrow 2$ .
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}x^{2n-1}\arctan(x)dx$

<think>
Exploiting $$\int_0^1 x^{2n-1}\arctan(x)\textrm{d}x=\frac{1}{2n}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\pi}{4}(-1)^{n-1}-(-1)^{n-1} \overline{O}_n\right),$$ which may be found proved in https://www.researchgate.net/publication/387133626 , together with the following integral representation of the $n$ th skew-harmonic of the second kind, $\displaystyle \frac12\int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\sin(2nx)}{\sin x}\textrm{d}x=\overline{O}_n$ , recently used in https://math.stackexchange.com/q/5090796 , we get that $$\int_0^1\frac{\arctan(x)\arctan(x^2)}{x}\textrm{d}x$$ $$=\frac{\pi}{4}G-\frac{\pi}{8} \int_0^{\pi/4} \frac{x}{\sin (x)} \textrm{d}x-\frac{\pi}{8} \int_0^{\pi/4} \frac{x}{\cos (x)} \textrm{d}x$$ $$=\frac{\pi}{2}G+\log(\sqrt{2}-1)\frac{\pi^2}{16}-\frac{\pi}{2}\operatorname{Ti}_2(\sqrt{2}-1),$$ where with simple substitutions (and integration by parts), we can get for both integrals forms in terms of the inverse tangent integral, $\displaystyle \operatorname{Ti}_2(x)=\int_0^x \frac{\arctan(t)}{t}\textrm{d}t$ . Note that we may write that $2(\operatorname{arctanh}(\tan(x/2)))'= \sec(x)$ . In the literature, I think we have very few special values for $\operatorname{Ti}_2$ , which should immediately help us establish the final closed form. Here is the short explanation of the fact that one can write the resulting integral from the closed form in terms of Polygamma function (and the form by Mariusz Iwaniuk can still be improved in terms of simplicity): Observe that $$\int_0^{\pi/4} \frac{x}{\sin (x)} \textrm{d}x=\frac{\pi}{4} \log \left(\sqrt{2}-1\right)-\int_0^{\pi/4} \log \left(\tan \left(\frac{x}{2}\right)\right) \textrm{d}x,$$ and if we use Fourier series for the remaining integral, we get $$\int_0^{\pi/4} \log \left(\tan \left(\frac{x}{2}\right)\right) \textrm{d}x=-2\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{\sin((2n-1)\pi/4)}{(2n-1)^2},$$ and we note that $\sqrt{2}\sin((2n-1)\pi/4) = 1, 1, -1, -1, 1, 1, -1, -1, ...$ , which is a bit scary, but one remedy is to exploit the parity, and from here we arrive immediately at the desired forms with Polygamma. End of story
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{w^{2}}{2-w^{2}}\cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-w^{2}}}dw$

<think>
You asked for a method to evaluate the integral. I propose you a numerical method You can write \begin{align*} \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\arctan\left(\sqrt{\tan\left(x\right)}+\sqrt{\cot\left(x\right)}\right)dx=&2\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{4}}\arctan\left(\sqrt{\tan\left(x\right)}+\sqrt{\cot\left(x\right)}\right)dx\\ =&2\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\arctan\left(t^{\frac{1}{2}}+t^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)}{1+t^{2}}dt\\ =&\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\arctan\left(2\cosh\left(\frac{s}{2}\right)\right)}{\cosh\left(s\right)}ds\\ =&2\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\arctan\left(2\cosh\left(s\right)\right)}{2\cosh\left(s\right)^{2}-1}ds\\ =&2\int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{2z^{2}-1}\cdot\frac{\arctan\left(2z\right)}{\sqrt{z^{2}-1}}dz\\ =&2\int_{0}^{1}\frac{w}{2-w^{2}}\cdot\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-\arctan\left(\frac{w}{2}\right)}{\sqrt{1-w^{2}}}dw\\ =&\pi\cdot\frac{\pi}{4}-2\int_{0}^{1}\frac{w}{2-w^{2}}\cdot\frac{\arctan\left(\frac{w}{2}\right)}{\sqrt{1-w^{2}}}dw \end{align*} Then you can approximate $$\arctan\left(\frac{w}{2}\right)\approx \frac{w}{2}-\frac{w^{3}}{24}+\frac{w^{5}}{160}-\frac{w^{7}}{896}$$ And using $$\int_{0}^{1}\frac{w^{2}}{2-w^{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-w^{2}}}dw=\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}-\frac{1}{2}\right)\pi$$ $$\int_{0}^{1}\frac{w^{4}}{2-w^{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-w^{2}}}dw=\left(\sqrt{2}-\frac{5}{4}\right)\pi$$ $$\int_{0}^{1}\frac{w^{6}}{2-w^{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-w^{2}}}dw=\left(2\left(1+\sqrt{2}\right)-\frac{75}{16}\right)\pi$$ $$\int_{0}^{1}\frac{w^{8}}{2-w^{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-w^{2}}}dw=\left(4\left(1+\sqrt{2}\right)-\frac{305}{32}\right)\pi$$ You have $$I\approx \pi\cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{93056\sqrt{2}-89689}{215040}\right)$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\log(1-t^2)-\log(t)}{1+t^2}dt$

<think>
Substitute $u=y+\frac\pi2$ and then split the integral \begin{align} I=& \int_{0}^{\pi}\frac{u}{1-\cos u}\ln \frac{1+\sin u}{1-\sin u} \>{d}u\\ =&\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\bigg( \frac{\frac\pi2+y}{1+\sin y}+ \frac{\frac\pi2-y}{1-\sin y}\bigg)\ln\frac{1+\cos y}{1-\cos y}\overset{t=\tan\frac y2}{dy}\\ = & -4\pi\int_0^1 \frac{\ln t}{(1+t)^2}dt- 32\int_0^1 \frac{(\frac\pi4 - \tan^{-1} t)\> t \ln t}{(1-t^2)^2}dt\tag1 \end{align} where $ \int_0^1 \frac{\ln t}{(1+t)^2}dt=-\ln2$ . Integrate the 2nd integral by parts \begin{align} &\int_0^1 \frac{(\frac\pi4 - \tan^{-1} t) t \ln t}{(1-t^2)^2}dt\\ =&\int_0^1 (\frac\pi4 - \tan^{-1} t)\>d\left( \frac{(1-t^2) \ln(1-t^2) +2t^2\ln t}{4(1-t^2)}\right)\\ =& \ \frac14 \int_0^1 \frac{\ln t}{1-t^2}dt +\frac14 \int_0^1 \frac{\ln(1-t^2)-\ln t}{1+t^2}dt \end{align} where $\int_0^1 \frac{\ln t}{1-t^2}dt =-\frac{\pi^2}8$ $$K=\int_0^1 \frac{\ln(1-t^2)-\ln t}{1+t^2}dt \overset{t\to\frac{1-t}{1+t}}= \int_0^1 \frac{2\ln2}{1+t^2}dt -K\\ =\int_0^1 \frac{\ln2}{1+t^2}dt =\frac\pi4\ln2 $$ Substitute above results into (1) to obtain $$I= {\pi^2}+2\pi\ln2$$
</think>

\begin{align}J&=\int_0^1\int_0^1\int_0^1\frac{\ln x\ln y\ln y}{1-xyz}dxdydz\\ &\overset{u(x)=xyz}=\int_0^1\int_0^1\frac{\ln y\ln z}{yz}\left(\int_0^{yz}\frac{\ln u-\ln(yz)}{1-u}du\!\right)\!dydz\\ &=\underbrace{\int_0^1\!\!\int_0^1\frac{\ln y\ln z}{yz}\left(\int_0^{yz}\frac{\ln u}{1-u}du\right)dydz}_{=J_1}-\\&\!\!\int_0^1\!\!\int_0^1\frac{\ln y\ln z\ln(yz)}{yz}\left(\int_0^{yz}\frac{1}{1-u}du\right)dydz\\ &=J_1-2\underbrace{\int_0^1\int_0^1\frac{\ln y\ln^2 z}{yz}\left(\int_0^{yz}\frac{1}{1-u}du\right)dydz}_{=J_2}\\ J_1&\overset{v(y)=yz}=\int_0^1\frac{\ln z}z\left(\int_0^z\frac{\ln v-\ln z}{v}\left(\int_0^v\frac{\ln u}{1-u}du\right)dv\right)dz\\ &=\int_0^1\frac{\ln z}z\left(\int_0^z\frac{\ln v}{v}\left(\int_0^v\frac{\ln u}{1-u}du\right)dv\right)dz-\!\!\int_0^1\frac{\ln^2 z}z\left(\int_0^z\frac{1}{v}\left(\int_0^v\frac{\ln u}{1-u}du\right)dv\right)dz\\ &\overset{\text{IBP}}=-\frac{1}{2}\int_0^1\frac{\ln^3 z}{z}\left(\int_0^z\frac{\ln u}{1-u}du\right)dz+\frac{1}{3}\int_0^1\frac{\ln^3 z}{z}\left(\int_0^z\frac{\ln u}{1-u}du\right)dz\\ &=-\frac{1}{6}\int_0^1\frac{\ln^3 z}{z}\left(\int_0^z\frac{\ln u}{1-u}du\right)dz\overset{\text{IBP}}=\frac{1}{24}\int_0^1\frac{\ln^5z}{1-z}dz=\boxed{-5\zeta(6)}\\ J_2&\overset{v(y)=yz}=\int_0^1\frac{\ln^2 z}{z}\left(\int_0^z\frac{\ln v-\ln z}{v}\left(\int_0^v\frac{1}{1-u}du\right)dv\right)dz\\ &=\int_0^1\frac{\ln^2 z}{z}\left(\int_0^z\frac{\ln v}{v}\left(\int_0^v\frac{1}{1-u}du\right)dv\right)dz-\!\!\int_0^1\frac{\ln^3 z}{z}\left(\int_0^z\frac{1}{v}\left(\int_0^v\frac{1}{1-u}du\right)dv\right)dz\\ &\overset{\text{IBP}}=-\frac{1}{3}\int_0^1\frac{\ln^4z}{z}\left(\int_0^z\frac{1}{1-u}du\right)dz+\frac{1}{4}\int_0^1\frac{\ln^4z}{z}\left(\int_0^z\frac{1}{1-u}du\right)dz\\ &=-\frac{1}{12}\int_0^1\frac{\ln^4z}{z}\left(\int_0^z\frac{1}{1-u}du\right)dz\overset{\text{IBP}}=\frac{1}{60}\int_0^1\frac{\ln^5z}{1-z}dz=\boxed{-2\zeta(6)}\\ &\boxed{J=-\zeta(6)=-\frac{\pi^6}{945}} \end{align} NB: I assume that, \begin{align}\int_0^1\frac{\ln^5x}{1-x}dx&=-120\zeta(6)\\ \zeta(6)&=\frac{\pi^6}{945} \end{align}

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{\cos(2x)(1-\log\cos(x))}{x^2 +(1-\log \cos(x))^2}dx$

<think>
Let $b=1-\ln \cos x$ and utilize $\int_0^\infty \cos xt \ e^{-b t}dt=\frac b{x^2+b^2}$ to reexpress the integral as \begin{align} \Omega =&\int^{\pi/2}_{0} \frac{\cos2x\ (1-\ln\cos x)}{x^2 + (1-\ln \cos x)^2}dx \\ =& \int^{\pi/2}_0\int_0^\infty\cos2x \cos tx\ \cos^tx\ e^{-t}dt \ dx \\ =& \int_0^\infty \frac{e^{-t} }2\int^{\pi/2}_0 [\cos(t+2)x+ \cos(t-2)x] \cos^tx \ dx \ dt \\ \end{align} Evaluate the two inner integrals with $n=\pm 2$ as follows \begin{align} &\int^{\pi/2}_0 \cos[(t+n)x]\cos^tx \ dx \\ =&\ \Re \int^{\pi/2}_0 e^{i(t+n)t}\left(\frac{e^{i x}+e^{-i x}}2 \right)^t \ dx\\ =&\ \Re\int^{\pi/2}_0 \frac1{2^{t}}\sum_{k=0}^\infty \binom tk e^{i(2k+n)x}\ dx=\frac{\pi t}{2^{t+1}} \end{align} which is for $n=-2$ and the integral with $n=2$ vanishes. Thus $$\Omega= \frac\pi4\int_0^\infty \frac{e^{-t}t}{2^{t}}\ dt =\frac\pi{4(1+\ln2)^2} $$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\frac{\log(1+\tan(y))}{(2+\tan(y))\sqrt{1+\tan(y)}}\, \sec^2ydy$

<think>
Continue with $z=1+\tan y$ . $$I = \int_0^\tfrac\pi2 \frac{\log(1+\tan y)}{(2+\tan y) \sqrt{1+\tan y}} \, \sec^2y\,dy = \int_1^\infty \frac{\log z}{\sqrt z(1+z)} \, dz$$ Upon replacing $z\mapsto\dfrac1{z^2}$ , we can use Taylor series and integration by parts to finish the job. $$I = -4 \int_0^1 \frac{\log z}{1+z^2} \, dz = -4 \sum_{n\ge0} (-1)^n \int_0^1 z^{2n} \log z \, dz = 4 \sum_{n\ge0} \frac{(-1)^n}{(2n+1)^2} = 4G$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{1}^{2}\frac{\log(2-y)\log^ny}{y}\, dy$

<think>
Change of variable: $$y=1+x$$ $$I(n)=\int_1^2 \frac{\ln(2-y)\ln^ny}{y} \, dy$$ Now consider $$I(a)=\int_1^2y^a\ln(2-y)\, dy$$ We get back to the original integral by differentiating $I(a)$ with respect to $a$ $n$ times and then taking $a=-1$ Using expansion $$\ln\left (1-\frac{y}{2} \right )=-\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{y^k}{k2^k}$$ we get after a simple integration: $$I(a)=\ln 2\frac{2^{a+1}-1}{a+1}+\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k2^k(k+a+1)}-\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{2^{k+a+1}}{k2^k(k+a+1)}$$ Now, by differentiating $I(a)$ with respect to $a$ $n$ times and then taking $a=-1$ we reach the desired result: $$I(n)=\frac{(\ln 2)^{n+2}}{n+1}+(-1)^nn!\left [\text{Li}_{n+2} \left ( \frac{1}{2} \right ) -\zeta(n+2)-\sum_{i=1}^{n}(-1)^{i}\frac{(\ln 2)^{i}}{i!}\zeta(n+2-i)\right ]$$ An addition An alternative form that does not use the polylogarithm and zeta function: $$I(n)=\frac{(\ln 2)^{n+2}}{n+1}-(-1)^nn!\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1- \frac{1}{2^k}+f(k,n)}{k^{n+2}}$$ where $$f(k,n)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(-1)^{i}\frac{(k\ln 2)^{i}}{i!}$$ The previous result follows directly from this last form
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{t^2\log(t)}{\left(1+\frac{t^4}{2}\right)^{5/4}}dt$

I'll start by saying that the solution isn't graphically nice to look at, but on the other hand the integral is quite complicated anyway , anyway respect the fact that you asked for a closed form of the integral (incidentally, even without the presence of the logarithm it would have been necessary to use hypergeometric functions). Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}0 dx$

we have: $$\sum_{i=0}^{n}x^i=\frac{1-x^{n+1}}{1-x}$$ \begin{align*} I&=\lim_{n\to \infty} \int_{0}^{1} \frac{\log\bigl( \sum_{i=0}^n x^i \bigr)}{x^2 + 1}dx \\ &=-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\log\bigl( 1-x \bigr)}{x^2 + 1}dx+\lim_{n\to \infty}\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\log\bigl( 1-x^{n+1}\bigr)}{x^2 + 1}dx \end{align*} Let: $f_n(x)=\frac{\log\bigl( 1-x^{n+1}\bigr)}{x^2 + 1}$ We have : $\forall x\in [0,1[ $ $\lim_{n\to \infty}f_n(x)=0$ and $|f_n(x)|<\frac{1}{1+x^2}$ integrable Using Dominated convergence theorem $$\lim_{n\to \infty}\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\log\bigl( 1-x^{n+1}\bigr)}{x^2 + 1}dx =\int_{0}^{1} 0 dx=0$$ Therfore: $$I=-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\log\bigl( 1-x \bigr)}{x^2 + 1}dx= \operatorname{Im}\left( \operatorname{Li}_2\left( \frac{1+i}{2} \right) \right) $$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\log(2)}\frac{\log(2 e^{-y}-1)}{2y}dy\,$

<think>
You ask for an expression (in terms of a sum) for the integral $$I= -\frac{1}{4}\int_0^1\frac{\ln(x)}{\bigl(\frac{x+1}{2}\bigl)\ln\bigl(\frac{x+1}{2}\bigl)}dx\,. $$ Let us perform the substitution $$ x = 2 e^{-y} - 1\,.$$ The integral then can be rewritten as $$ I = \int_0^{\ln 2} \frac{ \ln (2 e^{-y} -1) }{2y} \,dy\,.$$ Next, we use the Taylor expansion $\Bigl(\ln (1-x) = -\sum_{k=1}^\infty x^k/k\Bigr)$ $$ \ln (2 e^{-y} -1) = \ln e^{-y} - \ln (1-\tfrac12 ) + \ln\left(1- \tfrac12 e^{y}\right) = - y - \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{e^{k y} -1}{2^{k} k} = -y -\sum_{k,n=1}^\infty \frac{k^{n-1}}{2^{k} n!} y^n \,.$$ Using the elementary integrals $\int_0^{\ln2}\!y^{n-1}\,dy = (\ln 2)^n/n $ , we arrive at the result $$I = -\frac{\ln 2}{2} - \sum_{k,n=1}^\infty \frac{k^{n-1} (\ln 2)^n}{2^{k+1} n\, n!} \,.$$

Too long for a comment Using the Frullani' integral $\,\,\displaystyle \ln (t)=-\int_0^\infty\frac{e^{-xt}-e^{-x}}xdx\,\,$ and changing the order of integration $$\int_0^\infty \ln (t) \,t^{-\frac12} e^{-t} dt=-\int_0^\infty\frac{dx}x\int_0^\infty\left(e^{-(x+1)t}-e^{-t}e^{-x}\right)t^{-\frac12}dt$$ $$=-\int_0^\infty\frac{dx}x\left(\frac1{\sqrt{1+x}}-e^{-x}\right)\int_0^\infty t^{-\frac12}e^{-t}dt=\sqrt\pi\int_0^\infty\left(e^{-x}-\frac1{\sqrt{1+x}}\right)\frac{dx}x$$ Integrating by parts, we have $$=\sqrt\pi\ln x\left(e^{-x}-\frac1{\sqrt{1+x}}\right)\,\bigg|_{x=0}^\infty-\sqrt\pi\int_0^\infty\left(\frac{\ln x}{2(1+x)^{\frac32}}-e^{-x}\ln x\right)dx$$ $$=-\sqrt\pi\,\gamma-\frac{\sqrt\pi}2\int_0^\infty\frac{\ln x}{(1+x)^{\frac32}}dx\overset{t=\frac1{\sqrt{1+x}}}{=}-\sqrt\pi\,\gamma-\sqrt\pi\int_0^1\ln \frac{1-t^2}{t^2}dt$$ $$=-\sqrt\pi\,\gamma+2\sqrt\pi\int_0^1\ln (t)\,dt-\sqrt\pi\int_0^1\ln(1-t)dt-\sqrt\pi\int_0^1\ln(1+t)dt$$ $$I=-\sqrt\pi\big(\gamma+2\ln2\big).$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{(2k+1)\frac{\pi}{2}}^{+\infty}\frac{dx}{2\cosh(x)}$

<think>
We have $$ \frac{\pi}{2}-\arctan\left(\exp\left((2k+1)\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)=\int_{(2k+1)\frac{\pi}{2}}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{2\cosh x}\tag{1} $$ so $$ S=\sum_{k\geq 0}(-1)^k\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\arctan\left(\exp\left((2k+1)\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)\right)=\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathbb{1}_A(x)}{\cosh(x)}\mathrm{d}x=\frac{1}{4}\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathbb{1}_B(x)}{\cosh(x)}\mathrm{d}x \tag{2} $$ where $A=\left[\frac{\pi}{2},\frac{3\pi}{2}\right]\cup \left[\frac{5\pi}{2},\frac{7\pi}{2}\right]\cup\ldots$ and $B=A\cup(-A)$ . By considering the Laplace transform of $\mathbb{1}_A$ and the inverse Laplace transform of $\frac{1}{2\cosh x}$ we recover (since $\text{sech}$ is almost a fixed point of the Fourier transform) $$ S=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{k\geq 0}\frac{(-1)^k}{(2k+1)\cosh\left(\frac{\pi}{2}(2k+1)\right)}=\frac{1}{2\pi}\sum_{k\geq 0}\frac{(-1)^k}{2k+1}\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\frac{\cos((2k+1)t)}{\cosh t}\mathrm{d}t\tag{3} $$ which equals $$ S=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\cosh(t)}\sum_{k\geq 0}\frac{(-1)^k}{2k+1}\cos((2k+1)t)=\frac{1}{4}\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{R}\setminus A}(x)-\mathbb{1}_A(x)}{\cosh(x)}\,\mathrm{d}x.\tag{4}$$ By $(4)$ and $(2)$ $$ 2S+S = \frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{R}\setminus A}(x)}{\cosh(x)}\mathrm{d}x,\quad 4S=\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\cosh(x)}=\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{e^{x}+e^{-x}}=\int_{1}^{+\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}z}{z^2+1}=\frac{\pi}{2}\tag{5}$$ hence, finally, $\boxed{S=\frac{\pi}{8}}$ . This is a bit different from the mentioned approaches: the LHS of $(3)$ is directly recovered from the self-adjointness of the Laplace transform and the LHS of $(4)$ follows from the Fourier transform of $\frac{1}{\cosh}$ . A rectangular wave appears in the RHS of $(4)$ and this leads to a symmetry, which is not apparent in $(2)$ . In any case $\arctan\left(\exp\left((2k+1)\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)$ converges to $\frac{\pi}{2}$ , so in order to assign a finite value to $\sum_{k\geq 0}(-1)^k \arctan\left(\exp\left((2k+1)\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)$ you have to use some kind of regularization.
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\log(1+y)}{y+1}d y$

<think>
Letting $y=\sqrt x$ transforms the integral without radical \begin{aligned} I & =\int_0^1 \frac{\ln \left(1-y^4\right)}{y(y+1)} 2 y d y \\ & =2 \int_0^1 \frac{\ln (1+y)+\ln (1-y)+\ln \left(1+y^2\right)}{y+1} d y \end{aligned} $$ \int_0^1 \frac{\ln (1+y)}{y+1} d y=\left[\frac{\ln ^2(1+y)}{2}\right]_0^1=\frac{\ln ^2 2}{2} $$ By the post , we have $$ \int_0^1 \frac{\ln (1-y)}{y+1} d y=\frac{1}{2} \ln ^2 2-\frac{\pi^2}{12} $$ By the post , we have $$\displaystyle \int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln(1+y^{2})}{y+1}dx=\frac{3}{4}\ln^{2}(2)-\frac{{\pi}^{2}}{48}$$ Hence $$I =\int_0^1 \frac{\ln \left(1-y^4\right)}{y(y+1)} 2 y d y = \ln ^2 2+\ln ^2 2-\frac{\pi^2}{6} +\frac{3}{2}\ln^{2}(2)-\frac{{\pi}^{2}}{24}=\frac 72 \ln^2 2-\frac {5 }{4}\zeta(2) \\ $$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}{\frac{{\sin{x^2}}}{{\pi -{x^2}}}dx}$

<think>
Note that \begin{align} I=&\int_0^\infty {\frac{{\sin {x^2}}}{{\pi - {x^2}}}dx} \\ =&\ \frac{1}{{2\sqrt \pi }}\int_{-\infty}^\infty {\frac{{\sin \pi {x^2}}}{{1 - {x^2}}}dx} =\frac{1}{4{\sqrt \pi }}\int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{\sin \pi {x^2} }{\underset{1-x\to x}{1 - x}} +\frac {\sin \pi {x^2} }{\underset{1+x\to x}{1 +x}}\ dx\\ =& \ \frac{1}{{2\sqrt \pi }}\int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{\sin \pi {(1-x)^2} }x dx = \frac{1}{{2\sqrt \pi }}\int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{\sin [\pi x(2-x) ]}x dx \end{align} Let $K(a) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{\sin[a^2x(2-x)]}x dx$ \begin{align} K’(a) =& \ 2a\int_{-\infty}^\infty \cos [a^2-a^2(1-x)^2 ](2-x)\ \overset{1-x\to x}{dx}\\ = & \ 2a\int_{-\infty}^\infty \cos [a^2(1-x^2)]{dx}\\ = & \ 2a \int_{-\infty}^\infty [\cos (ax)^2 \cos a^2 + \sin (ax)^2 \sin a^2 ] dx \\ = &\ \sqrt{2\pi}\left({\cos a^2} + {\sin a^2} \right) \end{align} Then \begin{align} I= &\ \frac1{2\sqrt\pi} K(\sqrt{\pi})= \frac1{2\sqrt\pi}\int_0^{\sqrt{\pi}}K’(a)da\\ =&\ \frac{1}{\sqrt2}\int_0^{\sqrt{\pi }}\left({\cos a^2} + {\sin a^2}\right)da =\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}2\left[C(\sqrt{2})+S(\sqrt{2})\right] \end{align}
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\log(1-x)}{1+x^2}dx$

<think>
Following Cornel's method in this solution ( check the integral $\mathcal{J})$ $$I=\int_0^1\frac{\ln(1-x)}{1+x^2}\ dx =\Im\int_0^1\frac{i\ln(1-x)}{1-ix}\ dx\overset{1-x=t}{=}\Im\int_0^1\frac{i\ln(t)}{1-i+it}\ dt$$ $$=\Im\text{Li}_2\left(\frac{i}{i-1}\right)=\Im\left(-\text{Li}_2(i)-\frac12\ln^2(1-i)\right)=\frac{\pi}8\ln(2)-G$$ where in the last step, I used landen's identity.

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\arcsin^2(ax)}{x}\, dx$

<think>
$$I=\int \frac{\arcsin^2(ax)}{x}\, dx$$ $$x=\frac{\sin (t)}{a} \quad \implies \quad I=\int t^2\, \cot (t)\,dt$$ A few integrations by parts $$I=i t \text{Li}_2\left(e^{-2 i t}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \text{Li}_3\left(e^{-2 i t}\right)+\frac{i t^3}{3}+t^2 \log \left(1-e^{-2 i t}\right)-\frac{i \pi ^3}{24}$$ Back to $x$ and the bounds and a few simplifications $$J(a)=\int_0^1 \frac{\arcsin^2(ax)}{x}\, dx$$ $$\color{blue}{J(a)=\small\frac{1}{2} \text{Li}_3\left(-2 a^2-2 i \sqrt{1-a} \sqrt{a+1} a+1\right)+i \text{Li}_2\left(-2 a^2-2 i \sqrt{1-a} \sqrt{a+1} a+1\right) \sin ^{-1}(a)+}$$ $$\color{blue}{\small\log \left(2 a^2+2 i \sqrt{1-a} \sqrt{a+1} a\right) \sin ^{-1}(a)^2+\frac{1}{3} i \sin ^{-1}(a)^3-\frac{\zeta (3)}{2}}$$ Beside $J(1)$ already given by @Alexander Shin, a nice one is $$ J\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)=\frac{\pi }{4}\,C-\frac{35 }{64}\zeta (3)+\frac{\pi ^2}{32} \log (2)$$ Notice that a good approximation is given by the series $$\frac{a^2}{2}+\frac{a^4}{12}+\frac{4 a^6}{135}+\frac{a^8}{70}+\frac{64 a^{10}}{7875}+\frac{32 a^{12}}{6237} +\frac{512 a^{14}}{147147}+O\left(a^{16}\right)$$ which could have been obtained by the series expansion of the integrand around $x=0$ . Using this truncated series, the absolute error for $ J\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)$ is $1.56\times 10^{-5}$ .
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\arcsin^2(ax)}{x}dx$

<think>
Let $$I(a)=\int\limits_{0}^{1}\frac{\arcsin^2(ax)}{x}\,dx, \quad |a|\le 1$$ So \begin{align*} I'(a)&=\int\limits_0^1 \frac{2\,\arcsin(ax)}{x}\cdot\frac{x}{\sqrt{1-a^2x^2}}\,dx=2\int\limits_0^1 \frac{\arcsin(ax)}{\sqrt{1-a^2x^2}}\,dx\\ &\overset{t=ax}{=}\frac{2}{a}\int\limits_0^{a}\frac{\arcsin t}{\sqrt{1-t^2}}\,dt\overset{t=\sin u}{=}\frac{\alpha^2}{a},\quad \alpha=\arcsin a \end{align*} Then \begin{align*} I(a)&=\int\limits_0^{a}\frac{\arcsin^2 t}{t}\,dt=\int\limits_0^{\alpha} \theta^2\cot\theta\,d\theta\\ &=\left( \theta^2\ln(\sin\theta) \right)\Bigg|_0^{\alpha}-2\int\limits_0^{\alpha}\theta\ln(\sin\theta)\,d\theta\\ &=\alpha^2\ln(\sin\alpha)-2\int\limits_0^{\alpha}\theta\ln(\sin\theta)\,d\theta \end{align*} $$\ln\left( 2\sin\theta \right)=-\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{\cos(2n\theta)}{n}\Rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_2(\phi)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{\sin(n\phi)}{n^2},\ \ C_3(\phi)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{\cos(n\phi)}{n^3}$$ Answer \begin{align*} I(a)&=\alpha^2\ln\bigl(2\sin\alpha\bigr)+\alpha\,\mathrm{Cl}_2(2\alpha)+\frac12\,C_3(2\alpha)-\frac12\,\zeta(3),\quad \alpha=\arcsin|a|\in\left[ 0,\frac{\pi}{2} \right]\\ &=\alpha^2\ln(2\sin\alpha)+\alpha\,\Im\operatorname{Li}_2\left( e^{2i\alpha} \right)+\frac12\,\Re\!\operatorname{Li}_3\left( e^{2i\alpha} \right)-\frac12\,\zeta(3) \end{align*} Testing on specific cases $$a=0\Rightarrow \alpha=0\Rightarrow I(0)=0,\, a=1\Rightarrow \alpha=\frac{\pi}{2}\Rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_2(\pi)=0$$ $$C_3(\pi)=\sum_{n\ge1}\frac{(-1)^n}{n^3}=-\frac{3}{4}\zeta(3)$$ $$I(1)=\int\limits_0^1\frac{\arcsin^2 x}{x}\,dx=\frac{\pi^2}{4}\ln 2-\frac{7}{8}\,\zeta(3)$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\log \left(\frac{2 + \sin(x)}{2 - \sin(x)}\right)\, dx \,$

<think>
Ramanujan found that $$\int_{0}^{\pi/2} \ln \left( \frac{2 + \sin x}{2 - \sin x} \right) \, dx \, = \, \color{blue}{\displaystyle\sum_{n=0}^\infty \displaystyle\frac{1}{\displaystyle\binom{2n}{n}\left(2n+1\right)^2}} \, = \,\boxed{\displaystyle\frac{8C-\pi\ln\left(2+\sqrt{3}\right)}{3}}$$ where $C$ is Catalan's constant . The first few terms are: $$\int_{0}^{\pi/2} \ln \left( \frac{2 + \sin x}{2 - \sin x} \right) \, dx \, = \, 1 + \frac{1}{18}+\frac{1}{150}+\frac{1}{980} + \cdots$$ The denominators are listed in OEIS sequence A294486 . This series can also be expressed as the value of a hypergeometric function : $$_3F_2\left(1,1, \frac{1}{2}\, ;\,\,\frac{3}{2}, \frac{3}{2}\, ; \,\,\frac{1}{4}\right)$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{e^{-\sqrt{\pi}x}-e^{-x}}{x}dx$

<think>
There is a beautiful trick here. $f(x)=x\cosh(x)$ clearly is a smooth increasing function over $\mathbb{R}^+$ , such that its inverse function $h(x)$ is also smooth and increasing. From $g(f(x))=x$ we have $f'(x) g'(f(x))=1$ and $f'(x)=\frac{1}{g'(f(x))}$ , as well as $$ f'(g(x)) = \frac{1}{g'(x)}.\tag{1} $$ Even if $g(x)$ does not have a nice closed-form expression, we are allowed to use it in a change of variable. For instance $$ \int \frac{f'(t)}{f(t)} e^{-f(t)}\,dt \stackrel{t\mapsto g(x)}{=} \int\frac{f'(g(x))g'(x)}{f(g(x))}e^{-f(g(x))}\,dx = \int \frac{e^{-x}}{x}\,dx.\tag{2}$$ This readily gives that your integral equals $$ \int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{e^{-\sqrt{\pi}x}-e^{-x}}{x}\,dx = -\log\sqrt{\pi} = -\frac{1}{2}\ln\pi\tag{3} $$ by Frullani's theorem. $f(x)=h(x)=x+O(x^3)$ , so when considering $\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0^+}\int_{\varepsilon}^{+\infty}$ the singular parts of $\int_{0}^{+\infty}e^{-x}\frac{dx}{x}$ and $\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{f'(t)}{f(t)}e^{-f(t)}\,dt$ cancel out.
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi/ 2}\arctan(\tan(2a)\cos(x))dx$

<think>
Note that \begin{align}\int_{0}^{\pi/ 2} &\tan^{-1} (\tan 2a \cos x) dx =\int_0^{\pi/2}\int_0^a \frac{2\cos x}{1-\sin^2 2y \cos^2x}dy \ dx\\ =& \int_0^a \frac{2\tanh^{-1}(\sin 2y)}{\sin 2y} {dy} \overset{t=\tan y} = \int_0^{\tan a}\frac{1}{t}\tanh^{-1}\frac{2t}{1+t^2}\ dt\\ =&\int_0^{\tan a}\frac{\ln(1+t)-\ln(1-t)}{t}\ dt =\text{Li}_2(\tan a) -\text{Li}_2(-\tan a)\\ \end{align} Thus \begin{align} &\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \tan^{-1}\frac{2\cos x}{1 + 2\cos^2 x} \, dx\\ =& \underset{}{\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}}} \tan^{-1}[(\sqrt3+1)\cos x]- \tan^{-1} [(\sqrt3-1)\cos x]\ dx\\ = & \ \text{Li}_2(\tan a_+) -\text{Li}_2(-\tan a_+) - \text{Li}_2(\tan a_-)+ \text{Li}_2(-\tan a_-) \end{align} with $a_{\pm}=\frac12\tan^{-1}(\sqrt3\pm 1)$ .
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}}x \cos(2\pi nx)dx$

<think>
Writing $$\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}}x \log (\Gamma (x))\,dx=\int_{0}^{\frac12} x \frac{\log( 2\pi)}{2}\,dx+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{\frac12}x\frac{\cos (2\pi nx)}{2n}\,dx+$$ $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\int_{0}^{\frac12}x\frac{(\gamma+\log (2\pi n))\sin (2\pi nx)}{n\pi}\,dx$$ Using integration by parts $$\int_{0}^{\frac12}x \cos (2\pi nx)\,dx=\frac{(-1)^n-1}{4 \pi ^2 n^2}$$ $$\int_{0}^{\frac12}x \sin (2\pi nx)\,dx=\frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{4 \pi n}$$ Summing, the result is $$\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}}x \log (\Gamma (x))\,dx=\frac 1{96}\Big(2 \gamma +\log \left(64 \pi ^8\right)-\frac{3 \left(4 \zeta '(2)+7 \zeta (3)\right)}{\pi ^2} \Big)$$ But $$\zeta '(2)=\frac{2}{3} \pi ^2 (-12 \log (A)+\gamma+\log (2 \pi ))$$ Simplifying $$\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}}x \log (\Gamma (x))\,dx=\frac 1{96}\Big(\log \left(16 \pi ^6 A^{24}\right)-\frac{21 \zeta(3)}{\pi ^2} \Big)$$ All the trick was $\zeta '(2)$ Edit May be simpler would have been to use $$\log (\Gamma (x))=-\gamma (x-1)+\sum_{k=2}^\infty (-1)^k\, \frac{\zeta (k)}{k}\,(x-1)^k$$ which gives $$J=\int x \,\log (\Gamma (x))\,dx=-\frac{\gamma}{6} x^2 (2x-3)+\sum_{k=2}^\infty (-1)^k\, \frac{\zeta (k)}{k}\,\frac{(x-1)^{k+1} (k x+x+1)}{(k+1) (k+2)}$$ that is to say (if no mistake) $$J=\Big(\frac{\gamma }{6}+\frac 14\log \left(\frac{A^4}{2 \pi }\right)-\frac{\zeta (3)}{8 \pi ^2}-\frac{1}{2} \zeta ^{(1,0)}(-2,x) \Big)+\left(\zeta ^{(1,0)}(-1,x)+\frac{1}{24}\right)\,x+$$ $$\frac {\log \left(2 \pi \sqrt{e} \right)}4\, x^2-\frac 14 x^3$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}t^{\alpha - 1}e^{-a t}\, dt$

<think>
Applying the substitution $ t = x^2 - 1 $ , so $ x = \sqrt{t + 1} $ , $ dx = \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{t + 1}} \, dt $ . Limits: $ x = 1 \to t = 0 $ , $ x \to \infty \to t \to \infty $ . $$ \int_{1}^{\infty} \frac{(a (x^2 - 1))^m}{1 + x} \frac{e^{-a (x^2 - 1)}}{(1 + b (x^2 - 1))^n} \, dx = \frac{a^m}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{t^m e^{-a t}}{(1 + b t)^n \sqrt{t + 1} (1 + \sqrt{t + 1})} \, dt $$ Using the series form for the denominator, define $ f(t) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{t + 1} (1 + \sqrt{t + 1})} = \frac{\sqrt{t + 1} - 1}{t \sqrt{t + 1}} $ . $$ \sqrt{t + 1} - 1 = \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \binom{1/2}{j} t^j, \quad f(t) = \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \binom{1/2}{j} t^{j-1} $$ Applying the binomial expansion: $$ (1 + b t)^{-n} = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k \binom{n + k - 1}{k} (b t)^k $$ $$ I = \frac{a^m}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} t^m e^{-a t} \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \binom{1/2}{j} t^{j-1} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k \binom{n + k - 1}{k} b^k t^k \, dt $$ Interchanging the sum and integral: $$ I = \frac{a^m}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \binom{1/2}{j} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k \binom{n + k - 1}{k} b^k \int_{0}^{\infty} t^{m + j - 1 + k} e^{-a t} \, dt $$ Using the gamma function: $$ \int_{0}^{\infty} t^{\alpha - 1} e^{-a t} \, dt = \Gamma(\alpha) a^{-\alpha}, \quad \alpha = m + j + k $$ $$ I = \frac{a^m}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \binom{1/2}{j} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k \binom{n + k - 1}{k} b^k \Gamma(m + j + k) a^{-(m + j + k)} $$ $$ = \boxed{\frac{1}{2 a^m} \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \binom{1/2}{j} a^{-j} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k \binom{n + k - 1}{k} \Gamma(m + j + k) \left( \frac{b}{a} \right)^k} $$
</think>

messages.content: You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x}{e^{\pi x}-1}\, x^{s-1}\, dx$

<think>
As you noted the sum $$S=\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{n(-1)^{n+1}}{(-1)^n+e^{\pi n}}=\frac{1}{24}\tag{1}$$ can be written as $$S=\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} f(2n-1)+\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} g(2n)\tag{2}$$ where $$f(x)=\frac{x}{e^{\pi x}-1}\tag{3}$$ and $$g(x)=-\frac{x}{e^{\pi x}+1}\tag{4}$$ with Mellin transforms $$F(s)=\mathcal{M}_x\left[f(x)\right](s)=\int\limits_0^{\infty} \frac{x}{e^{\pi x}-1}\, x^{s-1} \, dx=\pi^{-s-1}\, \Gamma(s+1)\, \zeta(s+1)\tag{5}$$ and $$G(s)=\mathcal{M}_x\left[g(x)\right](s)=\int\limits_0^{\infty } -\frac{x}{e^{\pi x}+1} x^{s-1} \, dx=\left(2^{-s}-1\right) \pi^{-s-1}\, \Gamma(s+1)\, \zeta(s+1)\tag{6}.$$ The inverse Mellin Transforms $$f(x)=\mathcal{M}_s^{-1}[F(s)](x)=\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int\limits_C F(s)\, x^{-s} ds\tag{7}$$ and $$g(x)=\mathcal{M}_s^{-1}[G(s)](x)=\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int\limits_C G(s)\, x^{-s}\, ds\tag{8}$$ lead to $$S=\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int\limits_C \left(F(s)\, \sum\limits_{n=1}^\infty (2n-1)^{-s}+G(s)\, \sum\limits_{n=1}^\infty (2n)^{-s}\right)\, ds$$ $$=\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int\limits_C 4^{-s}\, \left(2^s-1\right)^2\, \pi^{-s-1}\, \Gamma(s+1)\, \zeta(s+1)\, \zeta(s)\, ds\tag{9}$$ where the integrand $4^{-s}\, \left(2^s-1\right)^2\, \pi^{-s-1}\, \Gamma(s+1)\, \zeta(s+1)\, \zeta(s)$ has a pole with a corresponding residue of $\frac{1}{24}$ at $s=\pm 1$ , and I'm assuming the residue at $s=−1$ must be discarded for reasons similar to this answer to your related question.
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x^4-2x^2+2}\, dx$

<think>
Too long for a comment. As you wrote $$I=\int^{\infty}_{1}\frac{1}{x^4-2x^2+2}\, dx=\frac i 2 \int^{\infty}_{1}\Bigg(\frac{1}{x^2-(1-i)}-\frac{1}{x^2-(1+i)} \Bigg) \,dx$$ Then $$I=\frac{i}{2} \left(\frac{\tanh ^{-1}\left(\sqrt{1-i}\right)}{\sqrt{1-i}}-\frac{\tanh ^{-1}\left(\sqrt{1+i}\right)}{\sqrt{1+i}}\right)$$ or $$I=\frac 14 \left( (1+i)^{3/2} \tanh ^{-1}\left(\sqrt{1+i}\right)-(1-i)^{3/2} \tanh ^{-1}\left(\sqrt{1-i}\right) \right)$$ seem to be the simplest forms of $I$ . Everything becomes very complicated if you try to expand $\sqrt{1\pm i}$ in terms of $\sin \left(\frac{\pi }{8}\right)$ and $\cos \left(\frac{\pi }{8}\right)$ . Inverse symbolic calculators do not find anything looking like $0.5301166461353718584494007$ Edit Many thanks to @Mariusz Iwaniuk who gave the exact result $$I=\frac{1}{4} \sqrt{1+\sqrt{2}} \left(\pi -\tan ^{-1}\left(\sqrt{2\left(1+\sqrt{2}\right)}\right)\right)+$$ $$\frac{1}{8 \sqrt{1+\sqrt{2}}}\log \left(\frac{1+\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{2 \left(1+\sqrt{2}\right)}}{1+\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{2 \left(1+\sqrt{2}\right)}}\right)$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{1}^{\infty}t^{2-6 n}\log ^2(t)\log \left(t^2-1\right)dt$

<think>
A lazy solution Using $$\frac 1{1+t^6}=\sum_{n=0}^\infty (-1)^n\, t^{-6 (n+1)}$$ $$\int \frac{t^2 \log ^2(t) \log \left(t^2-1\right)}{t^{6 n}+1}\,dt=\sum_{n=0}^\infty (-1)^n\,\int t^{2-6 n} \log ^2(t) \log \left(t^2-1\right)\,dt$$ $$I_n=\int t^{2-6 n} \log ^2(t) \log \left(t^2-1\right)\,dt$$ is given in terms of the Gaussian hypergeometric function. Using the bounds $$J_n=\int_1^\infty t^{2-6 n} \log ^2(t) \log \left(t^2-1\right)\,dt$$ $$J_n=-\frac{9 (1-2 n)^2 \psi ^{(2)}\left(3 n-\frac{3}{2}\right)+8 \psi ^{(0)}\left(3 n-\frac{3}{2}\right)+12(1-2 n) \psi ^{(1)}\left(3 n-\frac{3}{2}\right)+8 \gamma }{108 (2 n-1)^3}$$ The summation converges slowly to $0.1277413$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{-1}^{1}\frac{1}{{x}}\sqrt{\frac{1+x}{1-x}}\log\left(\frac{1+2rsx+(r^2+s^2-1)x^2}{1-2rsx+(r^2+s^2-1)x^2}\right)dx$

<think>
We use the below lemma which was proved in this answer for the related integral you found: Proposition: If $0<r<1$ and $r<s$ then $$I(r,s) := \int_{-1}^1 \frac1{x}\sqrt{\frac{1+x}{1-x}}\log\left(\frac{1+2rsx+(r^2+s^2-1)x^2}{1-2rsx+(r^2+s^2-1)x^2}\right) dx = 4\pi\arcsin r.$$ Let $p(x)=x^4+\sqrt{2}x^3+x^2+\sqrt{2}x+1.$ As its coefficients are palindromic, we consider a factorisation of the form $p(x)=(x^2+a_1x+1)(x^2+a_2x+1)$ . By expanding and comparing coefficients we get the equations $$a_1+a_2=\sqrt{2}\ \text{ and }\ a_1a_2=-1$$ which are quickly solved to get $$a_{1,2}=\frac{1\pm\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{2}}=2\sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{12}\right),-2\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{12}\right).$$ $f(x)$ is then given by $$f(x)=\log\left(\frac{p(x)}{p(-x)}\right)=\log\left(\frac{x^2+a_1x+1}{x^2-a_1x+1}\right)-\log\left(\frac{x^2-a_2x+1}{x^2+a_2x+1}\right)=f(\theta_1)-f(\theta_2)$$ for $\theta_1=\frac{5\pi}{12}$ and $\theta_2=\frac{\pi}{12}$ , where $$f(\theta)=\log\left(\frac{x^2+2x\sin\theta+1}{x^2-2x\sin\theta+1}\right).$$ Both parts are of the form required for the proposition, so we must solve the simultaneous equations $$2r_ns_n=|a_n|=2\sin\theta_n\ \text{ and }\ r_n^2+s_n^2-1=1$$ for $n=1,2$ under the constraints $0<r<1, r<s$ . These are again quickly solved to get $$\{r_n,s_n\}=\left\{\sqrt{2}\sin\frac{\theta_n}{2}, \sqrt{2}\cos\frac{\theta_n}{2}\right\},$$ and since both $\theta_n$ are in the range $\left(0,\frac{\pi}{2}\right)$ where $\cos\frac{\theta}{2}>\sin\frac{\theta}{2}$ we get $$r_n=\sqrt{2}\sin\frac{\theta_n}{2}\ \text{ and }\ s_n=\sqrt{2}\cos\frac{\theta_n}{2}.$$ Thus using the proposition, the integral is given by $$I = 4\pi\left(\arcsin\left(\sqrt{2}\sin\frac{5\pi}{24}\right)-\arcsin\left(\sqrt{2}\sin\frac{\pi}{24}\right)\right).$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt{1+4x}-1}{2xe^x}dx$

<think>
Well, strictly speaking, solving for the closed form of the continued fraction isn't that hard. The closed form is given by $$\frac1{1+\overset{\infty}{\underset{n=1}{\large{\text{K}}}} \frac x1} = \frac1{1+\frac{2x}{\sqrt{4x+1}+1}} = \frac{\sqrt{4x+1}-1}{2x}$$ This can be found by solving for $y$ in the equation $y = \frac xy - 1$ and choosing to take the positive version by inspection (if anyone has a better method, please tell lol) So, the integral just collapses into finding $$\int_0^\infty \frac{\sqrt{1+4x}-1}{2xe^x}\text{ d}x$$ Here, both Rubi and Mathematica cannot give the antiderivative, and I've not tinkered around with it much to be able to solve it analytically for now. Regardless, the definite integral is given by Mathematica to be $$\frac1{12}{}_2F_2\left(1, 1; 2, \frac52; \frac14\right) - \frac\pi2\operatorname{erfi}\left(\frac12\right) - 1 + \frac\gamma2 + e^{\frac14} \pi^{\frac12} \approx 0.68623$$ which matches the result you give.
</think>

messages.content: You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}t^{m+n-1}\, dt$

<think>
I found an answer $$s = \sum _{n=1}^{\infty } \sum _{m=1}^{\infty } \frac{1}{m n (m+n)} = 2 \zeta (3)$$ Letting $$\frac{1}{n+m} = \int_0^1 t^{m+n-1} \, dt$$ the double sum factorizes nicely under the $t$ -integral leading to $$s =\int_0^1 t^{-1} \sum _{n=1}^{\infty }\frac{t^{n}}{n} \sum _{m=1}^{\infty }\frac{t^{m}}{m} \, dt$$ The sums are just $-\log (1-t)$ so that we have $$s = \int_0^1 t^{-1} {\log (1-t)}^{2} \, dt$$ Letting now $$t \to 1 - e^{-u}$$ gives $$s = \int_0^\infty u^{2} \frac{e^{-u}}{1-e^{-u}} \, du$$ Expanding into a geometric sum gives $$s = \sum _{k=1}^{\infty } \int_0^\infty u^{2}e^{- k\; u} \, du$$ The integral can easily be evaluated letting $k\; u \to z$ to give $$\frac {1}{k^3} \Gamma(3)$$ Hence observing that $\Gamma(3)=2$ and $$\sum _{k=1}^{\infty } \frac{1}{k^3} = \zeta(3)$$ completes the proof.
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\frac{t}{2}\log(2\sin(t))dt$

<think>
\begin{align} I=&\int^1_0 \frac{\tan^{-1}{\frac{1-x}{1+x}}\tan^{-1}x}{1-x}dx\\ \overset{ibp}=& \int^1_0 \frac{\ln(1-x)\left( \tan^{-1}{\frac{1-x}{1+x}}-\tan^{-1}x\right)}{1+x^2}\overset{x\to \frac{1-x}{1+x}}{ dx}\\ =& \int^1_0 \frac{\ln\frac{2x}{1+x}\left(2 \tan^{-1}x -\frac\pi4\right)}{1+x^2}{ dx}\\ =& \int^1_0 \frac{2\ln\frac{4x}{1+x^2} \tan^{-1}x }{1+x^2}dx +\int^1_0 \frac{2\ln\frac{1+x^2}{2(1+x)}\tan^{-1}x }{1+x^2}-\frac{\frac\pi4\ln\frac{2x}{1+x}}{1+x^2}\ dx \end{align} Note that the 2nd integral vanishes as seen below \begin{align} &\int^1_0 \underset{x\to \frac{1-x}{1+x}}{\frac{2\ln\frac{1+x^2}{2(1+x)}\tan^{-1}x }{1+x^2}}{ dx} -\int^1_0 \frac{\frac\pi4 \ln\frac{2x}{1+x}}{1+x^2}dx= \int^1_0 \frac{\frac\pi4 \ln\frac{1+x^2}{4x}}{1+x^2}dx=0 \end{align} Thus $$I= \int^1_0 \frac{2\ln\frac{4x}{1+x^2} \tan^{-1}x }{1+x^2}{dx} \overset{x=\tan \frac t2} =\int_0^{\frac\pi2}\frac t2\ln(2\sin t)dt= \frac{7}{32}\zeta(3) $$ See here for the last step.
</think>
