Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{x}{e^{x^2}+ e^{-x^2}}\right)^n \, dx$

<think>
We consider the below integral: $$ I(n) = \int_0^{\infty} \left( \frac{x}{e^{x^2} + e^{-x^2}} \right)^n \, dx $$ For background, recall that the Gamma function is defined by $$ \Gamma(z) = \int_0^\infty t^{z-1} e^{-t} \, dt, \quad \Re(z) > 0, $$ so that in particular $$ \int_0^\infty t^{z-1} e^{-st} \, dt = \frac{\Gamma(z)}{s^z} $$ Also recall the identity: $$ (1+u)^{-n} = \sum_{m=0}^\infty \binom{n+m-1}{m} (-u)^m $$ The main result is stated below: \begin{align} I(n) = \frac{\Gamma\!\left(\tfrac{n+1}{2}\right)}{2} \sum_{m=0}^\infty (-1)^m \binom{n+m-1}{m} (n+2m)^{-\frac{n+1}{2}} \end{align} Substitution $t = x^2$ . Let $t = x^2$ , so that $dx = \frac{dt}{2\sqrt{t}}$ , and $x = \sqrt{t}$ . Then, \begin{align} I(n) &= \int_0^\infty \frac{x^n}{(e^{x^2} + e^{-x^2})^n} \, dx \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty \frac{t^{n/2}}{(e^t + e^{-t})^n} t^{-1/2} \, dt \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty t^{\frac{n-1}{2}} \frac{dt}{(e^t + e^{-t})^n} \end{align} Hence, $$ I(n) = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty t^{\frac{n-1}{2}} \frac{1}{(e^t + e^{-t})^n} \, dt $$ Rewriting the denominator. Observe that $$ e^t + e^{-t} = e^{-t}(1 + e^{2t}) = e^t(1 + e^{-2t}) $$ We use the form: $$ (e^t + e^{-t})^{-n} = e^{-nt}(1 + e^{2t})^{-n} = e^{nt}(1 + e^{-2t})^{-n} $$ Inserting this into the integral gives: $$ I(n) = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty t^{\frac{n-1}{2}} e^{-nt} (1 + e^{-2t})^{-n} \, dt $$ Now apply the binomial series: $$ (1 + e^{-2t})^{-n} = \sum_{m=0}^\infty \binom{n+m-1}{m} (-e^{-2t})^m = \sum_{m=0}^\infty \binom{n+m-1}{m} (-1)^m e^{-2mt} $$ Substituting this into the integral: $$ I(n) = \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty t^{\frac{n-1}{2}} e^{-nt} \sum_{m=0}^\infty \binom{n+m-1}{m} (-1)^m e^{-2mt} \, dt $$ Assuming term-by-term integration is justified: \begin{align} I(n) = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{m=0}^\infty (-1)^m \binom{n+m-1}{m} \int_0^\infty t^{\frac{n-1}{2}} e^{-(n+2m)t} \, dt \end{align} Using the Gamma function: $$ \int_0^\infty t^{\frac{n-1}{2}} e^{-(n+2m)t} \, dt = \frac{\Gamma\!\left( \frac{n+1}{2} \right)}{(n + 2m)^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} $$ Therefore: $$ I(n) = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{m=0}^\infty (-1)^m \binom{n+m-1}{m} \frac{\Gamma\!\left( \frac{n+1}{2} \right)}{(n + 2m)^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} $$ Finally, factor out the constant: $$ I(n) = \frac{\Gamma\!\left( \frac{n+1}{2} \right)}{2} \sum_{m=0}^\infty (-1)^m \binom{n+m-1}{m} (n + 2m)^{-\frac{n+1}{2}} $$ Numerical verification for the closed form and the integral \begin{array}{c|c|c} n & \text{closed form } & \text{Integral Expression} \\ \hline 1 & 0.39269908169872415481 & 0.39269908169872415482 \\ 2 & 0.094766002680412 & 0.094766002680412133579 \\ 3 & 0.0259978496360762 & 0.025997849636077179039 \\ 4 & 0.0075402944966602 & 0.007540294496602175356 \\ 5 & 0.002256598131146 & 0.0022565981311454201286 \\ 6 & 0.000689062333003 & 0.00068906233300314074189 \\ 7 & 0.000213374690745 & 0.00021337469074537602378 \\ 8 & 0.0000667573925 & 0.00006675739251729180495 \\ 9 & 0.000021051436954106155279 & 0.000021051436954106155279 \\ 10 & 6.679926256 \times 10^{-6} & 6.6799262559104934239 \times 10^{-6} \\ \end{array}
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{2\pi}e^{-x}\arcsin \sin(x)dx$

<think>
Note that $f(x)=\sin^{-1}\sin x$ is a periodic function of period $T=2\pi$ . Let $$I_n=\int_{0}^{nT} e^{-x} f(x) dt.$$ As $f(x+T)=e^{-T} f(x)$ , we can break the integral $I_n$ into the intervals $(0,T), (T,2T), (2T,3T).......((n-1)T,nT)$ and have $$I_n=\left(\frac{e^{-nT}-1}{e^{-T}-1}\right)\int_{0}^{T} f(x) dx\implies I_{\infty}=\frac{\int_{0}^{T} f(x) dx}{1-e^{-T}}.$$ Let us evaluate $$J=\int_{0}^{T} f(x) dx=\int_{0}^{2\pi}e^{-x} \sin^{-1} \sin x dx= \int_{0}^{\pi/2} x e^{-x} dx+ \int_{\pi/2}^{3\pi/2} e^{-x} (\pi-x) dx+ \int_{3\pi/2}^{2\pi} e^{-x} (x-2\pi) dx.$$ Next using $\int_{a}^{b} xe^{-x} dx=(1+a)e^{-a}-(1+b)e^{-b}$ and $\int_{a}^{b} e^{-x} dx=e^{-a}-e^{-b}.$ We gather $$J=e^{-\pi}[(e^{\pi}-e^{-\pi})-2(e^{\pi/2}-e^{-\pi/2})]. $$ Finally the required $$I_{\infty}=\frac{J}{1-e^{-2\pi}}=1-\mbox{sech}\frac{\pi}{2}.$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\arcsin(\sin(t))e^{-st}dt$

<think>
Consider the Laplace transform $$F(s) \equiv \int_0^\infty \arcsin(\sin t)e^{-st}dt$$ where $F(1)$ is the integral we want. The function $\arcsin(\sin(t))$ is the sum of (alternating) triangles and each triangle is the (shifted) convolution of the following rectangle with itself: $$h(t) = \begin{cases} 1 & 0\leq x \leq \frac{\pi}{2} \\ 0 & \text{else}\end{cases}$$ Since the Laplace transform is linear we can decompose it into a sum $$F(s) = \int_0^\infty (h\star h)(t)e^{-st}dt - \int_0^\infty (h\star h)(t-\pi)e^{-st}dt + \cdots$$ And because each function is $0$ up until the point $t=k\pi$ for nonnegative integer $k\in\Bbb{Z_{\geq0}}$ , we can use the Laplace time shift to modulation property $$F(s) = \int_0^\infty (h\star h)(t) e^{-st}dt\left(1-e^{-s\pi}+e^{-2s\pi}-\cdots\right) = \int_0^\infty (h\star h)(t)e^{-st}dt\left(\frac{1}{1+e^{-s\pi}}\right)$$ which leaves us with our final Laplace transformation property to exploit, that the Laplace transform of the convolution of functions is the product of their Laplace transforms $$F(s) = \frac{(H(s))^2}{1+e^{-s\pi}} = \frac{1}{2}\left(e^{s\frac{\pi}{4}}H(s)\right)^2\operatorname{sech}\left(s\frac{\pi}{2}\right)$$ Having cheated our way out of complex integration with convenient properties, we are left with a simple integral to calculate $$H(s) = \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}}e^{-st}dt = \frac{1-e^{-s\frac{\pi}{2}}}{s} = \frac{2e^{-s\frac{\pi}{4}}}{s}\sinh\left(s\frac{\pi}{4}\right)$$ which gives us $$F(s)=\frac{1}{s^2}\left(2\sinh^2\left(s\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\operatorname{sech}\left(s\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right) = \frac{1-\operatorname{sech}\left(s\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}{s^2}$$ with the help of a hyperbolic double angle identity, and thus $F(1) = \boxed{1-\operatorname{sech}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt{x+1}+2}{(x+1)^2-\sqrt{x+1}}dx$

<think>
The integral in your self answer has no simple closed form but here's this: $$I=\int\frac{\sqrt{x+1}+2}{(x+1)^2-\sqrt{x+1}}dx$$ Substitute $\sqrt{1+x}=u$ , $$I=2\int\frac{u+2}{u^3-1} \,du$$ Using $u^3-1=(u-1)(u^2+u+1)$ , $$I=2\int\frac{u+2}{(u-1)(u^2+u+1)} \,du=2\int \frac{1}{u-1}\,du-2\int \frac{u+1}{u^2+u+1}\,du$$ $$=2\int \frac{1}{u-1}\,du -\int \frac{2u+1}{u^2+u+1}\,du-\int\frac{1}{u^2+u+1}\,du$$ Now evaluating these integrals is straightforward: $$(1) \int \frac1x \,dx= \ln|x|$$ $$(2)\int\frac{f'(x)}{{f(x)}}\,dx=\ln(f(x))$$ $$(3)\int \frac{1}{x^2+a^2}=\frac1a\arctan \left(\frac{x}{a}\right)$$ and all this will match your old notes from the journal $$I=2\ln|\sqrt{x+1}-1|-\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{2\sqrt{x+1}+1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)-\ln|4x+4\sqrt{x+1}+8|+C$$ $$I=2\ln|\sqrt{x+1}-1|-\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{2\sqrt{x+1}+1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)-\ln|x+\sqrt{x+1}+2|+C$$ And, $$I=\int_1^\infty \frac{\sqrt{x+1}+2}{(x+1)^2-\sqrt{x+1}}dx=\frac{2}{\sqrt3}\arctan\left(\frac{2\sqrt2+1}{\sqrt3}\right)+\ln\left(\frac{3+\sqrt2}{3-2\sqrt2}\right)-\frac{\pi}{\sqrt3}$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{u(au+1)}\, du$

<think>
Let $u = e^x$ . This gives $ \,du = e^x \,dx$ , so $\, dx = \frac{du}{u}$ . The limits change from $x \in [0, \infty)$ to $u \in [1, \infty)$ . $$ I(a) = \int_1^\infty \frac{1}{au+1} \cdot \frac{du}{u} = \int_1^\infty \frac{1}{u(au+1)} \, du $$ Using partial fractions $\frac{1}{u(au+1)} = \frac{1}{u} - \frac{a}{au+1}$ $$ \begin{aligned} I(a) &= \int_1^\infty \left( \frac{1}{u} - \frac{a}{au+1} \right) du \\ &= \left[ \ln|u| - \ln|au+1| \right]_1^\infty \\ &= \left[ \ln\left|\frac{u}{au+1}\right| \right]_1^\infty \end{aligned} $$ Now, we evaluate the limits: $$ \begin{aligned} I(a) &= \lim_{u\to\infty} \ln\left(\frac{u}{au+1}\right) - \ln\left(\frac{1}{a(1)+1}\right) \\ &= \ln\left(\frac{1}{a}\right) - \ln\left(\frac{1}{a+1}\right) \\ &= -\ln(a) - (-\ln(a+1)) \\ &= \ln(a+1) - \ln(a) = \ln\left(\frac{a+1}{a}\right) \end{aligned} $$ Set $a=1$ in the general solution for $I(a)$ : $$ I(1) = \ln\left(\frac{1+1}{1}\right) = \ln(2) $$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{1+e^x}dx$

<think>
Let $e^{\frac{x}{2}} = \tan \theta$ . $$ \frac{1}{2}e^{\frac{x}{2}}dx = \sec^2\theta \, d\theta \quad \implies \quad dx = \frac{2}{\tan\theta}\sec^2\theta \, d\theta $$ so $$ \int \frac{1}{1+e^x}dx = \int\frac{1}{1+\tan^2\theta}\frac{2}{\tan\theta}\sec^2\theta \, d\theta = 2\int \frac{1}{\tan\theta}d\theta = 2\int \frac{\cos\theta}{\sin\theta}d\theta = 2\ln|\sin\theta|+C. $$ Since $e^{\frac{x}{2}} = \tan\theta$ , $\sin\theta = \frac{e^{\frac{x}{2}}}{\sqrt{1+e^x}}$ . So $$ \int \frac{1}{1+e^x}dx = 2\ln\left(\frac{e^{\frac{x}{2}}}{\sqrt{1+e^x}}\right)+C. $$ Then, $$ \begin{aligned} \int_0^\infty \frac{1}{1+e^x}dx &= \lim_{R\to\infty} \left. 2\ln\left(\frac{e^{\frac{x}{2}}}{\sqrt{1+e^x}}\right)\right|_0^R \\ &= \lim_{R\to\infty} 2\ln\left(\frac{e^{\frac{R}{2}}}{\sqrt{1+e^R}}\right) - 2\ln\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right). \end{aligned} $$ Note that $$ \lim_{R\to\infty} \frac{e^{\frac{R}{2}}}{\sqrt{1+e^R}} = 1 $$ and so $$ \lim_{R\to\infty} 2\ln\left(\frac{e^{\frac{R}{2}}}{\sqrt{1+e^R}}\right) = 2\ln(1)=0. $$ Therefore, $$ \int_0^\infty \frac{1}{1+e^x}dx = -2\ln\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) = \ln(2). $$ $$ \tag*{$\square$} $$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{x^a+1}{x^{2a}+1}dx$

<think>
A complex-analytic, reverse-engineering approach might be the following one. $\frac{1}{\sin z}$ and $\frac{1}{\cos z}$ are meromomorphic functions over the complex plane with simple poles at the even/odd multiples of $\frac{\pi}{2}$ . By computing the residues of these functions at such points (and recalling that both $\sin z$ and $\cos z$ are entire functions with order $1$ , since they are the imaginary/real part of $e^{iz}$ ) it follows that $$ \frac{1}{\sin z}=\frac{1}{z}+\sum_{n\geq 1}(-1)^n\left(\frac{1}{z-n\pi}+\frac{1}{z+n\pi}\right),\tag{ES} $$ $$ \frac{1}{\cos z}=\sum_{n\geq 0}(-1)^{n}\left(\frac{1}{z+(2n+1)\frac{\pi}{2}}-\frac{1}{z-(2n+1)\frac{\pi}{2}}\right)\tag{EC} $$ hold uniformly over any compact subset of $\mathbb{R}\setminus\frac{\pi}{2}\mathbb{Z}$ . As you essentially noticed in the last lines, for any $a>1$ we have $$ I(a)=\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{x^a+1}{x^{2a}+1}\,dx=\int_{0}^{1}\frac{1+x^{a-2}+x^{a}+x^{2a-2}}{1+x^{2a}}\,dx \tag{I}$$ and the integrand function in the RHS of $(I)$ can be expanded as a geometric series and termwise-integrated, leading to $$ I(a)=\sum_{n\geq 0}(-1)^n \left(\frac{1}{2an+1}+\frac{1}{2an+a-1}+\frac{1}{2an+a+1}+\frac{1}{2an+2a-1}\right)\tag{S} $$ which is clearly related to $(ES)$ and $(EC)$ evaluated at $z=\frac{\pi}{2a}$ . Indeed a simple substitution gives $$ I(a) = \frac{\pi}{2a}\left(\frac{1}{\sin\frac{\pi}{2a}}+\frac{1}{\cos\frac{\pi}{2a}}\right).\tag{F}$$

$$ \begin{align*} \mathcal{I} &= \frac{\pi}{16} \int_0^1 (1-a^2) \sec \left(a \frac{\pi}{2} \right) \, \mathrm{d}a \\& \overset{\text{IBP}}{=} \frac{1}{8} \int_0^1 a \ln \left(\frac{1+\sin\left(\frac{a \pi}{2}\right)}{1-\sin\left(\frac{a \pi}{2}\right) } \right) \, \mathrm{d}a \\&\overset{\frac{a \pi}{2}=u}{=} \frac{1}{2\pi^2} \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} u \ln \left(\frac{1+\sin(u)}{1-\sin(u)}\right) \, \mathrm{d}u \\&= \frac{-1}{\pi^2} \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} u \ln \left( \tan\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{u}{2}\right) \right) \, \mathrm{d}u \\&= \frac{1}{\pi^2} \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \left(u-\frac{\pi}{2}\right) \ln \left( \tan \left(\frac{u}{2} \right) \right) \, \mathrm{d}u \end{align*} $$ Now we apply the Fourier series of $\ln(\tan(x))$ to obtain $$ \begin{align*} \mathcal{I} &= \frac{2}{\pi^2} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2n+1} \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \left(\frac{\pi}{2}-u\right) \cos((2n+1)u) \, \mathrm{d}u \\&= \frac{2}{\pi^2} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(2n+1)^3} \\&= \frac{7 \zeta(3)}{4 \pi^2} \end{align*} $$ We conclude that $$\int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^2(x-1)}{(x^2+1)^3 \ln(x)} \, \mathrm{d}x= \frac{7 \zeta(3)}{4\pi^2} $$

Note that (consequence of Binomial Theorem): $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{n}(4n)!}{16^{n}(2n)!^2}=\frac{\sqrt{1+\sqrt{1-x}}}{\sqrt{2}\sqrt{1-x}},\tag{2}$$ replacing $x=k^2\sin^2{t}$ in $(2)$ integrating in $(0,\pi/2)$ and applying Wallis's formula: $$\frac{\sqrt{2}\pi}{2}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(4n)!k^{2n}}{2^{6n}(2n)!n!^2}=\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{\sqrt{\sqrt{1-k^2\sin^2t}+1}}{\sqrt{1-k^2\sin^2t}}dt=\frac{K(\sqrt{\frac{2k}{1+k}})}{\sqrt{1+k}}\tag{3}.$$ We have seen that: $$\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{k\log{(k)}K(\sqrt{\frac{2k}{1+k}})}{\sqrt{1+k}}dk=\frac{\sqrt{2}\pi}{3}-\frac{16}{9},\tag{4}$$ then multiplying $(3)$ by $k\log{k}$ , integrating in $(0,1)$ , using $(4)$ and: $$\int_{0}^{1}k^{2n+1}\log{k}dk=-\frac{1}{(n+1)^2},$$ we deduce $(1)$ .

\begin{align}J&=\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2 x\ln(1-x)}{1-x}dx\\ &\overset{\text{IBP}}=\underbrace{\left[\left(\int_0^x \frac{\ln^2 t}{1-t}dt-\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2 t}{1-t}dt\right)\ln(1-x)\right]_0^1}_{=0}+\\&\int_0^1 \frac{1}{1-x}\left(\underbrace{\int_0^x \frac{\ln^2 t}{1-t}dt}_{u(t)=\frac{t}{x}}-\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2 t}{1-t}dt\right)dx\\ &=\int_0^1\int_0^1 \left(\frac{x\ln^2(ux)}{(1-x)(1-ux)}-\frac{\ln^2 u}{(1-x)(1-u)}\right)dudx\\ &=\int_0^1 \int_0^1 \left(\frac{\ln^2 x}{(1-x)(1-u)}+\frac{2\ln x\ln u}{(1-x)(1-u)}-\frac{\ln^2(ux)}{(1-u)(1-ux)}\right)dudx\\ &=2\zeta(2)^2+\int_0^1\frac{1}{1-u}\left(\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2 x}{1-x}dx-\underbrace{\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2(ux)}{1-ux}dx}_{z(x)=ux}\right)du\\ &=2\zeta(2)^2+\int_0^1\frac{1}{u(1-u)}\left(u\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2 z}{1-z}dz-\int_0^u \frac{\ln^2 z}{1-z}dz\right)du\\ &\overset{\text{IPP}}=2\zeta(2)^2-\int_0^1 \ln\left(\frac{u}{1-u}\right)\left(\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^2 z}{1-z}dz-\frac{\ln^2 u}{1-u}\right)du\\ &=2\zeta(2)^2+\int_0^1 \frac{\ln\left(\frac{u}{1-u}\right)\ln^2 u}{1-u}du=\underbrace{2\zeta(2)^2}_{=5\zeta(4)}+\underbrace{\int_0^1 \frac{\ln^3 u}{1-u}du}_{=-6\zeta(4)}-J \end{align} Therefore, \begin{align}\boxed{J=-\frac{1}{2}\zeta(4)}\end{align} Addendum. Another solution more "natural". \begin{align} J&=\int_0^1\frac{\ln(1-x)\ln^2x}{1-x}dx\\ K&=\int_0^\infty\frac{\ln^2x\ln(1+x)}{x(1+x)}dx\\ &\overset{u=\frac x{1+x}}=-\int_0^1\frac{\ln(1-u)\ln^2\left(\frac{u}{1-u}\right)}udu\\ &=\int_0^1\frac{2\ln^2(1-u)\ln u-\ln^2 u\ln(1-u)-\ln^3(1-u)}udu\\ &=2\underbrace{\int_0^1\frac{\ln^2(1-u)\ln u}udu}_{z=1-u}-\underbrace{\int_0^1\frac{\ln^2u\ln(1-u)}udu}_{\text{IBP}}-\\ &\underbrace{\int_0^1\frac{\ln^3(1-u)}udu}_{z=1-u}\\ &=2J-\left(\frac{1}{3}+1\right)\int_0^1\frac{\ln^3u}{1-u}=\boxed{2J+8\zeta(4)} \end{align} On the other hand, \begin{align}K&=\int_0^1\frac{\ln^2x\ln(1+x)}{x(1+x)}dx+\underbrace{\int_1^\infty\frac{\ln^2x\ln(1+x)}{x(1+x)}dx}_{u=\frac1x}\\ &=\underbrace{\int_0^1\frac{\ln^2x\ln(1+x)}{x}dx}_{\text{IBP}}-\int_0^1\frac{\ln^2x\ln(1+x)}{1+x}dx+\\ &\int_0^1\frac{\ln^2x\ln(1+x)}{1+x}dx-\int_0^1\frac{\ln^3x}{1+x}dx\\ &=-\frac43\int_0^1\frac{\ln^3x}{1+x}dx=-\frac43\int_0^1\frac{\ln^3x}{1-x}dx+\frac43\underbrace{\int_0^1\frac{2x\ln^3x}{1-x^2}dx}_{u=x^2} =\boxed{7\zeta(4)} \end{align} Thus, \begin{align}\boxed{J=-\frac{\zeta(4)}2}\end{align}

But its position only affects the imaginary part of the integral. Now, let's consider the integral in the complex plane $$-\frac\pi 4\Re\oint_C\frac{\ln\Gamma(iz)}{\sinh^2(\pi z)}dz$$ along the following contour: where $r$ is small but fixed parameter. Noting that $\ln\Gamma(i(z-i))-\ln\Gamma(iz)=\ln(iz), \,\sinh^2(\pi(z-i))=\sinh^2(\pi z)$ , that integrals along the paths 1 and 2 tend to zero at $R\to\infty$ and that there are no poles insider to contour $C$ $$-\frac\pi 4\Re\oint_C\frac{\ln\Gamma(iz)}{\sinh^2(\pi z)}dz=\frac\pi4\Re\left(\int_{-\infty}^{-r}+\int_r^\infty\frac{\ln\Gamma(i(x-i))-\ln\Gamma(ix)}{\sinh^2(\pi x)}dx+I_{C_1}+I_{C_2}\right)=0$$ $$\Rightarrow\,\frac\pi4\Re\left(\int_{-\infty}^{-r}+\int_r^\infty\frac{\ln(ix)}{\sinh^2(\pi x)}dx\right)=I_1(r)=-\frac\pi4\Re\left(I_{C_1}+I_{C_2}\right)\tag{3}$$ where $I_{C_{1,2}}$ denotes the integrals along the small arches of the radius $r$ $$-\frac\pi4\left(I_{C_1}+I_{C_2}\right)=\frac\pi4\int_\pi^{2\pi}\frac{\ln\Gamma(ire^{i\phi})}{\sinh^2(\pi re^{i\phi})}ire^{i\phi}d\phi+\frac\pi4\int_0^\pi\frac{\ln\Gamma(1+ire^{i\phi})}{\sinh^2(\pi re^{i\phi})}ire^{i\phi}d\phi$$ $$=\frac\pi4\int_\pi^{2\pi}\frac{\ln\Gamma(ire^{i\phi})-\ln\Gamma(1+ire^{i\phi})}{\sinh^2(\pi re^{i\phi})}ire^{i\phi}d\phi+\frac\pi4\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{\ln\Gamma(1+ire^{i\phi})}{\sinh^2(\pi re^{i\phi})}ire^{i\phi}d\phi$$ $$=-\frac\pi4\int_\pi^{2\pi}\frac{\ln(ire^{i\phi})}{\sinh^2(\pi re^{i\phi})}ire^{i\phi}d\phi+\frac\pi4\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{\ln\Gamma(1+ire^{i\phi})}{\sinh^2(\pi i}2\int_\pi^{2\pi}\frac{ie^{-i\pi}}{\pi^2r}d\phi-\frac{\pi i}4\int_\pi^{2\pi}\frac{i\phi\, e^{-i\phi}}{\pi^2r}d\phi-\frac\pi4\frac{\ln r}{\pi^2r}\int_\pi^{2\pi}e^{-i\phi}id\phi+O(r\ln r)$$ integrating $$\frac\pi4\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{\ln\Gamma(1+ire^{i\phi})}{\sinh^2(\pi re^{i\phi})}ire^{i\phi}d\phi=\frac\gamma2+O(r)\tag{5}$$ Taking the real part and then putting (4), (5) into (3a) and then into (3) $$I_1(r)=\frac{\ln r}{2\pi r}+\frac1{2\pi r}+\frac\gamma2+O(r\ln r)\tag{6}$$ Putting (6) and (2) into (1) $$I=-\frac\gamma2-\frac{\ln(2\pi)}2+\lim_{r\to0}\left(\frac{\ln r}{2\pi r}+\frac1{2\pi With help of Mathematica and using Mellin and Inverse Mellin transform: $$\int_0^{\infty } \frac{\sin \left(x^n\right)}{x^2+1} \, dx=\\\mathcal{M}_s^{-1}\left[\mathcal{M}_x\left[\sin \left(x^n\right)\right](s) \mathcal{M}_x\left[\frac{1}{1+x^2}\right](1-s)\right](1)=\\\mathcal{M}_s^{-1}\left[\frac{\pi \sec \left(\frac{\pi s}{2}\right) \left(\Gamma \left(\frac{s}{n}\right) \sin \left(\frac{\pi s}{2 n}\right)\right)}{2 | n| }\right](1)=\\\mathcal{M}_s^{-1}\left[\frac{\pi \Gamma \left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{s}{2}\right) \Gamma \left(\frac{s}{n}\right) \Gamma \left(\frac{1+s}{2}\right)}{2 | n| \Gamma \left(\frac{s}{2 n}\right) \Gamma \left(1-\frac{s}{2 n}\right)}\right](1)$$ Then using definition of FoxH function I get: Mathematica code: Pi/(2 Abs[n])*FoxH[{{{1,-(1/n)}}, {{0,1/(2 n)}}}, {{{1/2,-(1/2)}, {1/2, 1/2}}, {{0,1/(2 n)}}}, 1] for: $n>0$ and $n\in \mathbb{R}$ ,
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{n^2t^2}{\sqrt{n^4t^4+1}}dt$

<think>
Note $$\frac{1}{n} \int_0^n \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{x^4+1}} \mathrm{d} x\overset{t=\frac{x}n}=\int_0^1\frac{n^2t^2}{\sqrt{n^4t^4+1}}dt=\int_0^1\frac{t^2}{\sqrt{t^4+\frac1{n^4}}}dt. $$ Since $$ \frac{t^2}{\sqrt{t^4+\frac1{n^4}}}\le1,$$ one has, by the convergence of boundedness, \begin{aligned} \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \int_0^n \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{x^4+1}} \mathrm{d} x = & \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \int_0^1\frac{t^2}{\sqrt{t^4+\frac1{n^4}}}dt=\int_0^1\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{t^2}{\sqrt{t^4+\frac1{n^4}}}dt=1. \end{aligned}
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\arcsin^2(x)\log xdx$

<think>
Here is the direct series approach, note that $$ \arcsin^2(x) = \frac1{2}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n}}{n^2\binom{2n}{n}} x^{2n},\quad \frac{\arcsin x}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} = \frac1{2}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n}}{n\binom{2n}{n}} x^{2n-1} $$ which gives $$ I = -\frac1{2}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n}}{n^2(2n+1)^2\binom{2n}{n}} = -\frac1{2}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n}}{\binom{2n}{n}} \left(\frac1{n^2} - \frac{4}{n(2n+1)} + \frac{4}{(2n+1)^2} \right) $$ where $$ \frac1{2}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n}}{n^2\binom{2n}{n}} = \arcsin^2(1) = \frac{\pi^2}{4} $$ $$ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n}}{n(2n+1)\binom{2n}{n}} = 2\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x\arcsin x}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} = 2\left[x-\sqrt{1-x^2}\arcsin x\right]_{x=0}^{1} = 2 $$ note the well-known integral which is nothing but $$ \begin{aligned} 2G = \int_{0}^{\pi/2} \frac{x}{\sin x} \,\mathrm{d}x & = \int_{0}^{1} \frac{\arcsin x}{x\sqrt{1-x^2}} \,\mathrm{d}x = \frac1{2}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n}}{n\binom{2n}{n}} \int_{0}^{1} x^{2n-2}\,\mathrm{d}x \\ & = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n}}{2n(2n-1)\binom{2n}{n}} = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n-2}}{(2n-1)^2\binom{2n-2}{n-1}} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{2^{2n}}{(2n+1)^2\binom{2n}{n}} \end{aligned} $$ combine those three results we have $$ I = \int_{0}^{1} \arcsin^2(x)\ln x\,\mathrm{d}x = 6-\frac{\pi^2}{4}-4G $$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{p}\log(x)^{2}\,\frac{1+x^2}{1+x^4}dx$

<think>
$$I=\int\log^2(x)\,\frac{1+x^2}{1+x^4}\,dx$$ Write $$\frac{1+x^2}{1+x^4}=\frac {(x+i)(x-i)} {\prod _{i=1}^4 (x-r_i)}$$ and use partial fraction decomposition to face $$\frac{1+x^2}{1+x^4}=\sum _{i=1}^4 \frac {A_i}{x-r_i}$$ and use $$\int \frac {\log^2(x)}{x-r_i}\,dx=\log ^2(x) \log \left(1-\frac{x}{r_i}\right)+2 \log (x) \,\text{Li}_2\left(\frac{x}{r_i}\right)-2\, \text{Li}_3\left(\frac{x}{r_i}\right)$$ Recombine everything and compute $$J(p)=\int_0^p\log^2(x)\,\frac{1+x^2}{1+x^4}\,dx$$ Expanding as a series for large $p$ $$J(p)=\frac{3 \pi ^3}{16 \sqrt{2}}-\frac{\log ^2(p)+2 \log (p)+2}{p}-\frac{9 \log ^2(p)+6 \log (p)+2}{27 p^3}+O\left(\frac{1}{p^5}\right)$$ Edit You could use this approach for $$K_{m,n}=\int_0^\infty \log^2(x)\,\frac{1+x^m}{1+x^n }\,dx$$ For $n=m+2$ , this would generate (starting from $m=0$ ) $$\left\{\frac{\pi ^3}{4},\frac{20 \pi ^3}{81 \sqrt{3}},\frac{3 \pi ^3}{16 \sqrt{2}},\frac{2\sqrt{850+362 \sqrt{5}}}{625} \pi ^3,\frac{7 \pi ^3}{54}\right\}$$ which is close to $$K_{m,m+2}\sim 4+\frac{\pi ^3}{85 m}$$
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt{x}\log(x)}{(1+x)^2}dx$

<think>
The integrand is positive for $x>1$ , so normally we'd just state the problem as $$\int_0^\infty\frac{\sqrt{x}\ln x}{(1+x)^2}dx=\pi.$$ Let's first note that the substitution $x=\tan^2 t$ allows us to solve a seemingly unrelated problem, $$\int_0^\infty\frac{x^{k-1}}{(1+x)^2}dx=\int_0^{\pi/2}2\sin^{2k-1}t\cos^{3-2k} tdt=\operatorname{B}(k,\,2-k)\\=\Gamma(k)\Gamma(2-k)=\pi(1-k)\csc\pi k.$$ (Look up Beta and Gamma functions if you don't know them well.) But this problem is not unrelated! Let's differentiate with respect to $k$ : $$\int_0^\infty\frac{x^{k-1}\ln x}{(1+x)^2}dx=-\pi\csc\pi k[1+(1-k)\cot\pi k].$$ Finally, substituting $k=\frac{3}{2}$ gives $$\int_0^\infty\frac{\sqrt{x}\ln x}{(1+x)^2}dx=\pi.$$
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{\pi/2}^{\pi}(\frac{1+2\cos(x)}{3})^ndx$

<think>
Let $I_n:=\int^{2\pi}_0\Big(\frac{1+2\cos x}{3}\Big)^n\,dx$ . The $2\pi$ -periodicity of $\cos$ allows us to change the interval of integration to $[-\pi,\pi]$ . For $|x|\leq \pi/2$ $$\Big(\frac{1+2\cos x}{3}\Big)^n=\exp\Big(-n\log\Big(\frac3{1+2\cos x}\Big)\Big)$$ On $[-\pi/2,\pi/2]$ , the function $g(x)=\log\Big(\frac3{1+2\cos x}\Big)=-\log\Big(\frac{1+2\cos x}{3}\Big)$ attains its minimum at $x=0$ with $g(0)=0$ for $g'(x)=\frac{2\sin x}{1+2\cos x}$ and $g''(x)=\frac{(1+2\cos x)2\cos x+4\sin^2 x}{(1+2\cos x)^2}=\frac{2\cos x+4}{(1+2\cos x)^2}$ . $g''(0)=\frac{6}{9}=\frac{2}{3}$ . The Laplace' method yields $$\int^{\pi/2}_{-\pi/2}\Big(\frac{1+2\cos x}{3}\Big)^n\,dx\sim \frac{\sqrt{2\pi}}{\sqrt{\frac23}}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}=\sqrt{\frac{3\pi}{n}}$$ Outside $[-\pi/2,\pi/2]$ , $\Big|\frac{1+2\cos x}{3}\Big|\leq\frac13$ and and so, $$\int^{\pi}_{\pi/2}\Big(\frac{1+2\cos x}{3}\Big)^n\,dx\leq\frac{\pi}{2} 3^{-n}\xrightarrow{n\rightarrow\infty}0$$ Hence $I_n\sim \frac{\sqrt{3\pi}}{\sqrt{n}}$ .
</think>
You are Qwen, created by Alibaba Cloud. You are a helpful assistant.
Evaluate the integral: $\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}(\frac{1+2\cos(x)}{3})^n dx$

<think>
$$ \int_{-\pi}^\pi (\frac{1+2\cos x}{3})^n dx $$ $$ =\frac{1}{3^n}\int_{-\pi}^\pi \sum_{l=0}^n \binom{n}{l}(2\cos x)^l dx $$ where the integrals are zero for odd $l$ $$ =\frac{1}{3^n}\int_{-\pi}^\pi \sum_{l=0,2,4,6,8,\ldots }^n \binom{n}{l}2^l \cos^l(x) dx $$ $$ =\frac{1}{3^n}\int_{-\pi}^\pi \sum_{l=0}^{n/2} \binom{n}{2l}4^l \cos^{2l}(x) dx $$ $$ =\frac{1}{3^n} \pi \sum_{l=0}^{n/2} \binom{n}{2l}4^l 2\binom{2l}{l}/4^l $$ $$ =\frac{2}{3^n} \pi \sum_{l=0}^{n/2} \binom{n}{2l} \binom{2l}{l} $$ $$ =\frac{2}{3^n} \pi \sum_{l=0}^{n/2} \frac{n!}{(n-2l)!l!^2} $$ Where $\sum_{l=0}^{n/2} \frac{n!}{(n-2l)!l!^2} = 1,1,3,7,19,51,\ldots$ are known as the central trinomial coefficients https://oeis.org/A002426 which grow for large $n$ as $$ \sum_{l=0}^{n/2} \frac{n!}{(n-2l)!l!^2}\sim \frac12 \sqrt{3/\pi} 3^n/\sqrt{n}. $$ So in the limit $n\to \infty$ the integral is $$ \sim\frac{2}{3^n} \pi \frac12 \sqrt{3/\pi} 3^n/\sqrt{n} =\sqrt{3\pi/n}. $$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}{\frac{e^{-x}\sin ax}{x}}dx$

<think>
Assume the simpler twin integrals \begin{align} &\int_0^{\infty} {\frac{e^{-x}\sin ax}x}dx =\tan^{-1}a\\ & \int_0^{\infty} {\frac{e^{-x} (1-\cos ax)}x}dx =\frac12\ln(1+a^2) \end{align} as well as $ \int_0^{\infty} e^{-x}\ln x\ dx =-\gamma$ are known. Then \begin{align} I(a)=&\int_0^{\infty} \frac{e^{-x}\sin ax\ln x}{x}dx \\ I’(a)=& \int_0^{\infty} {e^{-x}\cos ax\ln x}\ dx = \frac1a\int_0^{\infty} {e^{-x}\ln x}\ d(\sin ax)\\ \overset{ibp}=&\ \frac1{a^2}\int_0^{\infty} {e^{-x}\ln x}\ d(1-\cos ax)-\frac1a \int_0^{\infty} {\frac{e^{-x}\sin ax}x}\ dx \\ \overset{ibp} =&-\frac1{a^2}I’(a)-\frac{\gamma}{a^2} - +\frac1{2a^2}\ln(1+a^2)-\frac1a \tan^{-1}a \\ =& -\frac{\gamma}{1+a^2}-\frac12\bigg[\ln(1+a^2)\tan^{-1}a\bigg]’\\ \end{align} Thus \begin{align} &\int_0^{\infty} \frac{e^{-x}\sin ax\ln x}{x}dx \\ =&\int_0^a I’(t)dt =-\gamma \tan^{-1}a -\frac12 \ln(1+a^2)\tan^{-1}a \end{align} For comparison, its twin is \begin{align} &\int_0^{\infty} \frac{e^{-x}(1-\cos ax)\ln x}{x}dx \\ =&-\frac{ \gamma }2\ln(1+a^2) -\frac18 \ln^2(1+a^2)+\frac12 (\tan^{-1}a)^2 \end{align}
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-x}\sin(ax)\log(x)}{x}dx$

<think>
The desired integral $$I(a)=\int_0^\infty \frac{e^{-x}\sin(ax)\ln x}xdx=\Im\frac{\partial}{\partial s}\,\bigg|_{s=-1}\int_0^\infty e^{-x(1-ia)}x^sdx$$ Making the substitution $x=t(1+ia)$ (what is, in fact, integration along a segment of a circle in the complex plane, where the integrals along a small arch around $z=0$ and along a big arch tend to zero as the radiuses of the arches tend to zero and $\infty$ correspondingly). $$J(a,s)=\int_0^\infty e^{-x(1-ia)}x^sdx=(1+ia)^{1+s}\int_0^\infty t^se^{-t(1+a^2)}dt$$ $$=\frac{(1+ia)^{1+s}}{(1+a^2)^{1+s}}\Gamma(1+s)$$ Denoting $s=-1+\epsilon$ and taking the imaginary part $$I(a)=\frac{\partial}{\partial\epsilon}\,\bigg|_{\epsilon=0}\frac{\Gamma(\epsilon)}{(1+a^2)^{\frac\epsilon2}}\sin(\epsilon\arctan a)=\frac{\partial}{\partial\epsilon}\,\bigg|_{\epsilon=0}\frac{\Gamma(1+\epsilon)}{(1+a^2)^{\frac\epsilon2}}\frac{\sin(\epsilon\arctan a)}\epsilon$$ $$=-\left(\gamma+\frac{\ln(1+a^2)}2\right)\arctan a$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-x}\sin(ax)\log(x)}{x}dx$

<think>
If you consider $$\int \frac{e^{-(1-i a)x }\log(x)}{x }\,dx $$ you face a generalized hypergeometric function (have a look here ) plus a few more or less pleasant terms. Using the bounds for the imaginary part $$\int_0^{\infty} \frac{e^{-x}\sin(ax)\log(x)}{x}\,dx=-\left(\log \left(\sqrt{a^2+1}\right)+\gamma\right) \tan ^{-1}(a)$$ If you work with (as you wrote it), $$\int_0^{\infty}\frac{dt}{t}\left[e^{-t}\arctan(a)-\arctan\left(\frac{a}{1+t}\right)\right]\,dt$$ the singularity is removable since if $$A=\frac{1}{t}\left[e^{-t}\arctan(a)-\arctan\left(\frac{a}{1+t}\right)\right]$$ $$A=\left(\frac{a}{a^2+1}-\tan ^{-1}(a)\right)+ \left(\frac{1}{2} \tan^{-1}(a)-\frac{a}{\left(a^2+1\right) ^2}\right)\,t +O\left(t^2\right)$$ We also have $$A=\frac{e^{-t} \tan ^{-1}(a)}{t}-\frac a {t^2}+\frac a {t^3}+O\left(\frac{1}{t^4}\right)$$ Using the logarithmic representation of the arctangent function, the antiderivative is given in terms of the exponential integral function, a few logarithms and polylogarithms of complex arguments. Using the bounds, the same result.

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\frac{1}{a+b\sin(x)}dx$

<think>
Here’s my continuation to your last step, $$\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{1}{a+b\sin x}\,dx=\frac{1}{\sqrt{b^2-a^2}}\left[{\ln\left(\frac{\left|\sqrt{b^{2} - a^{2}} - b - a\right|}{\left|\sqrt{b^{2} - a^{2}} + b + a\right|}\right)} - {\ln\left(\frac{\left|2 \sqrt{b^{2} - a^{2}} - 2b\right|}{\left|2 \sqrt{b^{2} - a^{2}} + 2b\right|}\right)}\right]$$ In your first integral, set $b=1$ $$I_1=\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{1}{a+\sin x}\,dx=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-a^2}}\left[{\ln\left(\frac{\left|\sqrt{1 - a^{2}} - (1+a)\right|}{\left|\sqrt{1 - a^{2}} + (1 + a)\right|}\right)} - {\ln\left(\frac{\left| \sqrt{1 - a^{2}} - 1\right|}{\left| \sqrt{1 - a^{2}} + 1\right|}\right)}\right]$$ In your second integral, set $b=-1$ $$I_2=\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{1}{a-\sin x}\,dx=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-a^2}}\left[{\ln\left(\frac{\left|\sqrt{1 - a^{2}} + 1 - a\right|}{\left|\sqrt{1 - a^{2}}+a-1\right|}\right)} - {\ln\left(\frac{\left| \sqrt{1- a^{2}} + 1\right|}{\left| \sqrt{1 - a^{2}} - 1\right|}\right)}\right]$$ $$\frac{\partial I(a)}{\partial a}=I_1+I_2$$ (I have not given proof to above generalized integral as it’s pretty popular and doable using the half angle tangent substitution and some partial fractions) But i think this is too messy to solve, if you are interested to carry on, refer here Anyways, I found a nice closed form to share, i will leave it for reference; $$\boxed{\int_0^{\pi/2}\frac{1}{1+a\sin x }\, dx=\frac{2}{\sqrt{1-a^2}}\left(\tan^{-1}\left(\sqrt{\frac{1+a}{1-a}}\right) - \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{a}{\sqrt{1-a^2}}\right)\right)}$$ Here's the easier alternative; Consider the integral from here Set $a^2=A$ and $b^2=A-1$ We get, $$J(a)=\int_0^{\pi/2}\log(A-\sin^2(x))dx=\pi\ln \left(\frac{\sqrt{A}+\sqrt{A-1}}{2}\right)$$ So for $a>1$ , $$\boxed{I(a)=\int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(a^2-\sin^2x)\,\mathrm dx=\pi\ln \left(\frac{{a}+\sqrt{a^2-1}}{2}\right)}$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}u^z(1-u)^{-z}dz$

<think>
Under $z=x+\frac12(\alpha-\beta)$ , $$I=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\Gamma(\lambda+z)\Gamma(\lambda -z)dz=\Gamma(2\lambda)\int_{-\infty}^\infty \int_0^1 u^{\lambda+z-1}(1-u)^{\lambda-z-1}du\space dz \\=\Gamma(2\lambda)\int_0^1u^{\lambda-1}(1-u)^{\lambda-1}\left[\underbrace{\int_{-\infty}^\infty u^z(1-u)^{-z}dz}_{J(u)}\right ]du $$ Where $\lambda=\frac12(\alpha+\beta)$ . $$J(u)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty u^z(1-u)^{-z}dz=\int_{-\infty}^\infty \exp\left(z\log\frac{u}{1-u}\right)dz\stackrel{}{=}\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{sz}dz=2\pi\delta(s)$$ Where $s=\log\frac{u}{1-u}$ . Using $$\delta(g(u))=\frac{\delta(u-u_0)}{|\frac{dg}{du}|}$$ With $g(u)=\log\frac{u}{1-u}$ and $u_0=1/2$ , $$J(u)=\frac\pi2\delta\left(u-\frac12\right).$$ Thus , $$I=\Gamma(2\lambda)\int_{-\infty}^\infty u^{\lambda-1}(1-u)^{\lambda-1}\left[\frac\pi2\delta\left(u-\frac12\right)\right]du=\Gamma(2\lambda)\frac\pi2\left(\frac12\right)^{\lambda-1}\left(1-\frac12\right)^{\lambda-1}\\=\pi2^{1-2\lambda}\Gamma(2\lambda)\space ,\space \Re(\lambda)>0$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\log \left| \sin(t)^{2}- \sin(s)^{2}\right|dt$

<think>
Case $|x|<1$ : Let $z=\sin t $ and $x=\sin s$ to rewrite the integral as \begin{align} & \int_{-\pi/2}^{\pi/2} \ln \left| \sin t - \sin s\right|\,dt\\ &=\int_0^{\pi/2} \ln \left| \sin^2 t - \sin^2 s\right|\,dt =\frac14\int_0^{2\pi} \ln \left| \sin^2 t - \sin^2 s\right|\,dt\\ &=\frac{1}{4}\int_0^{2\pi} \ln \left| \sin \left( t+s\right)\right|+\ln \left| \sin \left( t-s\right)\right|\,dt\\ &=\frac{1}{2}\int_0^{2\pi} \ln \left| \sin t\right|\,dt= 2 \int_0^{\pi/2} \ln \sin t\ dt=-\pi \ln2 \end{align}

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\operatorname{arccot}\sqrt{2+y^2}}{(1+y^2)\sqrt{2+y^2}}dy$

<think>
Integrate as follows \begin{align} &\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}\frac{\tan^{-1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-2x^2}}}{1+x^2} {dx}\\ \overset{ibp}=&\ \frac{\pi^2}{18}-\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}\frac{x\tan^{-1} x}{(1-x^2)\sqrt{1-2x^2}}dx \>\>\>\>\>\>\>\sqrt2 x=\cos t\\ =& \ \frac{\pi^2}{18} -\int_{\cot^{-1}\sqrt2}^{\pi/2} \frac{\tan^{-1}(\cos t/\sqrt2)\cos t}{2-\cos^2 t}dt\\ =& \ \frac{\pi^2}{18} -\int_{\cot^{-1}\sqrt2}^{\pi/2}\int_0^1 \frac{\sqrt2\cos^2t}{(2-\cos^2 t)(2+y^2\cos^2t)}dy\ dt\\ =& \ \frac{\pi^2}{18} -\int_0^1\frac1{1+y^2}\bigg(\frac\pi4-\frac\pi{2\sqrt{2+y^2}}+\frac{\cot^{-1} \sqrt{2+y^2}}{\sqrt{2+y^2}}\bigg)dy\\ =& \ \frac{11\pi^2}{144}- \int_0^1 \frac{\cot^{-1} \sqrt{2+y^2}}{(1+y^2)\sqrt{2+y^2}}dy =\frac{11\pi^2}{144}-\frac{\pi^2}{32}= \frac{13\pi^2}{288} \end{align} where \begin{align} I=&\int_0^1 \frac{\cot^{-1} \sqrt{2+y^2}}{(1+y^2)\sqrt{2+y^2}}dy =\int_0^1 \int_0^1 \frac1{(1+y^2)(y^2+x^2+2)}dx \ dy\\ =& \int_0^1 \int_0^1 \frac1{1+x^2}\bigg(\frac1{1+y^2}-\frac1{y^2+x^2+2}\bigg)dy \ dx =\frac{\pi^2}{16}-I=\frac{\pi^2}{32} \end{align}
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{- a \, x^2 - b \, \cosh(x)}\, dx$

<think>
By using $$ e^{-z \, \cosh(\theta)} = I_{0}(z) + 2 \, \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^n \, I_{n}(z) \, \cosh(n \theta) $$ and \begin{align*} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{- a \, x^2} \, dx &= \frac{1}{2} \, \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} \\ \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{- a \, x^2} \, \cosh(n x) \, dx &= \frac{1}{2} \, \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} \, e^{n^2/(4 a)} \end{align*} then $$ \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{- a \, x^2 - b \, \cosh(x)} \, dx = \frac{1}{2} \, \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} \, \left( I_{0}(b) + 2 \, \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (-1)^n \, I_{n}(b) \, e^{n^2/(4 a)} \right). $$ Note that as $n$ increases so does the exponential in the summation. If $I_{n}(b)$ does not compensate for the growth as $n$ gets large then the series will certainly diverge, or at least have issues. This solution sets forth a plan of attack and has avoided the consideration(s) for the series to be absolutely convergent. This is a good exercise for the reader.
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\log\left(1-\alpha^2x^2 \right)}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx$

<think>
let $x=\sin t$ , $$ I(\alpha)=\int_0^1 \frac{\ln\left(1-\alpha^2x^2 \right)}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx =\int_0^{\pi/2}\ln(1-\alpha^2 \sin^2 t)dt $$ \begin{align} I'(\alpha) =& \int_0^{\pi/2}\frac{-2\alpha\sin^2 t}{1-\alpha^2 \sin^2 t}dt \\ =&\ \frac2{\alpha}\int_0^{\pi/2}\left(1-\frac{1}{1-\alpha^2 \sin^2 t}\right)dt = \frac{\pi}{\alpha} - \frac{\pi}{\alpha\sqrt{1-\alpha^2}} \end{align} Thus $$I(\alpha) = \int_0^{\alpha} I'(s)ds= \pi \int_0^{\alpha}\bigg( \frac1{s} -\frac{1}{s\sqrt{1-s^2}}\bigg)ds\\ =\pi \ln\bigg(1+\sqrt{1-s^2}\bigg)_0^{\alpha} =\pi\ln\frac{1+\sqrt{1-\alpha^2}}2$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{1+e^{\sqrt{x}}}dx$

Substitute $t=e^{-\sqrt x}$ $$ \int_0^{\infty} \frac{1}{1+e^{\sqrt{x}}}dx=-2\int_0^1 \frac{\ln t}{1+t}dt =-2(-\frac{\pi^2}{12})=\frac{\pi^2}6 $$ where $\int_0^1 \frac{\ln t}{1+t}dt\overset{ibp}=- \int_0^1 \frac{\ln (1+t)}{t}dt = -\frac{\pi^2}{12} $ .
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}ye^{-y}dy$

<think>
The integral equals $$\sum_{n=1}^\infty(-1)^{n-1}\int_0^\infty e^{-n\sqrt x}dx.$$ Substitute $y=n^2x$ which gives $$\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^{n-1}}{n^2}\int_0^\infty 2ye^{-y}dy.$$ Now combine Alternating Reciprocal of Squares with $$\int_0^\infty ye^{-y}dy=\Gamma(2)=1.$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{M}\sin(x^3)dx$

<think>
Here's a different flavor of approximation that's much more efficient: Expanding the integral in a series at $M = \infty$ (see below for the derivation) gives $$\int_0^M \sin(x^3) \,dx = \frac16 \Gamma\left(\frac13\right) - \frac1{3 M^2} \cos (M^3) + \cdots ,$$ where $\cdots$ denotes a remainder decaying as $O(M^{-5})$ . Already for $M = \pi$ truncating after the first nonconstant term gives an absolute error $<10^{-3}$ : \begin{align} \int_0^\pi \sin(x^3) \,dx &= \color{#007f00}{0.4158338146\ldots} \\ \frac16 \Gamma\left(\frac13\right) - \frac1{3 \pi^2} \cos (\pi^3) &= \color{#007f00}{0.415}5104547\ldots . \end{align} Figure 1. Graphs of $\color{#7f0000}{\int_0^M \sin (x^3) \,dx}$ (red) and the approximation $\color{#00007f}{\frac16 \Gamma\left(\frac13\right) - \frac1{3 M^2} \cos (M^3)}$ (blue): This computation reduces the problem to evaluating or looking up $\operatorname{\Gamma}\left(\frac13\right) = 2.6789385347\ldots$ to adequate accuracy. This can be accomplished, e.g., with the approximation https://dlmf.nist.gov/5.11#E14 , a truncation of which gives $$\operatorname{\Gamma}\left(\frac13\right) \approx \frac{6!}{\frac13 \cdot \frac43 \cdot \cdots \cdot \frac{16}3 \cdot \frac{19}3} \left(7 + \frac{\frac13 - 1}{2}\right)^{\frac13} = \frac1{1729}\left(\frac{3^{26} 5}{2^7}\right)^{\frac13} = \color{#007f00}{2.678}1972464\ldots ,$$ or a method of Borwein and Zucker , giving (where $m = \frac{2 - \sqrt 3}{4}$ ) $$\operatorname{\Gamma}\left(\frac13\right) = \frac{2^{\frac49} \pi^{\frac23}}{3^{\frac1{12}} \operatorname{AGM}\left(1, \sqrt{1 - m}\right)} \approx \frac{2^{\frac49} \pi^{\frac23}}{3^{\frac1{12}} (1 - m)^{\frac14}} = \frac{2^{\frac{25}{36}} \pi^{\frac23}}{3^{\frac1{12}} (1 + \sqrt{3})^{\frac16}} = \color{#007f00}{2.67}90056121\ldots ,$$ either of which would contribute $< 10^{-4}$ to the error in the approximation of $\int_0^\pi \sin(x^3) \,dx$ . See answers to this question for more details of both of these approximations. Alternatively, since $e^{-u^3}$ decays rapidly enough, we have $$\Gamma\left(\frac13\right) = 3\int_0^\infty e^{-u^3} \,du \approx 3 \int_0^2 e^{-u^3} \,du,$$ and already for $n = 3$ Simpson's rule gives $\color{#007f00}{2.67}98249579\ldots$ , an absolute error $< 10^{-3}$ ( $n = 5$ gives an absolute error $< 10^{-4}$ ). To establish the above terms of the series (and the decay of the remainder term), we first write the integral as $$\int_0^M \sin(x^3) \,dx = \int_0^\infty \sin(x^3) \,dx - \int_M^\infty \sin(x^3) \,dx .$$ Using residue calculus or the Laplace transform gives that the first integral on the right, which gives the constant term of the series, has value $$\int_0^\infty \sin(x^3) \,dx = \frac16 \Gamma\left(\frac13\right) .$$ Applying integration by parts to the second integral on the right with $u = \frac1{x^2}$ , $dv = x^2 \sin(x^3) \,dx$ gives $$- \int_M^\infty \sin(x^3) \,dx = - \frac1{3 M^2} \cos (M^3) + \frac23 \int_M^\infty \frac{\cos(x^3)}{x^3} \,dx ,$$ and again applying integration by parts to the integral on the right gives that it decays as $O\left(M^{-5}\right)$ .

Using the principal branch of the logarithm and assuming that $0 \le x \le \pi/2$ , we have $$ \begin{align} \int \ln (\tan x) \, dx &= \int \ln \left( -i \, \frac{1-e^{-2ix}}{1+e^{-2ix}}\right) \, dx \\ &= \int \ln(-i) \, dx + \int \ln(1-e^{-2ix}) \, dx - \int \ln(1+e^{-2ix}) \, dx \\ &= -\frac{ i \pi x}{2} - \frac{1}{2i} \int \frac{\ln (1-u)}{u} \, du + \frac{1}{2i}\int \frac{\ln(1+u)}{u} \, du \\ &\overset{(1)}{=} - \frac{i \pi x}{2} + \frac{1}{2i} \operatorname{Li}_{2}(u) - \frac{1}{2i} \operatorname{Li}_{2}(-u) + C \\ &= \frac{1}{2i} \left( \pi x + \text{Li}_{2}(e^{-2ix}) -\text{Li}_{2}(-e^{-2ix}) \right) + C . \end{align}$$ Then, for example, $$ \begin{align} \int_{0}^{\pi /4} \ln(\tan x) \ dx &= \frac{1}{2i} \Big[\frac{\pi^{2}}{4} + \text{Li}_{2}(-i) -\text{Li}_{2}(i) - \text{Li}_{2}(1) + \text{Li}_{2}(-1) \Big] \\ &\overset{(2)}{=} \frac{1}{2i} \Bigg[\frac{\pi^{2}}{4} + \left( -\frac{\pi^{2}}{48}- i G \right) - \left(- \frac{\pi^{2}}{48} + i G \right) - \frac{\pi^{2}}{6} - \frac{\pi^{2}}{12}\Bigg] \\ &= \frac{1}{2i} \left( -2iG\right) \\ &= -G \, ,\end{align}$$ where $G$ is Catalan's constant. $ $ $(1)$ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dilogarithm $(2)$ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polylogarithm#Relationship_to_other_functions

\log(1+u)}{u+v} \, dv \, du & v\to uv\\ &= \frac19 \underbrace{\int_0^1 \log(1+u) \log\left(\frac{u^2(1+u)}{1+u^2}\right) \, du}_J \\ &\qquad + \frac19 \underbrace{\int_0^1 \int_{u^2}^\tfrac1u \frac{\log\frac{1+v}v}{u+v} \, dv \, du}_K & \text{by parts} \\ &= \frac19 \int_0^1 \left[2 \log t \log(1+t) + \log^2(1+t) \right. \\ &\qquad\qquad + 2t \log\left(1+\frac1t\right) \log\left(1+\frac1{t^2}\right) \\ &\qquad\qquad \left. + \left(\frac1{t^2}-1\right) \log(1+t) \log\left(1+t^2\right) \right] \, dt \\ &= \frac19 \left[2 \left(2-2\log2-I_1\right) + \left(2-4\log2 + 2\log^22\right)\right. \\ &\qquad\qquad + \left(\frac\pi2 + \log2 + 2\log^22 - 2I_1 + I_2 - 2I_3\right) \\ &\qquad\qquad \left. + \left(\frac\pi2 - 4 + 5\log2 - 2\log^22 + I_2 - 2I_3\right)\right] & (*) \\ &= \boxed{\frac{2 + \pi - \zeta(2) - 2\log2 - \log^22}9} \end{align*}$$ $K$ is evaluated as follows, then joined with $J$ using the dummy variable $t$ : $$\begin{align*} K &= \left\{\int_0^1 \int_0^{\sqrt v} + \int_1^\infty \int_0^\tfrac1v\right\} \frac{\log\frac{1+v}v}{u+v} \, du \, dv & \text{Fubini} \\ &= \int_0^1 \int_0^{\sqrt v} \frac{\log\frac{1+v}v}{u+v} \, du \, dv + \int_0^1 \int_0^v \frac{\log(1+v)}{v(1+uv)} \, du \, dv & v\to\frac1v \end{align*}$$ $(*)$ is the result of several rounds of integration by parts on $I$ which decomposes it into a combination of elementary integrals and some well-known ones, namely $$\begin{align*} I_1 = \int_0^1 \frac{\log(1+t)}t \, dt &= \frac{\pi^2}{12} \\ I_2 = \int_0^1 \frac{\log\left(1+t^2\right)}t \, dt &= \frac{\pi^2}{24} \\ I_3 = \int_0^1 \frac{\log\left(1+t^2\right)}{1+t} \, dt &= -\frac{\pi^2}{48} + \frac34\log^22 \end{align*}$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{M}\frac{\log(x)}{x+c}dx$

<think>
Actually you do not need Complex Analysis for this: $\frac{1}{(x+a)(x+b)}=\frac{1}{b-a}\left(\frac{1}{x+a}-\frac{1}{x+b}\right)$ and $$\begin{eqnarray*}\int_{0}^{M}\frac{\log x}{x+c}\,dx&\stackrel{x\mapsto cz}{=}& \int_{0}^{M/c}\frac{\log(c)+\log(z)}{z+1}\,dz=\log(c)\log(1+M/c)+\int_{0}^{M/c}\frac{\log z}{z+1}\,dz\\&\stackrel{z\mapsto 1/u}{=}&\log(c)\log(1+M/c)-\int_{c/M}^{+\infty}\frac{\log u}{u(u+1)}\\&\stackrel{u\mapsto v/M}{=}&\log(c)\log(1+M/c)-\int_{c}^{+\infty}\frac{\log(v)-\log(M)}{v(v/M+1)}\,dv\\&=&\log(Mc)\log(1+M/c)-\int_{c}^{+\infty}\frac{\log v}{v(v/M+1)}\,dv\tag{1}\end{eqnarray*}$$ from which it follows that $$\int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{\log x}{(x+a)(x+b)}\,dx =\\= \frac{1}{b-a}\lim_{M\to +\infty}\left(\log(Ma)\log(1+M/a)-\log(Mb)\log(1+M/b)-\int_{a}^{b}\frac{\log v}{v(v/M+1)}\,dv\right).\tag{2}$$ By the dominated convergence theorem the integral term inside the parenthesis converges to $-\frac{\log^2(b)-\log^2(a)}{2}$ while it is simple to check (for instance, through Lagrange's theorem) that $$\lim_{M\to +\infty}\left(\log(Ma)\log(1+M/a)-\log(Mb)\log(1+M/b)\right)=\log^2(b)-\log^2(a),\tag{3}$$ leading to $$ \int_{0}^{+\infty}\frac{\log(x)}{(x+a)(x+b)}\,dx = \frac{\log^2(b)-\log^2(a)}{2(b-a)}\tag{3} $$ as wanted. An alternative is to use Feynman's trick.

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\sin \pi x}{(1-x)^x x^{1-x}}dx$

<think>
$\DeclareMathOperator{Im}{Im}$ This answer will have a method that does not mention contour integration nor the residue theorem. Notice: $$\int^1_0 \frac{\sin \pi x}{(1-x)^x x^{1-x}}dx=-\Im\int_0^1\frac1x\left(1- \frac1x\right)^{-x}dx$$ If one were to expand $e^{-x\ln(1-\frac1x)}$ or $\frac1{x-1}e^{(1-x)\ln(1-\frac1x)}$ with $e^x$ ’s MacLaurin series, the value would be off by $\pi$ . However, splitting the integral and expanding like so resolve the problem: $$-\Im\int_0^1\frac1x\left(1-\frac1x\right)^{-x}dx= \Im\int_0^1\left(1-\frac1x\right)\left(1-\frac1x\right)^{-x}dx-\Im\underbrace{\int_0^1\left(1-\frac1x\right)^{-x}dx}_{x\to1-x}=2\Im\int_0^1\left(1-\frac1x\right)^{1-x}dx=2\Im\int_0^1\frac{x-1}x\left(1-\frac1x\right)^{-x}dx=\Im\sum_{n=0}^\infty\frac1{n!}\int_0^12(-1)^n(1-x)x^{n-1}\ln^n\left(1-\frac1x\right)dx$$ One can see the $n=0$ term is $0$ and use $n$ th derivatives and the beta function. Then, one can use beta function properties and get a Pochhammer symbol $(x)_n$ expression $$\Im\int_0^12(-1)^n(1-x)x^{n-1}\ln^n\left(1-\frac1x\right)dx=\Im \frac{d^n}{da^n}\left.\int_0^12 (-1)^{a+n} x^{n-1-a} (1-x)^{a+1}\right|_{a=0}=2(-1)^n\frac{d^n}{da^n}\left.\sin(\pi a) B(n-a,a+2)\right|_{a=0}= -\frac{2\pi}{(n+1)!}\frac{d^n}{da^n}\left.\prod_{j=-1}^{n-1}(a-j)\right|_{a=0}=-\frac{2\pi}{(n+1)!}\frac{d^n}{da^n}(a-n+1)_{n+1}|_{a=0}$$ $(a-n+1)_{n+1}$ can be a polynomial of degree $n+1$ in $a-n+1$ that contains Stirling numbers of the first kind $S_n^{(k)}$ and the $(n+1)$ th and $n$ th power terms would survive due to the $n$ th derivative. $S_{n+1}^{(n)}=-\frac12n(n+1)$ $$-\frac{2\pi}{(n+1)!}\frac{d^n}{da^n}(a-n+1)_{n+1}|_{a=0}=\frac{2\pi}{(n+1)!}\sum_{k=n}^{n+1}(-1)^{k+n} S_{n+1}^{(k)} \frac{d^n}{da^n}\left.(a-n+1)^k\right|_{a=0}= \frac{2\pi S_{n+1}^{(n)}}{n+1}+2\pi(n-1) S_{n+1}^{(n+1)}=\pi(n-2)$$ Therefore: $$\int^1_0 \frac{\sin \pi x}{(1-x)^x x^{1-x}}dx=\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{\pi(n-2)}{n!}=\boxed{\pi(e-2)}$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{(1 + x^n)^m}$

<think>
Herein assume $n > 1$ , so that the integral converges. Define $$J_n(m) := \int_0^\infty \frac{dx}{(1 + x^n)^m},$$ so that our integral is $I_n = -J_n'(0)$ . Substituting $x = \tan^{\frac 2n} \theta$ transforms the integral to $$J_n(m) = \frac2n \int_0^{\frac\pi2} \sin^{\frac{2 - n}n} \theta \cos^{\frac{(2 m - 1) n - 2}n} \theta \,d\theta = \frac1n \mathrm{B}\left(\frac1n, m - \frac1n\right) = n \frac{\Gamma\left(\frac1n\right) \Gamma(m - \frac1n)}{\Gamma(m)} ,$$ where $\mathrm B$ and $\Gamma$ respectively denote the beta and gamma functions. Now, differentiating with respect to $m$ and setting $m = 1$ recovers $$I_n = -J_n'(1) = -\frac1n \Gamma\left(\frac1n\right) \Gamma\left(1 - \frac1n\right) \left(\gamma + \psi\left(1 - \frac1n\right)\right) ,$$ where $\psi$ denotes the digamma function, i.e., $\psi := (\log \Gamma)'$ . Invoking Euler's Reflection Formula ( $\Gamma(x) \Gamma(1 - x) = \pi \csc \pi x$ ) and the writing the digamma function in terms of the harmonic numbers $H_s$ (generalized to real index $s$ ) as $\psi(x) = H_{x - 1} - \gamma$ gives $$\boxed{\int_0^\infty \frac{\log(1 + x^n) \,dx}{1 + x^n} = -\frac{\pi}{n} H_{-\frac1n} \csc \frac\pi n}.$$ The special case $n = 2$ gives the well-known value $I_2 = \pi \log 2$ , which can also be derived by other means. Expanding in a series as $n \searrow 1$ gives $$\int_0^\infty \frac{\log(1 + x^n) \,dx}{1 + x^n} \sim \frac{1}{(n - 1)^2} + \frac{1}{(n - 1)} + \zeta(3) (n - 1) + \cdots ,$$ where $\cdots$ denotes a remainder in $O((n - 1)^2)$ , where $\zeta$ denotes the Riemann zeta function . Expanding in a series as $n \to \infty$ gives $$\int_0^\infty \frac{\log(1 + x^n) \,dx}{1 + x^n} \sim \frac{\zeta(2)}n + \frac{\zeta(3)}{n^2} + \frac{7 \zeta(4)}{2 n^3} + \cdots ,$$ where now $\cdots$ denotes a remainder in $O\left(\frac1{n^4}\right)$ .

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\frac{x}{1+x^2}\log ^2\left(\frac{x}{1-x}\right)dx$

<think>
For the first problem $$I=\int \frac{x}{1+x^2} \log ^2\left(\frac{x}{1-x}\right)\,dx$$ $$\frac{x}{1-x}=t \implies x=\frac{t}{t+1}\implies dx=\frac{dt}{(t+1)^2}$$ $$I=\int\frac{t }{2 t^3+4 t^2+3 t+1}\log ^2(t)\,dt$$ Write $$A=\frac{t }{2 t^3+4 t^2+3 t+1}=\frac{t }{2(t+1)(t-a)(t-b)}$$ where $$a=-\frac{1+i}{2}\qquad \text{and} \qquad b=-\frac{1-i}{2}$$ Using partial fraction decomposition $$A=-\frac{1}{2 (a+1) (b+1) (t+1)}+\frac 1{2(a-b)}\Bigg(\frac{a}{(a+1) (t-a)} -\frac{b}{(b+1) (t-b)} \Bigg)$$ So, we face three integrals $$J_c=\int \frac{\log ^2(t)}{t+c}\,dt$$ Two integrations by parts lead to $$J_c=\log ^2(t)\, \log \left(1+\frac{t}{c}\right)+2 \,\log (t)\, \text{Li}_2\left(-\frac{t}{c}\right)-2\, \text{Li}_3\left(-\frac{t}{c}\right)$$ Recombing the antiderivatives and then using the bounds $(0,\infty)$ , the raw result is $$\frac{1}{6} \left(\log ^3(1-i)+\log ^3(1+i)+\pi ^2 (\log (1-i)+\log (1+i))\right)$$ Simplifying the complex numbers $$I=\int_0^1 \frac{x}{1+x^2} \ln ^2\left(\frac{x}{1-x}\right)\,dx=\frac{1}{96} \log (2) \left(13 \pi ^2+4 \log ^2(2)\right)$$ For the extension $$I_n=\int \frac{x}{1+x^2} \log ^n\left(\frac{x}{1-x}\right)\,dx$$ you can keep the same approach which will require more integration by parts $$\int \frac{\log ^3(t)}{t+c}\,dt=\log ^3(t) \log \left(1+\frac{t}{c}\right)+3 \log ^2(t) \text{Li}_2\left(-\frac{t}{c}\right)-$$ $$6 \log (t) \text{Li}_3\left(-\frac{t}{c}\right)+6 \text{Li}_4\left(-\frac{t}{c}\right)$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\cos\frac{x}{2}\cos(x)^{{3/2}}\cos(2nx)dx$

<think>
Result : For $n>1$ , $$I_n = \int_0^{\pi/2}\cos\frac x2 \cos^{3/2}x\cos(2nx)dx = \frac{\pi}{8\sqrt2} \binom {3/2}{n+1} $$ Proof : Substitute $t =\cos x$ along with $\cos (2n x )= T_{2n}(t)$ , the Chebyshev polynomials, to evaluate the summation \begin{align} \sum_{n=0}^\infty I_n a^{2n} =& \ \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{t^{3/2}}{\sqrt{1-t}}\bigg( \sum_{n=0}^\infty T_{2n}(t)a^{2n}\bigg)dt\\ =& \ \frac{1}{2\sqrt{2}}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{t^{3/2}}{\sqrt{1-t}} \sum_{n=0}^\infty \bigg(T_{n}(t)a^n+ T_{n}(-t) a^{n}\bigg)dt\\ =& \ \frac{1}{2\sqrt{2}}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{t^{3/2}}{\sqrt{1-t}}\left(\frac{1-at}{1-2at+a^2}+ \frac{1+at}{1+2at+a^2}\right)dt\\ =& \ \frac{\pi}{8\sqrt2}\bigg[\frac32 + a^2+\frac{(1+a^2)^{3/2}-1}{a^2}\bigg]\\ = &\ \frac{\pi}{8\sqrt2}\bigg[3+\frac{11}8 a^2 + \sum_{n=2}^\infty \binom {3/2}{n+1}a^{2n}\bigg] \end{align} Match the coefficients of $a^{2n}$ to obtain $I_0=\frac{3\pi}{8\sqrt2}$ , $I_1=\frac{11\pi}{64\sqrt2}$ $$I_{n>1}= \frac{\pi}{8\sqrt2} \binom {3/2}{n+1} = \frac{3\pi}{8\sqrt2}\frac{(-1)^{n+1}(2n-3)!!}{[2(n+1)]!!} $$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\arctan\left(\frac{2a}{x}\right)\sin(bx)\, dx$

<think>
An alternate generalization we can go for is this, $$I_k=\int_0^\infty \arctan\left(\frac{1}{x^k}\right) \, dx$$ $$I_k\underset{x\to \frac1x}=\int_0^\infty \frac{\arctan\left(x^k\right)}{x^2} \, dt\underset{ibp}={k\int_0^\infty\frac{x^k}{x^2(1+x^{2k})}}\,dx$$ $\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{m-1}}{1+x^n} \, dx = \frac{\pi}{n\sin\left(\frac{\pi m}{n}\right)}\tag1$ $$I_k\underset{m=k-1,n=2k}\implies k\frac{\pi}{(2k)\sin\left(\frac{\pi (k-1)}{2k}\right)}\implies \frac{\pi}{2\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2k}\right)}$$ $$\boxed{\int_0^\infty \arctan\left(\frac{1}{x^k}\right) \, dx=\frac{\pi}{2\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2k}\right)}}$$ Set $k=2\implies I_2=\frac{\pi}{\sqrt2}$ Furthermore, we can go for is this, $$I=\int_0^\infty \arctan\left(\frac{a}{x^k}\right) \, dx$$ $$I_k\underset{x\to \frac1x}=\int_0^\infty \frac{\arctan\left(ax^k\right)}{x^2} \, dx\underset{ibp}={ak\int_0^\infty\frac{x^k}{x^2(1+(ax)^{2k})}}\,dx$$ Substitute $(ax)^{k}\to x$ and re-use $(1)$ $$\boxed{\int_0^\infty \arctan\left(\frac{a}{x^k}\right) \, dx=\frac{\pi\sqrt[k]{a}}{2\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2k}\right)}}$$ Off topic : Here are some more versions, \begin{align} \int_0^\infty x^p \arctan x \, dx &= \frac{\pi}{2(p+1)} \csc\left(\frac{p\pi}{2}\right) \\ \\ \int_0^\infty \arctan\left(\frac{2a}{x}\right) \sin(bx) \, dx &= \frac{\pi}{b} e^{-ab} \sinh(ab) \\ \\ \int_0^\infty \frac{a}{x} \arctan x \cos(bx) \, dx &= \frac{1}{2b} \left[ e^{-ab} \, \text{Ei}(ab) - e^{ab} \, \text{Ei}(-ab) \right] && \\ \\ \int_0^\infty \arctan\left( \frac{2ax}{x^2 + c^2} \right) \sin(bx) \, dx &= \frac{\pi}{b} e^{-b \sqrt{a^2 + c^2}} \sinh(ab) \\ \\ \int_0^\infty \arctan\left( \frac{2}{x^2} \right) \cos(bx) \, dx &= \frac{\pi}{b} e^{-b} \sin b\end{align}

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{x\sin(x)}{a+\cos(x)}dx$

<think>
Aussuming $a>0$ $$I=\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{x\sin (x)}{a+\cos (x)}dx$$ Integrating by parts $$\int\frac{x\sin (x)}{a+\cos (x)}dx=-x \log (a+\cos (x))+\int \log (a+\cos (x))\,dx$$ Using $$\log (a+\cos (x))=\log(a)+\sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^{n+1} \,\frac {\cos^n(x)}{n\, a^n }$$ $$I=\sqrt \pi\,\sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^{n+1} \,\frac{\Gamma \left(\frac{n}{2}+\frac{1}{2}\right)}{n^2 \, \Gamma \left(\frac{n}{2}\right)\,a^n}$$ Using generalized hypergeometric function $$\color{blue}{I=\frac{\pi}{2} \log \left(\frac{1}{2} \left(1+\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{a^2}}\right)\right)+\frac{1}{a}\, _3F_2\left(\frac{1}{2},1,1;\frac{3}{2},\frac{3}{2};\frac{1}{a^2}\right)} $$ Notice that $$\, _3F_2\left(\frac{1}{2},1,1;\frac{3}{2},\frac{3}{2};\frac{1}{a^2}\right)=\sqrt \pi\,\, \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{n!}{(2 n+1)^2 \left(n-\frac{1}{2}\right)!\,a^{2n}}$$ If $b_n$ is the summand $$\frac{b_{n+1}}{b_n}=\frac{2 (n+1) (2 n+1)}{a^2 (2 n+3)^2}=\frac 1 {a^2} \Bigg(1-\frac{3}{2n}+O\left(\frac{1}{n^2}\right)\Bigg)$$ Edit For small values of $a$ $$I=-\frac{\pi}{2} \log (2 a)+\log \left(\frac{2 e}{a}\right)\,a+\frac 1 {36}\log \left(\frac{64}{e a^6}\right)\,a^3+ O(a^5)$$ For large values of $a$ $$I=\frac{1}{a}-\frac{\pi }{8 a^2}+\frac{2}{9 a^3}-\frac{3 \pi }{64 a^4}+O\left(\frac{1}{a^5}\right)$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{2\pi}\sin(x)^{{2n}}\cos(2nx)\, dx$

<think>
Substitute $\sin(x) = \frac{\exp(ix) - \exp(-ix)}{2i}$ and $\cos(2nx) = \frac{\exp(2inx) + \exp(-2inx)}{2}$ . $$\int_0^{2\pi} \sin^{2n}(x) \cos(2nx)\, dx =\\ \frac{1}{2^{2n+1}(-1)^n}\int_0^{2\pi} \sum\limits_{k=0}^{2n} \binom{2n}{k} (-1)^k\cdot \exp((2n - 2k) \cdot ix) \cdot (\exp(2inx) + \exp(-2inx))\, dx = \\ \frac{1}{2^{2n+1}(-1)^n}\sum\limits_{k=0}^{2n} \binom{2n}{k}\int_0^{2\pi}(-1)^k\cdot(\exp(ix\cdot(4n - 2k)) + \exp(-2ixk)))\, dx $$ Because for non-zero integer $m$ , $\int_0^{2\pi} \exp(imx)\, dx = 0$ , all the integrals under $\sigma$ except $k = 0$ and $k = 2n$ are $0$ , and these two are $2\pi$ each. This gives the value you found: $\frac{4\pi}{2^{2n + 1}(-1)^n} = (-1)^n \frac{\pi}{2^{2n-1}}$ .

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi/2}x\cos(x)\,(\sin(x)^{{a+1}})'dx$

<think>
An elementary (enough) deduction of the (already mentioned) equality $$\boxed{I(a)=\frac{\pi^{3/2}}{4}\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{a+1}2\right)}{\Gamma\left(\frac{a+2}2\right)}-\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{\prod_{k=1}^{n-1}(a+2k)^2}{\prod_{k=1}^{2n}(a+k)}.\quad(\Re a>-1)}$$ We note that $$(a+1)\big(I(a)-I(a+2)\big)=\int_0^{\pi/2}x\cos x\,(\sin^{a+1}x)'\,dx$$ and integrate by parts; this yields the recurrence $$I(a)=\frac{a+2}{a+1}I(a+2)-\frac1{(a+1)(a+2)}.$$ Reusing it with $a+2$ in place of $a$ , we get $$I(a)=\frac{(a+2)(a+4)}{(a+1)(a+3)}I(a+4)-\frac1{(a+1)(a+2)}-\frac{a+2}{(a+1)(a+3)(a+4)}$$ and then, by induction (I'm writing it expanded intentionally), \begin{align} I(a)&=\frac{(a+2)(a+4)\cdots(a+2n)}{(a+1)(a+3)\cdots(a+2n-1)}I(a+2n) \\&-\frac{1}{(a+1)(a+2)}-\frac{a+2}{(a+1)(a+3)(a+4)} \\&-\dots-\frac{(a+2)(a+4)\cdots(a+2n-2)}{(a+1)(a+3)\cdots(a+2n-1)(a+2n)}. \end{align} And now we take $n\to\infty$ . The fact that $$\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{(a+2)(a+4)\cdots(a+2n)}{(a+1)(a+3)\cdots(a+2n-1)}\frac1{\sqrt n}=\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{a+1}2\right)}{\Gamma\left(\frac{a+2}2\right)}$$ may be obtained using infinite product representations of $\Gamma$ , or just the known limit $$\lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{\Gamma(x+a)}{x^a\,\Gamma(x)}=1.$$ And Laplace's method gives the remaining piece: $$\lim_{a\to\infty}I(a)\sqrt{a}=(\pi/2)^{3/2}\implies\lim_{n\to\infty}I(a+2n)\sqrt{n}=\frac{\pi^{3/2}}4.$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{1}^{\infty}\cos \left(x^x\right)dx$

<think>
Too long for a comment. What you did is very correct. You could also consider that $$I= \int_1^\infty \cos \left(x^x\right)\,dx=\int_1^{r_0} \cos \left(x^x\right)\,dx+\sum_{n=0}^\infty \int_{r_n}^{r_{n+1}} \cos \left(x^x\right)\,dx$$ where $$r_k=\exp\Big({W(t)}\Big)\qquad \text{where}\qquad t=\log \Big(2k+1)\frac \pi 2\Big)$$ $W(t)$ being the principal branch of Lambert function. Consider $$J_n=\int_{r_n}^{r_{n+1}} \cos \left(x^x\right)\,dx$$ which do not show a closed form but which do not make any problem from a numerical point of view (even for a very high accuracy). They form an alternating series and a bit of heuristics shows that, asymptotically, $$\left| \frac{J_{n+1}}{J_n}\right|=1-\frac 1n+\frac 1{n^2}$$ The partial sums (up to $n=p$ ) converge slowly $$\left( \begin{array}{cc} p & S_p \\ 100 & -0.193849 \\ 200 & -0.193185 \\ 300 & -0.192967 \\ 400 & -0.192859 \\ 500 & -0.192795 \\ 600 & -0.192753 \\ 700 & -0.192722 \\ 800 & -0.192700 \\ 900 & -0.192682 \\ 1000 & -0.192669 \\ \cdots &\cdots \\ \infty & -0.192547 \\ \end{array} \right)$$ Notice that a direct integration is just a nightmare. What is interesting to notice is that $$\int_1^\infty \cos \left(x^x\right)\,dx=\int_1^\infty \frac{\cos (y)}{y\, (1+W(\log (y)))}\,dy$$ which does not make any problem for numerical integration. Moreover, the integrand can be roughly bounded by $$\frac{2 \cos (y)}{ 3y}<\frac{\cos (y)}{y\, (1+W(\log (y)))}< \frac{ \cos (y)}{2y}$$ giving for the integral $$-\frac 23\,\text{Ci}(1) < I < -\frac 12\,\text{Ci}(1)$$ Using the average $$I \sim -\frac 7{12}\,\text{Ci}(1)=-0.196819$$ Edit Have a look here to see how nice is the plot of the integrand. If the link is broken, give Wolfram Alpha Plot[Cos[y]/(y*(1 + ProductLog[Log[y]])),{y,1,20}]

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}}-\left(1-\sqrt{4p}\right)\log\left(p\right)dp$

<think>
Disclaimer: This isn't very elegant and just brute-forces through the solution. You're trying to find $$P(a+b\ge c,a+c\ge b,b+c\ge a|a,b,c\sim U(0,1),b^2-4ac\ge0)$$ which is equal to $$\frac{P(a+b\ge c,a+c\ge b,b+c\ge a,b^2-4ac\ge0|a,b,c\sim U(0,1))}{P(b^2-4ac\ge0 | a,b,c\sim U(0,1))}$$ Since $a,b,c$ are chosen uniformly, we can directly set up an integral for the denominator as $$\iiint_{R}[b^2-4ac\ge0]dA$$ where $[b^2-4ac\ge0]$ , using the Iverson bracket , is $1$ if the condition is satisfied and $0$ otherwise, and $R=[0,1]^3$ . Simplifying and setting up the bounds a bit more clearly, this is equal to $$\int_0^1\int_0^1\int_{\min(\sqrt{4ac},1)}^11dbdcda=\int_0^1\int_0^1(1-\min(\sqrt{4ac},1))dcda$$ With the substitution $(p,r)\mapsto (p/r,r)=(a,c)$ . This is equal to $$\int_{0}^{1}\int_{p}^{1}\frac{1}{r}\left(1-\min\left(\sqrt{4p},1\right)\right)drdp = \int_{0}^{1}-\left(1-\min\left(\sqrt{4p},1\right)\right)\ln\left(p\right)dp$$ which simplifies to $$\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}}-\left(1-\sqrt{4p}\right)\ln\left(p\right)dp$$ If you do go through the trouble of integrating this, or just plug it into WolframAlpha , you get that the denominator is $$\frac{1}{36}(5+\ln(64))$$ Similarly, the numerator is given by $$\int_0^1\int_0^1\int_0^1[a+b\ge c,a+c\ge b,b+c\ge a,b^2-4ac\ge0]dadcdb$$ The integrand is symmetric about $c=a$ , so we can just consider $a\le c$ and multiply by 2. $$2\int_0^1\int_0^1\int_0^c[a+b\ge c,a+c\ge b,b^2-4ac\ge0]dadcdb$$ where we know $b+c\ge a$ since $c\ge a$ . With the substitution $(s,m)\mapsto ((s+m)/2,(s-m)/2) = (a,c)$ , we get $$\int_{0}^{1}\int_{0}^{b}\int_{b}^{\min(2-m,\sqrt{b^{2}+m^{2}})}1dsdmdb=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{0}^{b}(\min(2-m,\sqrt{b^{2}+m^{2}})-b)dmdb$$ which is equal to $$\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\min\left(b,1-\frac{b^{2}}{4}\right)}^{b}\left(2-m-b\right)dmdb+\int_{0}^{1}\int_{0}^{\min\left(b,1-\frac{b^{2}}{4}\right)}\left(\sqrt{b^{2}+m^{2}}-b\right)dmdb$$ WolframAlpha spits out as $$\frac{1}{36}(-93+64\sqrt{2}+\ln(64))$$ or we can continue splitting up the integrals to get $$\int_{0}^{-2+2\sqrt{2}}\int_{0}^{b}\left(\sqrt{b^{2}+m^{2}}-b\right)dmdb+\int_{-2+2\sqrt{2}}^{1}\int_{0}^{1-\frac{b^{2}}{4}}\left(\sqrt{b^{2}+m^{2}}-b\right)dmdb+\int_{-2+2\sqrt{2}}^{1}\int_{1-\frac{b^{2}}{4}}^{b}\left(2-m-b\right)dmdb$$ and continue on integrating. If we then looked at the conditional probabilities, we get $$\frac{\frac{1}{36}(-93+64\sqrt{2}+\ln(64))}{\frac{1}{36}(5+\ln(64))}=\frac{-93+64\sqrt{2}+\ln(64)}{5+\ln(64)}\approx 0.182178$$ which is pretty close to what your simulation got.

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\log(1+x)}{1-x^2+x^4}dx$

<think>
Split the integration range \begin{align} I& =\int _0^{\infty }\frac{\ln (1+x)}{1-x^2+x^4}dx= \int _0^1\frac{(1+x^2)\ln (1+x)-x^2\ln x}{1-x^2+x^4}dx\\ \end{align} Then, integrate by parts via $$d\left( \cot^{-1}\frac x{x^2-1}\right)=\frac{1+x^2}{1-x^2+x^4}dx$$ $$d\left( \frac12\tan^{-1}\frac x{1-x^2} - \frac1{2\sqrt3}\tanh^{-1}\frac {\sqrt3x}{1+x^2}\right)= \frac{x^2}{1-x^2+x^4}dx $$ to express the integral as \begin{align} I= I_1 -\frac1{2\sqrt3}I_2 +\frac12I_3\tag1 \end{align} where $$ I_1 = \int_0^1 \frac{dx}{1+x} \cot^{-1}\frac {x}{1-x^2},\>\>\>\>\> I_2 = \int_0^1 \frac{dx}{x} \tanh^{-1}\frac {\sqrt3x}{1+x^2}\\ I_3 = \int_0^1 \frac{dx}{x} \tan^{-1}\frac {x}{1-x^2} $$ To evaluate $I_1$ , let $J_1(a) =\int_0^1 \frac{dx}{1+x} \cot^{-1}\frac {2x\sin a}{1-x^2}$ \begin{align} J_1’(a) &= \int_0^1 \frac{2\cos a (x-x^2)dx}{(x^2+1)^2-(2x\cos a)^2}= - \frac\pi4\tan\frac a2+\frac12\left( a\>{\csc a}+ \ln\tan\frac a2\right) \end{align} \begin{align} I_1 &=J_1(\frac\pi6) = J_1(0)+\int_0^{\frac\pi6}J_1’(a)da \\ &= \frac\pi2\ln2-\frac\pi4 \int_0^{\frac\pi6}\tan\frac a2 da+\frac12\int_0^{\frac\pi6} d\left( a\ln\tan\frac a2\right)\\ &=\frac\pi2\ln2 -\frac\pi2\ln\cos\frac\pi{12}-\frac\pi{12}\ln\tan\frac\pi{12}= \frac\pi6\ln(2+\sqrt3)\tag2 \end{align} To evaluate $I_2$ , let $J_2(a) =\int_0^1 \frac{dx}{x} \tanh^{-1}\frac {2ax}{1+x^2}$ \begin{align} J_2’(a) &= \int_0^1 \frac{2 (1+x^2)}{(x^2+1)^2-(2ax)^2}dx = \frac\pi2\frac1{\sqrt{1-a^2}} \end{align} \begin{align} I_2 &=J_2(\frac{\sqrt3}2) = \int_0^{\frac{\sqrt3}2}J_2’(a)da = \frac\pi2 \int_0^{\frac{\sqrt3}2} \frac{da}{\sqrt{1-a^2}}=\frac{\pi^2}6\tag3 \end{align} To evaluate $I_3$ $$I_3 = \int_0^1 \frac{dx}{x} \tan^{-1}\frac {x}{1-x^2} = \int_0^1 \frac{\tan^{-1}x}x dx+ \int_0^1\underset{x^3\to x}{\frac{\tan^{-1}x^3}x}dx\\ = \frac43\int_0^1 \frac{\tan^{-1}x}x dx= \frac43G\tag4 $$ Plug (2), (3) and (4) into (1) to obtain $$I=\frac\pi6\ln(2+\sqrt3) -\frac{\pi^2}{12\sqrt3} +\frac23G $$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\log(x)\frac{1-x}{1-x^4}dx$

<think>
Note that $1-x^4=(1-x)(1+x+x^2+x^3)$ . Thus, we have $$\begin{align} \int_0^\infty \log(x) \frac{1-x}{1-x^4}\,dx&=\int_0^\infty \frac{\log(x)}{(1+x)(1+x^2)}\,dx\\\\ \end{align}$$ RESIDUES: Now, let's evaluate the integral of $\frac{\log^2(z)}{(1+z)(1+z^2)}$ around the classical keyhole contour (shown in the diagram of the posted question). Proceeding, the residue theorem guarantees that $$\oint_{C_{kh}}\frac{\log^2(z)}{(1+z)(1+z^2)}\,dz=2\pi i \sum_{i=1}^3 \text{Res}\left(\frac{\log^2(z)}{(1+z)(1+z^2)},z=z_i\right)$$ where $z_1=-1$ , $z_2=i$ , and $z_3=-i$ . Evaluating the residues, reveals $$\begin{align}\text{Res}\left(\frac{\log^2(z)}{(1+z)(1+z^2)},z=-1\right)&=\frac{-\pi^2}{2}\tag{1a}\\\\ \text{Res}\left(\frac{\log^2(z)}{(1+z)(1+z^2)},z=i\right)&=\frac{-\pi^2/4}{(1+i)2i}\tag{1b}\\\\ \text{Res}\left(\frac{\log^2(z)}{(1+z)(1+z^2)},z=-i\right)&=\frac{-9\pi^2/4}{(1-i)(-2i)}\tag{1c} \end{align}$$ CONTOUR INTEGRAL: In addition, we see that $$\begin{align} \oint_{C_{kh}}\frac{\log^2(z)}{(1+z)(1+z^2)}\,dz&=\int_0^\infty \left(\frac{\log^2(x)}{(1+x)(1+x^2)}-\frac{(\log(x)+i2\pi)^2}{(1+x)(1+x^2)}\right)\,dx\\\\ &=-i4\pi \int_0^\infty \frac{\log(x)}{(1+x)(1+x^2)}\,dx\\\\&+4\pi^2\int_0^\infty \frac{1}{(1+x)(1+x^2)}\,dx\tag2 \end{align}$$ Note that it is a straightforward exercise (left to the reader) to show that the contributions to the contour integral from integration around the semi-circles at $|z|=R$ and $|z|=\varepsilon$ vanish as $R\to \infty$ and $\varepsilon \to 0^+$ , respectively. Putting together $(1a)-(1c)$ and $(2)$ , we find that $$\int_0^\infty \frac{\log(x)}{(1+x)(1+x^2)}\,dx=-\pi^2/16$$ Aside : As a bonus, we also find that $$\int_0^\infty \frac{1}{1+x+x^2+x^3}\,dx=\pi/4 $$
</think>

For the square cross-section at a particular $x$ , the side length on the base is $2\sqrt{a^2-x^2}$ , so the cross-sectional area should be $4\left(a^2-x^2\right)$ -- $4\times$ what you used for $dV$ . $$dV = 4\left(a^2-x^2\right)dx$$ As the circular base goes from $x=-a$ to $x=a$ , the limits of integration may instead be from $-a$ to $a$ . This explains $2\times$ out of the scaling factor in your $V$ . These together explain the seemingly arbitrary $8\times$ scaling factor in your $V$ . $$\begin{align*} V &= \int_{-a}^a 4\left(a^2-x^2\right) dx\\ &= \int_{-a}^0 4\left(a^2-x^2\right) dx + \int_0^a 4\left(a^2-x^2\right) dx\\ &= \int_{a}^0 4\left(a^2-(-x)^2\right) d(-x) + \int_0^a 4\left(a^2-x^2\right) dx\\ &= \int_0^a 4\left(a^2-x^2\right) dx + \int_0^a 4\left(a^2-x^2\right) dx\\ &= 8\int_0^a \left(a^2-x^2\right) dx\\ &= 8\left[a^2x - \frac{x^3}{3}\right]_0^a\\ &= \frac{16}{3}a^3 \end{align*}$$ (Also, in an earlier version , you had an incorrect $\pi$ factor that got lost after incorrect integration.)

On the latter integral, start by substituting the integrand with an equivalent expression on the interval $$I=\int_0^{\pi/2}\arccos\left(\sqrt\frac{\cos x}{1+2\cos x}\right)dx$$ $$=\int_0^{\pi/2}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{1}2 \arctan\left(2\sqrt{\cos (x)(1+\cos(x))}\right)\right)dx=\frac{\pi^2}{4}-\frac{1}{2}\int_0^1\frac{\arctan(2\sqrt x\sqrt{1+x})}{\sqrt{1+x}\sqrt{1-x}}dx$$ Evaluate the ladder integral using a double integral (which can be bypassed with Leibniz's rule/Feynman's trick). $$J=\int_0^1\frac{\arctan(2\sqrt x\sqrt{1+x})}{\sqrt{1+x}\sqrt{1-x}}=\int_0^1\frac{\arctan(2y\sqrt x\sqrt{1+x})}{\sqrt{1+x}\sqrt{1-x}}\Bigg|_{y=0}^{y=1}dx$$ $$=\int_0^1\int_0^1\frac{2\sqrt x\sqrt{1+x}}{\sqrt{1+x}\sqrt{1-x}(1+4xy^2(1+x))}dxdy$$ Substitute $u=\sqrt{\frac{1}{x}-1}$ $$J=\int_0^1\int_0^\infty\frac{4}{x^4+2(1+2y^2)x^2+(1+8y^2)}dxdy$$ $$=2\pi\sqrt2\int_0^1\frac{dy}{\sqrt{1+8y^2}\sqrt{(\sqrt{1+8y^2}+1)(\sqrt{1+8y^2}+3)}}$$ This has a simple elementary antiderivative that can be found using $\sqrt{1+8y^2}+2=\sec x$ $$I=\frac{\pi^2}{4}-\frac{1}{2}\frac{\pi^2}{6}=\frac{\pi^2}{6}$$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\tanh(x)- x}{x^3}dx$

<think>
$I = \int_0^\infty \frac{\tanh x -x}{x^3}dx + \int_0^\infty \frac{\tanh^2 x}{x^2} dx$ . Let's call the first integral $I_1 =\int_0^\infty \frac{\tanh x -x}{x^3}dx$ and the second term $I_2 = \int_0^\infty \frac{\tanh^2 x}{x^2} dx$ . In this post it has been shown that $I_2=\frac{14\zeta(3)}{\pi^2}$ . From the following identity, $$\tanh{x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{2x}{x^2 + (n+\frac{1}{2})^2 \pi^2},$$ it follows that, $$\frac{\tanh x - x}{x^3} = 2\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^2(x^2 + (n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2)} -\frac{1}{x^2}$$ $$= -\frac{1}{x^2} + 2\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2}\left(\frac{1}{x^2} - \frac{1}{(x^2 + (n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2)}\right)$$ $$ = \frac{1}{x^2}\left(-1 + \frac{8}{\pi^2} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(2n+1)^2}\right) - 2\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2} \frac{1}{(x^2 + (n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2)}$$ The coefficient of $\frac{1}{x^2}$ is 0 because $\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(2n+1)^2} = \frac{\pi^2}{8}$ . Therefore, $$\frac{\tanh x - x}{x^3}= -2\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2} \frac{1}{(x^2 + (n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2)}$$ Therefore, $$I_1 = \int_0^\infty \frac{\tanh x - x}{x^3} dx$$ $$= -2\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2} \int_0^\infty \frac{1}{(x^2 + (n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2)}dx$$ $$ = -2\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(n+\frac{1}{2})^2\pi^2}\frac{1}{(n+\frac{1}{2})\pi}\frac{\pi}{2}$$ $$ = -\frac{8}{\pi^2} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(2n+1)^3}$$ Now, $\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(2n+1)^3} = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^3} - \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(2n)^3} = \zeta(3) - \zeta(3)/8 = \frac{7 \zeta(3)}{8}$ . Therefore, $$\boxed{I_1 = \int_0^\infty \frac{\tanh x -x}{x^3}dx = -\frac{7\zeta(3)}{\pi^2}}.$$ Thus, $$I = -\frac{7\zeta(3)}{\pi^2} + \frac{14\zeta(3)}{\pi^2} = \boxed{\frac{7\zeta(3)}{\pi^2}}$$ Alternative method: Using integration by parts, $I_1 = \int_0^\infty \frac{\tanh x - x}{x^3} dx = \int_0^\infty \frac{\operatorname{sech}^2 x - 1}{2 x^2}dx = -\frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty \frac{\operatorname{tanh}^2 x}{x^2}dx= -I_2/2 = -7\zeta(3)/\pi^2$ .

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi}\frac{\sin(x)}{x}\, dx$

<think>
This is the partial sum of the Fourier series for the sawtooth wave where $S(x) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{\sin nx}{n} = \frac{\pi-x}{2}$ on $(0,2\pi)$ . The waveform has a discontinuity at $x=0$ and $S(x) \to \frac{\pi}{2}$ as $x \to 0+$ . Note that $$\int_0^\pi \frac{\sin x}{x} \, dx = 1.85194\ldots > \frac{\pi}{2}$$ However, the partial sums overshoot the waveform (Gibbs phenomena) and it is proved here that $$\limsup_{n \to \infty}\sup_{x \in [0,\pi]} S_n(x) \geqslant \int_0^\pi \frac{\sin x}{x} \, dx $$ We can prove that $\displaystyle|S_n(x)| \leqslant \int_0^\pi \frac{\sin x}{x} \, dx$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $x \in [0,2\pi]$ . By periodicity and anti-symmetry it is enough to consider the interval $[0,\pi]$ . Here the relative maxima of $S_n (x)$ occur at $x_{n,m} = \frac{2m+1}{n+1}\pi$ for $m = 0,1, \ldots, \lfloor\frac{n-1}{2} \rfloor$ . It can be shown that $S_n(x_{n,m}) > S_n(x_{n,m+1})$ so that there is an absolute maximum of $S_n(x)$ on $[0,\pi]$ at $x_{n,0} = \frac{\pi}{n+1}$ . Evaluate the integral: $\;\int_{0}^{\infty}\! \frac{dx}{(x^{2}+1)(\log(x)^{{2}}+\pi^{2})}$

<think>
We aim to evaluate the integral $$ I \;=\;\int_{0}^{\infty}\! \frac{\text{d}x}{\bigl(x^{2}+1\bigr)\bigl(\log^{2}(x)+\pi^{2}\bigr)}. $$ Put $x=e^{t}$ and $\text{d}x=e^{t}\,\text{d}t$ , so $x\in(0,\infty)$ maps to $t\in(-\infty,\infty)$ : $$ I=\frac12\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\ \frac{\text{d}t}{(t^{2}+\pi^{2})\,\cosh (t)}. $$ Now the integrand as $f(t)g(t)$ with $$f(t)=\operatorname{sech}(t) \quad \text{and} \quad g(t)=\frac{1}{t^{2}+\pi^{2}}.$$ Using the symmetric Fourier transform, we have the well-known formulas $$ \mathcal{F}_t[f(t)](\omega)= \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}\, \operatorname{sech}\!\Bigl(\frac{\pi\omega}{2}\Bigr),\qquad \mathcal{F}^{-1}_t[g(t)](\omega)= \frac{e^{-\pi|\omega|}}{\sqrt{2\pi}}. $$ The Parseval theorem says $$ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\!\frac{dt}{(t^{2}+\pi^{2})\,\cosh(t)} \;=\; \frac{1}{4}\! \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-\pi|\omega|}\operatorname{sech}\!\Bigl(\frac{\pi\omega}{2}\Bigr)\,\text{d}\omega \;=\; \frac{1}{2}\! \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\pi\omega}\operatorname{sech}\!\Bigl(\frac{\pi\omega}{2}\Bigr)\,\text{d}\omega $$ Make the substitution $u=e^{-\pi\omega}$ : $$ I=\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\sqrt{u}}{1+u}\,\text{d}u = \frac{2}{\pi} - \frac{1}{2}. $$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\frac{\tan^{\frac{1}{3}}x}{(\sin(x)+\cos(x))^2}dx$

<think>
firstly we have $$\int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\tan^{\frac{1}{3}}x}{(\sin x+\cos x)^2}dx=\int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\tan^{\frac{1}{3}}x}{(\tan x+1)^2} \sec^2x dx $$ now put $x\to \tan^{-1} x$ and get $$\int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\tan^{\frac{1}{3}}x}{(\sin x+\cos x)^2}dx=\int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^{\frac{1}{3}}}{(x+1)^2}dx $$ we can use the formula $$ \int_0^\infty \frac{x^n}{(x+1)^2}dx=\pi n \csc(\pi n) $$ So $$\int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\tan^{\frac{1}{3}}x}{(\sin x+\cos x)^2}dx=\pi \frac{1}{3} \csc \left(\pi \frac{1}{3} \right)=\frac{2\pi}{3\sqrt{3}}$$ the formula we used can be easily prove by gamma function , but if you need to solve that integral without gamma function we can find indefinite integral firstly put $x\to \frac{1}{x}$ So $$ \int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^{\frac{1}{3}}}{(x+1)^2}dx=\int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^{\frac{-1}{3}}}{(x+1)^2}dx $$ So $$ \int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^{\frac{1}{3}}}{(x+1)^2}dx=\frac{1}{2} \int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^{\frac{1}{3}}+x^{\frac{-1}{3}}}{(x+1)^2}dx $$ now put $x \to x^3$ and get $$ \int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^{\frac{1}{3}}}{(x+1)^2}dx= \int_0^{\infty} \frac{3x^2(x+\frac{1}{x})}{(x^3+1)^2}dx $$ we can use partial fraction but its too long so lets see this trick $$\frac{3x^2(x+\frac{1}{x})}{(x^3+1)^2}=\frac{3x(x^2+1)}{(x^3+1)^2}-\frac{1+x}{x^3+1}+\frac{1+x}{x^3+1}$$ $$=\frac{-x^4+2x^3+2x-1}{(x^3+1)^2}+\frac{1}{\left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right)^2+\frac{3}{4}}$$ So $$\int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^{\frac{1}{3}}}{(x+1)^2}dx=\frac{1}{2}\int_0^\infty \frac{-x^4+2x^3+2x-1}{(x^3+1)^2} dx+\frac{1}{2}\int_0^\infty \frac{1}{\left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right)^2+\frac{3}{4}}dx$$ first integral equals zero (using indefinite integral you can try with) and the second integral can be evaluate using arctan function $$ \frac{1}{2} \int_0^\infty \frac{1}{\left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right)^2+\frac{3}{4}}dx=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{2x-1}{\sqrt{3}} \right)\right)^\infty_0=\frac{2\pi}{3\sqrt{3}}$$ finally $$\int_0^{\pi/2} \frac{\tan^{\frac{1}{3}}x}{(\sin x+\cos x)^2}dx=\frac{2\pi}{3\sqrt{3}} $$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{z}\frac{\arcsin(\sqrt{w})}{\sqrt{w(1-w)}}dw$

<think>
By the Maclaurin expansion of the arctangent function \begin{align} \int_{0}^{1}\frac{\arctan(ax)}{x\sqrt{1-x}}\,dx &= \sum_{n\geq 0}\frac{(-1)^n a^{2n+1}}{2n+1}\int_{0}^{1}\frac{x^{2n}\,dx}{\sqrt{1-x}} \\ &= 2a\sum_{n\geq 0}\frac{(-1)^n a^{2n}4^{2n}}{(2n+1)(4n+1)\binom{4n}{2n}} \tag{1} \end{align} hence the LHS depends on $$ f(z) = \sum_{n\geq 0}\frac{4^n z^n}{(n+1)(2n+1)\binom{2n}{n}}\tag{2} $$ evaluated at $\pm ia$ . Since (see here , for instance) $$\sum_{n\geq 0}\frac{4^n z^n}{(2n+1)\binom{2n}{n}}=\frac{\arcsin(\sqrt{z})}{\sqrt{z(1-z)}}\tag{3}$$ the problem boils down to the determination of a primitive for the RHS of $(3)$ . $$ \int_{0}^{z}\frac{\arcsin(\sqrt{w})}{\sqrt{w(1-w)}}\,dw=\int_{0}^{\sqrt{z}}\frac{2\arcsin(v)}{\sqrt{1-v^2}}\,dv=\frac{\arcsin^2(\sqrt{z})}{z}\tag{4}$$ so the LHS of $(1)$ only depends on $\arcsin^2(\sqrt{ia})$ and its conjugate. In explicit terms, provided that $|a|\leq 1$ , $$ \int_{0}^{1}\frac{\arctan(ax)}{x\sqrt{1-x}}\,dx = 2\,\operatorname{Im}\left(\arcsin^2(\sqrt{ia})\right).\tag{5} $$
</think>

My attempt using Real Analysis: $$ I = \int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{x \sin(x)}{1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(x)} \, dx $$ By using integration by parts, we have: Let $ u = x $ , and $dv = \frac{\sin(x)}{1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(x)} \, dx$ . Hence, $du = dx $ , and $$ v = \frac{1}{2a} \ln\left(1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(x)\right). $$ So we have: $$ I = \frac{x}{2a} \ln\left(1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(x)\right) \bigg|_{0}^{\pi} - \frac{1}{2a} \int_{0}^{\pi} \ln\left(1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(x)\right) \, dx. $$ Thus, $$ I = \frac{\pi}{2a} \ln\left(1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(\pi)\right) - \frac{1}{2a} \int_{0}^{\pi} \ln\left(1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(x)\right) \, dx. $$ This simplifies to: $$ I = \frac{\pi}{a} \ln\left(1 + a\right) - \frac{1}{2a} \int_{0}^{\pi} \ln\left(1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(x)\right) \, dx. $$ Let us suppose: $$ S(a) = \int_{0}^{\pi} \ln\left(1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(x)\right) \, dx. $$ Then, $$ S'(a) = \int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{-2 \cos(x)}{1 + a^{2} - 2a \cos(x)} \, dx. $$ Let $t = \tan\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)$ . Thus, $$ S'(a) = -2 \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\frac{1 - t^{2}}{1 + t^{2}}}{1 + a^{2} - 2a \left(\frac{1 - t^{2}}{1 + t^{2}}\right)} \cdot \frac{2}{1 + t^{2}} \, dt. $$ It is easy to find: $$ S'(a) = \frac{2\pi}{a} \implies S(a) = 2\pi \ln(a) + c, \quad \text{where } c = 0. $$ Thus, we have: $$ S = 2\pi \ln(a). $$ So, $$ I = \frac{\pi}{a} \ln(a + 1) - \frac{1}{2a} \cdot (2\pi \ln(a)). $$ Finally, we get: $$ I = \frac{\pi}{a} \ln\left(\frac{a + 1}{a}\right). $$

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{\frac{1}{3}}^{3}\frac{\arctan(x)}{x^2-x+1}dx$

<think>
Let $$I_1=\int_{\frac{1}{3}}^{3} \frac{\arctan(x)}{x^2-x+1}dx$$ and $$I_2=\int_{\frac{1}{3}}^{3} \frac{\arctan(\tfrac1x)}{x^2-x+1}dx.$$ In the first equality you showed that $I_1=I_2.$ Then, I guess you tried to do the trick $I_1=\frac{I_1+I_2}2...$ $$I_1=\frac12\int_{\frac{1}{3}}^{3} \frac{\arctan(x)+\arctan(\tfrac1x)}{x^2-x+1}dx\\ =\frac12\int_{\frac{1}{3}}^{3} \frac{\frac{\pi}2}{x^2-x+1}dx\\ =\frac{\pi}4\int_{\frac{1}{3}}^{3} \frac{4}{(2x-1)^2+3}dx\\ =\frac{\pi}{2\sqrt3}\arctan(\tfrac{2x-1}{\sqrt3})\vert_{1/3}^3\\ =\frac\pi{2\sqrt3}(\arctan(\tfrac5{\sqrt3})-\arctan(-\tfrac1{3\sqrt3}))\\ =\frac\pi{2\sqrt3}\arctan(4\sqrt3) $$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{a x-x^2}-e^{-a x-x^2}}{x}d x$

<think>
Feynman’s trick Consider the parametrised integral by $a$ , $$ I(a)=\int_0^{\infty} \frac{e^{a x-x^2}-e^{-a x-x^2}}{x} d x $$ where $I(0)=0.$ $$ \begin{aligned} I’(a)=&\int_0^{\infty} e^{-\left(x-\frac{a}{2}\right)^2+\frac{a^2}{4}} d x-\int_0^{\infty} e^{-\left(x+\frac{a}{2}\right)^2+\frac{a^2}{4}} d x \\ = & e^{\frac{a^2}{a}}\left[\int_0^{\infty} e^{-\left(x-\frac{a}{2}\right)^2} d x-\int_0^{\infty} e^{-\left(x+\frac{a}{2}\right)^2} d x\right] \\ = & \frac{e^{\frac{a^2}{4}}}{2} \sqrt{\pi}\left[\operatorname{erf}\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)+1+\operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{a}{2}\right)\right] \\ = & \sqrt{\pi} e^{\frac{a^2}{4}} \end{aligned} $$ Integrating from $a=0$ to $1$ yields $$ I(1)=\sqrt{\pi} \int_0^1 e^{\frac{a^2}{4}} d a $$ Hence we can conclude that $$ \boxed{\int_0^{\infty} \frac{e^{x-x^2}-e^{-x-x^2}}{x} d x=\sqrt{\pi}\left[\sqrt{\pi} \operatorname{erfi}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right]=\pi\operatorname{erfi}\left( \frac{1}{2}\right)\approx {1.93193}\;} $$ which doesn’t agree with WA.

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{1}\left(\frac{(1-x^{3m+3})(1-x)}{1-x^3}\right)dx$

<think>
An important trick here is that sigma and integral signs can be changed around. $$\int \sum^b_{n=a} f\left(n,x\right)\, dx = \sum^b_{n=a} \int f\left(n,x\right) \,dx$$ And this is because $$\int \sum^b_{n=a} f(n,x)\, dx$$ $$\int f\left(a,x\right) + f((a+1),x) + f((a+2),x) + \dots +f\left((b-1),x\right) + f(b,x) $$ $$ = \int f(a,x)\,dx + \int f((a+1),x) \,dx + \dots + \int f((b-1),x)\, dx + \int f(b,x)\, dx$$ Therefore $$\begin{align*} \sum_{n=0}^m \frac{1}{(3n+1)(3n+2)} =& \sum_{n=0}^m \left( \frac{1}{3n+1} - \frac{1}{3n+2} \right) \\ =& \sum_{n=0}^m \int_0^1 \left( x^{3n} - x^{3n+1} \right) \mathrm{d} x \\ =& \int_0^1 \sum_{n=0}^m \left( x^{3n} - x^{3n+1} \right) \mathrm{d} x \\ =& \int_0^1 \left( \frac{(1-x^{3m+3}) (1-x)}{1-x^3} \right) \mathrm{d} x = \int_0^1 \frac{1-x^{3m+3}}{1+x + x^2} \mathrm{d} x \end{align*} $$ Also because $$ \sum_{n=0}^m \left( x^{3n} - x^{3n+1} \right) = \frac{(1-x^{3(m+1)})(1-x)}{1-x^3} $$ Now let us see how the final integral $$\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{(3n+1)(3n+2)} = \int_0^1 \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{1+x+x^2} $$ is evaluated. $$ x^2+x+1 = \left(x+\frac{1}{2}\right)^2+ \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^2$$ therefore if you skip two steps of substitution and do it once $$ x+\frac{1}{2} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \tan \theta$$ $$ dx = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \sec^{2} \theta$$ $$ \begin{eqnarray} \int \frac{dx}{1+x+x^2} = \int \frac{ \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \sec^{2} \theta}{\frac{3}{4} \sec^{2} \theta} {\mathrm{d} \theta} &=& \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \theta \\ &=& \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \tan^{-1} \left(\frac{2x+1}{\sqrt{3}}\right) \end{eqnarray} $$ $$ \Rightarrow \int_0^1 \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{1+x+x^2} = \frac{2\sqrt{3}}{3} \left( \tan^{-1} ( \frac{3}{\sqrt{3}} ) - \tan^{-1} ( \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} ) \right)$$ $$ = \frac{2\sqrt{3}}{3} \left( \frac{\pi}{3} - \frac{\pi}{6} \right) = \frac{\pi}{3\sqrt{3}}$$
</think>

Evaluate the integral: $\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\cos(x)}{x^2}x^{s-1}dx$

<think>
The sum term $$T(x) = \sum_{n\ge 1}\frac{\cos(nx)}{n^2} = x^2 \sum_{n\ge 1}\frac{\cos(nx)}{(xn)^2}$$ is harmonic and may be evaluated by inverting its Mellin transform. Put $$S(x) = \sum_{n\ge 1}\frac{\cos(nx)}{(xn)^2}$$ and recall the harmonic sum identity $$\mathfrak{M}\left(\sum_{k\ge 1} \lambda_k g(\mu_k x);s\right) = \left(\sum_{k\ge 1} \frac{\lambda_k}{\mu_k^s} \right) g^*(s)$$ where $g^*(s)$ is the Mellin transform of $g(x).$ In the present case we have $$\lambda_k = 1, \quad \mu_k = k \quad \text{and} \quad g(x) = \frac{\cos x}{x^2}.$$ We need the Mellin transform $g^*(s)$ of $g(x)$ which is $$\int_0^\infty \frac{\cos x}{x^2} x^{s-1} dx = \int_0^\infty \cos x \times x^{(s-2)-1} dx.$$ Now the Mellin transform of $\cos(x)$ was computed at this MSE link and found to be $$\Gamma(s) \cos(\pi s/2)$$ and therefore $$g^*(s) = \Gamma(s-2) \cos(\pi (s-2)/2) = \Gamma(s-2) \cos(\pi s/2 - \pi) = -\Gamma(s-2) \cos(\pi s/2).$$ Therefore the Mellin transform $Q(s)$ of $S(x)$ is given by $$ Q(s) = -\Gamma(s-2) \cos(\pi s/2) \zeta(s) \quad\text{because}\quad \sum_{k\ge 1} \frac{\lambda_k}{\mu_k^s} = \zeta(s).$$ Therefore the Mellin inversion integral for an expansion about zero is $$\frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{5/2-i\infty}^{5/2+i\infty} Q(s)/x^s ds$$ which we evaluate in the left half-plane $\Re(s)<5/2.$ The cosine term cancels the poles of the gamma function term at odd negative integers and the zeta function term the poles at even negative integers. We are left with just three poles. $$\begin{align} \mathrm{Res}(Q(s)/x^s; x=2) & = \frac{\pi^2}{6x^2} \\ \mathrm{Res}(Q(s)/x^s; x=1) & = -\frac{\pi}{2x} \quad\text{and}\\ \mathrm{Res}(Q(s)/x^s; x=0) & = \frac{1}{4}. \end{align}$$ Hence in a neighborhood of zero, $$S(x) = \frac{\pi^2}{6x^2} -\frac{\pi}{2x} +\frac{1}{4}.$$ Using $T(x) = x^2 S(x)$ this finally yields in a neigborhood of zero that $$T(x) = \frac{\pi^2}{6} -x\frac{\pi}{2} +x^2\frac{1}{4}.$$ Since $T(x)$ is periodic with period $2\pi$ the interval this approximation is good in $(0,2\pi).$ There is a theorem hiding here, namely that certain Fourier series can be evaluated by inverting their Mellin transforms which is not terribly surprising and which the reader is invited to state and prove.
</think>
